title: BCI Ontology: A Context-based Sense and Actuation Model for Brain-Computer Interactions

sentences.text: Key developments in wearable sensors, wireless networks, and distributed computing will largely enable Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) as a powerful, natural and intuitive mainstream human-computer interaction in real-world activities.
BCI systems annotate the sensed signals in order to classify the analysis of brain states and dynamics in diverse daily-life circumstances.
There is no complete and standardized formal semantic structure to model the BCI metadata annotations, which are essential to capture the descriptive and predictive features of the brain signals.

We present the BCI Ontology (BCI-O): the first OWL 2 ontology that formalizes relevant metadata for BCI data capture activities by integrating BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model for describing any kind of real or virtual environments.
At its core, BCI-O defines a human-environment interaction model for any BCI, based on design patterns and primarily aligned to the SOSA/SSN, SAN-IoT-O, and DUL ontologies.

Its axiomatizations aid BCI systems to implement an ontological overlay upon vast data recording collections to support semantic query constructions to perform Adaptive BCI and reasoning for situation-specific data analytics to apply inference rules for Transfer Learning in multimodal classification.

Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) are electronic systems that are used to determine a user’s brain states by collecting and analyzing her neuro-physiological signals including electroencephalogram (EEG), electrocardiogram (ECG), electrooculogram (EOG) and then actuating specific responses, for example to drive her wheelchair or fight against her drowsiness.

Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) techniques are commonly used to analyze those biological signals, which are highly situation and individual dependent, and non-stationary in characteristics, in order to classify her brain states.
Lack of training data from individual users and comparable features among different users often hamper the accuracy and usefulness of BCI systems in real-world applications.

In a project in the research area of Advanced Computational Approaches under the Cognition and Neuroergonomics Collaborative Technology Alliance (CaN-CTA) program sponsored by the U.S. Army Research Laboratory (ARL), the Pervasive Embedding Technologies (PET) Lab in the National Chiao-Tung University (NCTU) in Taiwan has the chance to work with the Swartz Center for Computational Neuroscience (SCCN) in the University of California in San Diego (UCSD) to develop a semantic model that can aid the search for correlated neuro-physiological features for characterizing an individual’s cognitive states including fatigue, vigilance and enlightenment and the gathering of useful data sets for conducting interpersonal Transfer Learning.
This BCI Ontology was a product of that research project.

The project took a bottom-up approach; the SCCN team developed two sets of metadata vocabulary: the EEG Study Schema (ESS) and the Hierarchical Event Descriptor (HED) to describe the settings of the neuro-physiological recording and the specification of the neuro-physiological events respectively.
Collectively, they were referred to as the BCI metadata.

As the teams began to expand these metadata to cover more BCI experiments, the need to develop an ontological structure became obvious not only to accommodate future expansion of the vocabulary but also to specify the semantic relations among these concepts.
Most notably, the syntax of HED 2 started to resemble the RDF format.
Subsequent development of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), the semantic data repository and the federated SPARQL search all took place in NCTU with the results fed back to UCSD and ARL.

In order to employ BCI-O to accomplish the two goals mentioned above, the neuro-physiological signals/data sets collected from the experiments need to be processed for feature extraction and preliminary classification using existing ML algorithms.
In the task of gathering data sets for Transfer Learning, inference rules shall be in place to specify the criteria of selecting data sets classified by existing algorithms for the learning process.
In the task of deducing the correlated interpersonal features, the relations among the extracted features from different individuals shall be discovered through semantic search.
Since BCI is a type of sensor-actuator system, it is only proper to align BCI-O with the W3C Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) and Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) frameworks.
Because many BCI devices are connected to the Internet, BCI-O should also be aligned with the ontology for the Internet-of-Things (IoT-O).
An important contribution we made was the introduction of the concepts of context and contextual relations into BCI-O.
The characteristics of biological and neurophysiological signals are known to be highly situation or context dependent.
User’s physical conditions, time of day, environmental conditions can also affect the signals.

In order to include these factors in the search for the correlated interpersonal features and the relevant data sets for Transfer Learning, we incorporated the core concepts of the UNITY world model for game development into BCI-O.
We followed the human-environment interaction model in Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) to integrate the concepts of context with those of sense and actuation.
In the rest of this paper, the BCI metadata for context, multi-modal data, and event annotations were first depicted.
The structure, design principle, engineering and applications were then explained in subsequent sections.
Lastly, the main contribution and future work were summarized in the conclusion.

Real-world multimodal BCI may be decomposed into the following modeling artifacts: wearing a set of sensors and/or through actuators, human beings interact with an environment while performing real-world activities, where stimuli triggered by contextual events are observed, recorded, and marked in the sensed multimodal BCI data.

At its core, BCI-O defines the conceptual components in any BCI through a bidirectional subject-context interaction model: a Sense Model (context to subject) and an Actuation Model (subject to context), as depicted in the relevant figure.
The design principle underlying this interaction model is described in section 4.

However, its structure can be summarized in the following way: the Sense Model is based on the Stimulus-Sensor-Observation Ontology Design Pattern and aligned to the SOSA/SSN upper ontologies, whilst the Actuation Model is based on the Actuation-Actuator-Effect ODP and aligned to both SOSA and SAN upper ontologies.
Two distinct conceptual domains are found in this model: the BCI domain (observations, actuation, and interactions) and the context domain (surroundings).
The context domain concepts are based on the gaming architectural modeling of the Unity framework.
The BCI domain concepts were taken from the following semi-structured standard vocabularies and formats.
Extensible Data Format (XDF) is a general-purpose container format for multi-channel time series data with extensive associated meta-information stored as XML, called 'XDF Metadata Schemes'.
XDF is tailored towards bio-signal data but can easily hold data with high sampling rates or high numbers of channels.
EEG Study Schema (ESS) is an XML-based specification that holds a metadata hierarchy for describing and documenting electrophysiological studies and their raw recorded data.

Hierarchical Event Descriptor Tags for Analysis of Event-Related EEG Studies defines a hierarchy of standard and extended descriptors for EEG experimental events that provides a uniform human- and machine-readable interface.
In the BCI domain, after collecting multimodal data from a subject, systems proceed to annotate the data with descriptive and predictive parameters.
The descriptive features explain the interaction model settings of the data, whereas the predictive features provide important input to classification models for adaptive BCI.
In the BCI domain, context corresponds to the same concept as in HCI literature.

Due to its orientation on real-world BCI, the ontology's main design objectives are: defining core, generic, and relevant consensual concepts about BCI data capture activities, developing a machine-readable BCI semantic model for software agents' interoperability, and ensuring simplicity, extensibility, and reusability.
BCI-O structure depicts a conceptual framework that BCI systems can extend and use in their implementations.
The BCI-O namespace is https://w3id.org/BCI-ontology#.
BCI-O concepts are grouped into several modules.
Each module represents a key topic that gives a consistent explanation of its correspondent functional aspect in the mentioned BCI interaction model.
Following are presented a brief description of the modules and their core concepts.
Subject defines a human being engaging in an activity and its associated state.
The subject defines a person with certain attributes, equivalent to Patient in the HL7 standard.
Context captures the architectural description of a physical or virtual environment.
Its modeling is based on a sequence of scenes, each one depicting a collection of spatially located entities interacting with one another in a specific way.
These conceptual components enable the structural, functional, and temporal complexity definitions of any environment.

Under the event classification, BCI-O defines three key concepts that bind the contextual integration with its Sense and Actuation Models: a stimulus to the subject, an action issued by a subject while performing an activity, and an effect in the context as the result of an actuation.
Session represents the interaction between a subject and a context while performing a single activity under specific settings and conditions.
A session groups both observations and actuations.
Sense Model describes the contextual input data and events to the subject.
Observations are specific concepts aligned to the axioms for modeling observations.
These are related to a single observation, modality types, interpretation aspects, channeling schema information, recorded data as sensor output streams, and stimulus events.
Sensors are specific concepts aligned to the axioms for modeling sensors under observations.
These are related to devices, their channeling schema, and their specifications.
System Capabilities are specific concepts aligned to the horizontal segmentation module for system capabilities.
They are about logical components of a channeling schema's data structure model and other measurement properties.
Results are specific concepts aligned to the axioms for modeling results.
They include data blocks and recorded data, with actuation results also included in this module.
Actuation Model depicts how the subject can interact with the context.
Its main concepts are actuation and actuator.
Annotation Tag includes event markers based on context stimuli and response markers based on machine learning models for annotations on specific data segments.
These define the predictive data features, while the previously mentioned modules explain the descriptive data features.
Descriptor defines an external resource set that extends and/or complements the description associated with relevant entities defined in BCI-O.
EEG concepts for EEG applications represent EEG subtypes for channel, device, modality, and record.
The instant and interval concepts were borrowed from the W3C OWL-Time ontology.
URI locators to external resources and raw data can be used for accessing and indexing purposes.
BCI systems can express interoperable models extending BCI-O, which is useful in machine-to-machine environments.
The specification leaves open the way in which applications handle the semantic expressiveness level for measurement units and the procedure concept extension.

The Semantic Sensor Network (SSN), along with its self-contained core ontology SOSA (Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator), is a standard framework ontology that BCI-O further extends for the BCI domain.
SOSA/SSN gives BCI-O the conceptual template and structure for both its Sense and Actuation Models, describing functional aspects of any BCI data capture activity.
4.1 Sense Model: SOSA/SSN Ontologies & SSO Design Pattern
Besides the general benefits of SSN, BCI-O's Sense Model leverages it in the following ways:
BCI systems can be considered as specialized sensor networks; SOSA/SSN helps to improve their semantic interoperability and integration.
As a Linked Sensor Data standard, SSN helps to connect the IoT and the Internet of Services layers, which is of special interest to BCI in M2M environments.

SOSA/SSN supports different views related to BCI systems architecture, which can be centered around sensors (capabilities), observations (what was observed and how), and features and properties (how to observe them).
SSN provides a foundation for describing sensor networks as Web applications: real-time data processing from Web-of-Things sensors, which is a characteristic of BCI systems.
The SSN Skeleton module describes the Stimulus-Sensor-Observation (SSO) ontology design pattern, which forms the top-level of SSN.
BCI-O's Sense Model key concepts were first built aligned to SSO and later remapped to other frameworks.

Not only is SSO suitable for event/situation based data logging, but due to its generic and reusable structure, this pattern is intended for observation-related ontologies and for observation-based data on the Semantic Web.
Thus, it conforms a natural design structure for the BCI-O's Sense Model.
4.2 Actuation Model: SOSA + SAN Ontologies & AAE Design Pattern (IoT-O)
BCI-O's Actuation Model is based on the bci:Actuation and bci:Actuator abstractions.
In the IoT community, the Semantic Actuator Network (SAN) has been proposed as an upper ontology for IoT-O.
SAN is built around the Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) ontology design pattern.
BCI-O's Actuation Model integrates carefully both standard axiomatization models for actuations, developed by W3C/OGC and IoT communities.
Thus, its structure follows closely the AAE ODP while aligning to SOSA/SSN and SAN.

As part of the BCI-O's Actuation Model development, we raised the issue to the W3C Spatial Data on the Web Working Group regarding the mapping of SOSA/SSN to AAE ODP, due to their structural resemblance.
Figures show BCI-O's Actuation Model alignment perspective to SOSA/SSN and its alignment perspective to SAN (IoT-O) following the AAE ODP.
4.3 Design Approach: Ontology Alignments

BCI-O's basic design principle can be depicted as a three-layered architecture of an ontology library, with the following structure: the foundational layer (DUL), the core layer (SOSA/SSN + SAN), and the domain layer (BCI-O).
Thus, as an example, the participation foundational design pattern fits in the following way: objects dul:Object leads to sosa:Sensor leads to bci:Device.
For objects, dbp:Person or dul:NaturalPerson leads to bci:Subject.
For events, dul:Event leads to ssn:Stimulus leads to bci:StimulusEvent.
For events, dul:Event leads to sosa:Observation leads to bci:Record.
For spatial-temporal location, dul:Situation leads to either bci:Session, bci:Context, or bci:Context.Scene.
Based on the SSO ODP, the domain level concepts of the Sense Model were specialized initially from the SSN Skeleton module, following a similar alignment scheme that this one had with DUL.
Due to its alignment with the initial SSN version, BCI-O was documented as part of the analysis on the usage of SSN, as one of the ontologies that reuse SSN.
Subsequently, BCI-O's Sense Model was re-aligned to the Dolce-Ultralite (DUL) Alignment Module of the SOSA/SSN Vertical Segmentation.

SSO-based core alignments include: Stimulus, which is a detectable change in the environment that triggers the sensors to perform observations; Sensor, which is an object that performs observations to measure certain observable properties; and Observation, which is a multi-dimensional event that captures information about the stimulus, sensor, its output, and the spatial-temporal specification of the sensing activity.
Based on the AAE ODP, the domain level concepts of the Actuation Model were aligned initially to SOSA/SSN.
Afterwards, they were integrated with proper alignments to SAN (IoT-O), following closely their axiomatization satisfiability.

BCI-O's AAE-based core alignments include: Actuation, which carries out a procedure to change the state of the context using an actuator; Actuator, which is a device that is used by, or implements, an actuation that changes the state of the context; and Effect, which is any kind of physical modification induced by an actuator.
4.4 Context Model: Unity's Gaming High-Level Modeling Architecture
BCI-O's Context Model was built based on relevant abstractions curated from the gaming architectural modeling of the Unity framework.

Unity models the architectural description of any kind of environment based on the organization of its entities and their relationships from three complementary perspectives: structural, behavioral, and temporal.
These conceptual components enable the structural, functional, and temporal complexity definitions of any environment with a certain level of abstraction relevant to its purpose.
This is the main reason why Unity's core concepts were chosen as the basis for the Context Model.
Besides being one of the most popular game engines worldwide, its modeling artifacts are easy to understand and use.
In order to be consistent in the BCI-O's overall structure and intention, the Context Model core concepts were properly aligned to DUL.

As part of a pervasive online BCI system developed under the CaN-CTA Program of the U.S. ARL, a proto-ontology was initially designed based on the project specifications and incremental software engineering tasks.
Later, it was generalized and expanded through a modeling process described below.
Two fundamental and general representational aspects were considered for the domain modeling: BCI and physical/virtual environments (contexts).
The contextual aspect was focused on explaining the relevant component architecture of any environment for BCI, by abstracting the high-level concepts and relations found in the literature.
The BCI aspect focused on categorizing the entities in any interaction through structured metadata.

BCI interaction model complexity was addressed as follows: major players and flows were clearly identified based on HCI notions; their characterizations were formalized following open BCI vocabularies; and additional complementary design considerations were incorporated in a top-down approach to model the Annotation Tag module and related concepts.
Common concepts, such as time intervals, were defined as datatype properties to ease the modeling to BCI systems.
However, if required, BCI-O applications could add more semantic expressiveness for the representation of timestamps and intervals, using directly W3C OWL-Time ontology.
The modeling and its specifications were assessed several times until they reached a stable status.

Below are presented important aspects of the followed construction process: proto-ontology's project specification (requirements), conceptualization and formalization (analysis and design), and implementation (development and deployment).
A hybrid modeling style was used: verbal/semi-structured (BCI vocabularies), logic-based (upper ontologies), and structural-object (Unity framework).
The level of detail for BCI-O included conceptual and logical models.
A pattern-based architecture was used for the Sense and Actuation Models: SSO and AAE.
Non-ontological resource applications included context domain (Unity dictionary), video coding domain (MPEG-7 MDS glossary), and time domain (OWL-Time glossary).
Ontology design pattern reuse and alignment were applied to the Sense and Actuation Models.
Ontological resource reuse included SOSA/SSN, SAN (IoT-O), DUL, and dbpedia.
Ontology restructuring had a special focus on pruning and modularization.
Ontology authoring and quality were carefully considered during the overall process of building the BCI-O specifications.
Many best practices found in the SSN and IoT-O specifications were taken as proper guidelines for its structure and documentation.

The construction rules applied in the BCI-O development were: identify relevant BCI metadata terms to be included, which should have major impact on BCI activity/data annotation and machine-launched semantic search; determine the domain and scope of concepts, keeping the model simple and stable; define class hierarchies and design rules, following closely BCI vocabularies; find prominent ontologies from which we could apply ontology design patterns to directly align the term definitions: SOSA/SSN and SAN (IoT-O); and if necessary, establish equivalence relations with other related terms of interest.

During the ontology development, some terms from popular vocabularies were included to enrich the BCI-O concepts metadata as annotation properties, such as Dublin Core Metadata Terms (DC and DCMIType), SKOS (Simple Knowledge Organization System), VANN (a vocabulary for annotating vocabulary descriptions), and Open.vocab.org.
Besides their minimal semantic commitment, these annotations are well-known web-oriented representations that aim to reuse and share ontological concepts and their descriptions.
Guidelines were carefully followed while incorporating the annotations into the BCI-O specifications.

SKOS lexical labels (prefLabel) and notes documentation properties (such as definition, scope note, editorial note, and change note) were included into the specifications to distinguish and structure properly the different content nature for each BCI-O concept.
BCI-O's satisfiability was checked at different validation points immediately after including and modifying various axioms, such as disjoint concepts and DUL/SAN alignments.
The reasoner HermiT v1.3.8 was used.
As part of the ontology engineering process, a detailed log was kept with all the results and durations of each satisfiability checkpoint.
The specifications were developed in three versions, each with related XML documents.
First, the Base Version, an OWL 2 RDF/XML document with the complete modeling structure and content, plus embedded HTML formatting and text-handling rules.
Second, the HTML Version, a set of XSL 3 documents with XPath 3 functions and a companion XML configuration document to handle the base-to-HTML transformation.
And third, the OWL 2 RDF/XML Version, an XSL 3 document that strips off from the base version the HTML formatting to generate a clean and proper machine-readable document.

A simple linked data engine was developed to handle some specialized linked data services for the specifications, including serving the proper HTML and RDF/XML versions and URI entry points to different user agents.
A w3id.org identifier was registered as its namespace URI definition.
A basic content negotiation server-side script was developed to serve properly the different versions of the specifications.
The BCI-O specifications were published in the LOV registry on November 8, 2016.
The modeling and ontology tools used were: Astah Community Modeling Tool, IHMC CmapTools, and Protégé v5.2.0.
The BCI-O proto-ontology was developed in a joint project between NCTU (PET Lab) and UCSD (SCCN), with the U.S. ARL Translational Neuroscience Branch (CaN-CTA Program).
As an application for a proof of concept system, the proto-ontology was used to ensure that big data sets were semantically searchable for high-level processing via BCI metadata definitions.

The proto-ontology was successfully used further in heterogeneous BCI datasets coming from different applications, such as stress and fatigue neuroimaging, car driving tests, and multi-modal mobile brain imaging.
Another application is described in the paper on the Neuromonitoring VR/AR Goggle.

The BCI-O spec's HTML version presents two early applications, including their correspondent RDF graph model: the CerebraTek vPod Ontology, applied to glaucoma diagnostics using mfSSVEP, and the ESS+HED Standards Ontology for BCI-O, as an ontological overlay for the ESS v2.0 and HED v2.0 EEG data sharing tools.
These tools have been built as a multi-iterative process infrastructure with many layers to train and personalize machine learning models using semi-structured and non-interoperable metadata formats.
BCI-O's axiomatizations of relevant BCI metadata can greatly enhance these software pipelines.
Following, we describe a use case where BCI-O aids applications in transfer learning operations.
A semantic query is used for a transfer learning operation of data sets and segments between two machine learning models, based on categorized observations.

An application for Early Glaucoma Detection that uses the vPod Ontology aims to select data sets and segments that have been previously classified via a simple Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) as the input to a more sophisticated CNN model.
The glaucoma patients' datasets consist of EEG recordings collected from 100 subjects as part of an experiment performed by a UCSD research team.
Each subject has one session with two EEG records, one for each eye.
An EEG recording is classified as either Normal, G. Early, or G. Late, which are categories of glaucoma detection stages.
These annotations define the categorization of the observations.
Each recorded data that has been analyzed has a sequence of data segments with related attributes that define a probability and a correlation.
High-correlated segments signify relevant epochs to the source model that classify the eye's vision.
Only high-correlated segments are relevant to the target model.
The application only annotates both the probability and correlation for high-correlated segments of the source model.
The analyzed EEG recordings have a related EEGNet model, which is used as a high-level selector and as the transfer learning source model.
EEGNet is a simple 4-layer CNN model for glaucoma classification.
RevNet+I is a complex 24-layer CNN model, used as a more sophisticated tool to analyze features of the collected EEG signals, serving as the transfer learning target model.
The purpose of the semantic query is to select the analyzed raw data and data segments that have been annotated with high-correlation of their segments' probabilities as the input to RevNet+I.
For this use case, the semantic query has four important sections.
First, the Semantic Matching defines the relationship between the relevant metadata concepts for the BCI application based on the vPod Ontology and its alignment to BCI-O.
Second, the Query Restriction involves attribute-based restrictions of the categories on sessions, subjects, and records, which categorize the observations.
Third, the Model Selector for the Data is comprised of the annotated data segments with probabilities and correlations and classified recordings with the transfer learning source model.
Fourth, the Query Projection includes the raw data sets and their data segments for the transfer learning target model.

In general, BCI-O offers two main applications to BCI systems: the modeling of subject-independent features, which provides orthogonal conceptual dimensionality for subjects, and relevant data sets for personalized calibration of models with some level of confidence.
BCI-O models subject-context interactions while focusing on monitoring the brain dynamics.

In the long term, we would like to take BCI-O as the basis towards generalizing a semantic model to describe how any human body bio-signal, not only from the brain, can be monitored and made to interact with computing interfaces.
Initially, this work would lead to BCI-O's generalization towards a Bio-signal Computer-Interaction Ontology.

This modeling task is planned to be one of the main development drivers in the future for a set of ontological frameworks to capture the different bio-signal markers and technological interfaces for the entire human body: organs such as the brain, heart, liver, and systems including nervous, integumentary, and endocrine.
Additionally, there is an ongoing effort on proposing some extensions to the SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation.

We are following closely the new proposed concepts and relationships and providing our feedback from the BCI-O perspective in their ongoing discussions, with special interest for issue #1028 regarding the Homogeneity of an Observation Collection.
BCI-O will be updated accordingly following the structure and alignments of these extensions after the proposal becomes stable.
Lastly, some BCI applications keep part of their metadata stored in standard relational database systems.
As an aside project, we are planning to work on an OWL 2 QL profile version of BCI-O, so that those relevant metadata sets can be queried through a restrictive version of BCI-O.
As a foundational model for real-world BCI, BCI-O will become an important tool to aid large-scale BCI data analytics models and processes, due primarily to its OWL 2 formal structure.

Semantic reasoning based tasks of BCI-O's axiomatizations enable BCI systems to carry out two major jobs: first, to apply inference rules to aid machine learning techniques, such as feature-based transfer learning in online multimodal EEG classification, and second, to perform Adaptive BCI, which involves training and refining brain state prediction and classification models based on relevant data sets constructed through semantic data queries.
Another key contribution of BCI-O is its novel Context Model.
This model associates the context architectonic definition with the data recordings, making BCI systems semantically context-aware for real and virtual-world situations.
Thus, it provides a semantic foundation for augmented BCI, assisting ambient intelligence settings in sensor systems for any kind of BCI.

As a domain ontology for BCI sensors and actuators, BCI-O allows for semantically informed BCI analytics of sensor and actuator data patterns, including unambiguous searchability, similarities, simulations, and predictions, as well as semantic interoperability based on its alignments.
This enables easy integration, reusability, and extensibility into the Linked Data world for all kinds of BCI.
In general, its axiomatizations enable BCI systems to apply Semantic Web technologies for data analysis, serving as a form of semantic middleware for BCI sensor and actuator networks.

Entity-bci-o.label: BCI-O
Entity-bci-o.description: BCI-O is the first OWL 2 ontology designed to formalize relevant metadata for Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) data capture, integrating domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models with a Context Model to describe real or virtual environments.

Entity-bci_ontology.label: BCI Ontology
Entity-bci_ontology.description: The BCI Ontology (BCI-O) is the first OWL 2 ontology designed to formalize metadata for Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) data capture, integrating domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models with a Context Model to describe real or virtual environments.

Entity-bci-o_model.label: BCI-O models
Entity-bci-o_model.description: BCI-O models are frameworks within the BCI Ontology that describe the interactions between subjects and their contexts, specifically aimed at monitoring brain dynamics and facilitating the integration of bio-signal data with computing interfaces.

Entity-domain_ontology_for_bci_sensor_an.label: domain ontology for BCI sensors and actuators
aliases: domain ontology for BCI sensors and actuators
Entity-domain_ontology_for_bci_sensor_an.description: The 'domain ontology for BCI sensors and actuators' refers to the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which is an OWL 2 formal structure designed to provide a semantic framework for analyzing and integrating data from brain-computer interaction (BCI) systems, specifically focusing on the metadata associated with BCI sensors and actuators to enhance data analytics, interoperability, and context-awareness.

mentions.local_name: domain ontology for BCI sensors and actuators

Entity-bci-o_development.label: BCI-O development
Entity-bci-o_development.description: BCI-O development refers to the process of constructing the BCI Ontology, which formalizes metadata for Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems by integrating sense and actuation models with a context model to enhance data annotation and semantic search capabilities.

Entity-bci-o_s_sense_model.label: BCI-O's Sense Model
Entity-bci-o_s_sense_model.description: BCI-O's Sense Model is a specialized framework within the BCI Ontology that utilizes the Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) and its design patterns to enhance the semantic interoperability and integration of brain-computer interaction systems by describing the functional aspects of data capture activities.

Entity-the_bci_application.label: the BCI application
Entity-the_bci_application.description: The BCI application refers to the implementation of Brain-Computer Interaction systems that utilize the BCI Ontology to enhance the semantic searchability and processing of brain signal data across various contexts and use cases.

Entity-bci_interaction_model.label: BCI interaction model
Entity-bci_interaction_model.description: The BCI interaction model refers to a structured framework within the BCI Ontology that defines how human subjects interact with their physical or virtual environments during brain-computer interaction activities, encompassing various modules that describe sensory input, contextual factors, and actuation processes.

Entity-bci-o_concept.label: BCI-O concepts
Entity-bci-o_concept.description: BCI-O concepts refer to the structured modules within the BCI Ontology that define key topics and functional aspects of the brain-computer interaction model, facilitating the organization and understanding of various components related to human-environment interactions in BCI systems.

Entity-the_bci-o_perspective.label: the BCI-O perspective
Entity-the_bci-o_perspective.description: The BCI-O perspective refers to the viewpoint or approach derived from the BCI Ontology, which focuses on the integration and application of context-aware models for Brain-Computer Interaction, particularly in the context of providing feedback and insights on proposed concepts and relationships in ongoing discussions related to BCI metadata and its implications.

Entity-semantically_informed_bci_analyti.label: semantically informed BCI analytics
Entity-semantically_informed_bci_analyti.description: Semantically informed BCI analytics refers to the analytical processes enabled by the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that utilize semantic reasoning to enhance the understanding and interpretation of sensor and actuator data patterns in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-application.label: applications
Entity-application.description: In this paper, 'applications' refers to the practical implementations and use cases of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) in enhancing Brain-Computer Interaction systems through structured metadata and context-aware models.

Entity-bci-o_concept_metadata.label: BCI-O concepts metadata
Entity-bci-o_concept_metadata.description: BCI-O concepts metadata refers to the structured annotations and terms derived from established vocabularies that enhance the BCI Ontology by providing semantic context and definitions for brain-computer interaction data, facilitating improved data annotation and semantic search.

Entity-semantic_middleware_for_bci_senso.label: semantic middleware for BCI sensor and actuator networks
aliases: semantic middleware for BCI sensor and actuator networks
Entity-semantic_middleware_for_bci_senso.description: The 'semantic middleware for BCI sensor and actuator networks' refers to the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which provides a formal semantic structure that facilitates the integration, analysis, and interoperability of data from brain-computer interaction systems involving sensors and actuators.

mentions.local_name: semantic middleware for BCI sensor and actuator networks

Entity-bio-signal_computer-interaction_o.label: Bio-signal Computer-Interaction Ontology
Entity-bio-signal_computer-interaction_o.description: The Bio-signal Computer-Interaction Ontology is a proposed extension of the BCI Ontology that aims to create a comprehensive semantic framework for monitoring and interacting with various human body bio-signals through computing interfaces.

Entity-bci-o_structure.label: BCI-O structure
Entity-bci-o_structure.description: The BCI-O structure refers to a conceptual framework within the BCI Ontology that enables Brain-Computer Interaction systems to extend and implement a standardized model for capturing and interpreting BCI data in various contexts.

Entity-bci-o_application.label: BCI-O applications
Entity-bci-o_application.description: BCI-O applications refer to software applications that utilize the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) to enhance the semantic representation and processing of brain-computer interaction data, particularly in relation to timestamps and intervals.

Entity-bci-o_specification.label: BCI-O specifications
Entity-bci-o_specification.description: The BCI-O specifications refer to the detailed guidelines and structured documentation developed for the BCI Ontology, which formalizes metadata for Brain-Computer Interaction systems, ensuring quality and adherence to best practices in ontology authoring.

Entity-bci-o_namespace.label: BCI-O namespace
Entity-bci-o_namespace.description: The BCI-O namespace is a URI that serves as the identifier for the BCI Ontology, which formalizes metadata for Brain-Computer Interaction data capture activities.

Entity-novel_context_model.label: novel Context Model
Entity-novel_context_model.description: The novel Context Model is a component of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that enhances Brain-Computer Interaction systems by providing a semantic framework for associating context with data recordings, enabling BCI systems to be context-aware in both real and virtual environments.

Entity-semantic_foundation_for_augmented.label: semantic foundation for augmented BCI
Entity-semantic_foundation_for_augmented.description: The 'semantic foundation for augmented BCI' refers to the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which provides a structured framework for integrating context-aware data analytics in brain-computer interaction systems, enhancing their ability to operate in ambient intelligence environments.

Entity-human-environment_interaction_mod.label: human-environment interaction model
Entity-human-environment_interaction_mod.description: The human-environment interaction model is a theoretical framework defined within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that integrates design patterns and aligns with established ontologies to facilitate the interaction between brain-computer interfaces and various real or virtual environments.

Entity-real-world_multimodal_bci.label: Real-world multimodal BCI
Entity-real-world_multimodal_bci.description: Real-world multimodal BCI refers to a system that integrates various sensors and actuators to facilitate human interaction with environments during real-world activities, capturing and annotating brain signal data influenced by contextual stimuli.

Entity-bci-o_s_axiomatizations.label: BCI-O's axiomatizations
Entity-bci-o_s_axiomatizations.description: BCI-O's axiomatizations refer to the formalized rules and structures within the BCI Ontology that define and organize relevant metadata for Brain-Computer Interaction, enabling enhanced semantic processing and interoperability of BCI data across various applications.

Entity-bci_analytics.label: BCI analytics
Entity-bci_analytics.description: BCI analytics refers to the process of semantically informed analysis of sensor and actuator data patterns in Brain-Computer Interaction systems, enabling enhanced searchability, similarity detection, simulations, predictions, and interoperability through the use of a domain ontology.

Entity-bci_metadata_annotation.label: BCI metadata annotations
Entity-bci_metadata_annotation.description: BCI metadata annotations refer to the structured information that describes and predicts features of brain signals in Brain-Computer Interaction systems, which currently lack a standardized formal semantic framework.

Entity-bci_system.label: BCI systems
Entity-bci_system.description: BCI systems are technological frameworks that facilitate direct communication between the brain and external devices by interpreting neural signals.

Entity-bci-o_s_axiomatizations_of_releva.label: BCI-O's axiomatizations of relevant BCI metadata
aliases: BCI-O's axiomatizations of relevant BCI metadata
Entity-bci-o_s_axiomatizations_of_releva.description: BCI-O's axiomatizations of relevant BCI metadata refer to the formalized definitions and structures within the BCI Ontology that enhance the semantic searchability and processing of brain-computer interaction data, facilitating improved data analytics and machine learning applications.

mentions.local_name: BCI-O's axiomatizations of relevant BCI metadata

Entity-brain-computer_interaction__bci_.label: Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI)
Entity-brain-computer_interaction__bci_.description: Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) refers to the technology and methodologies that facilitate direct communication between the human brain and external devices, enabling intuitive and natural interactions in various real-world activities through the analysis and interpretation of brain signals.

Entity-bci-domain-specific_sense_and_act.label: BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models
Entity-bci-domain-specific_sense_and_act.description: BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models refer to specialized frameworks within the Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) domain that facilitate the interpretation and response to brain signals by integrating contextual information to enhance human-environment interactions.

Entity-bci.label: BCI
Entity-bci.description: BCI refers to brain-computer interfaces, which are systems that facilitate direct communication between the brain and external devices, enabling control and interaction through neural signals.

Entity-bci-o_s_overall_structure_and_int.label: BCI-O's overall structure and intention
Entity-bci-o_s_overall_structure_and_int.description: BCI-O's overall structure and intention refers to the comprehensive design and purpose of the BCI Ontology, which integrates various models for sense and actuation within brain-computer interaction systems, ensuring consistency and alignment with foundational ontological frameworks.

Entity-the_structure.label: The structure
Entity-the_structure.description: The structure refers to the ontological framework and organization of metadata within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that facilitates the integration and semantic representation of brain-computer interaction data, including context, sense, and actuation models.

Entity-this_work.label: this work
Entity-this_work.description: This work refers to the initial efforts aimed at generalizing the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) towards a broader Bio-signal Computer-Interaction Ontology, which will encompass various human body bio-signals and their interactions with computing interfaces.

Entity-sense_and_actuation_model.label: Sense and Actuation Models
Entity-sense_and_actuation_model.description: Sense and Actuation Models refer to a structured framework within the BCI Ontology that integrates domain-specific models to facilitate the interaction between brain-computer interfaces and their physical or virtual environments.

Entity-any_kind_of_bci.label: any kind of BCI
Entity-any_kind_of_bci.description: The term 'any kind of BCI' refers to various types of Brain-Computer Interaction systems that utilize semantic models and technologies to enhance data analytics and contextual awareness in both real and virtual environments.

Entity-bci__context.label: bci:Context
Entity-bci__context.description: bci:Context refers to a conceptual entity within the BCI Ontology that represents the spatial-temporal context in which brain-computer interaction activities occur, facilitating the understanding of how various environmental factors influence BCI data capture and processing.

Entity-sensed_multimodal_bci_data.label: sensed multimodal BCI data
Entity-sensed_multimodal_bci_data.description: Sensed multimodal BCI data refers to the collection of brain-computer interaction data that is captured through various sensors and actuators, which records and annotates stimuli triggered by contextual events during real-world activities.

Entity-the_semantic_data_repository.label: the semantic data repository
Entity-the_semantic_data_repository.description: The semantic data repository refers to the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which serves as a structured framework for organizing and managing metadata related to brain-computer interaction data, facilitating semantic queries and data analytics.

Entity-bci_metadata_for_context.label: BCI metadata for context
Entity-bci_metadata_for_context.description: BCI metadata for context refers to the structured vocabulary and annotations developed to describe the contextual factors influencing brain-computer interaction data, facilitating the classification and analysis of neuro-physiological signals in various environments.

Entity-the_bci_aspect.label: The BCI aspect
Entity-the_bci_aspect.description: The BCI aspect refers to the component of the BCI Ontology that is dedicated to categorizing entities involved in brain-computer interactions using structured metadata.

Entity-sense_and_actuation.label: sense and actuation
Entity-sense_and_actuation.description: The term 'sense and actuation' refers to the integrated concepts within the BCI Ontology that describe how brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) perceive neuro-physiological signals from users and respond with specific actions, thereby facilitating human-environment interactions in various contexts.

Entity-bci_activitydata_annotation.label: BCI activity/data annotation
Entity-bci_activitydata_annotation.description: BCI activity/data annotation refers to the process of identifying and categorizing relevant metadata terms related to Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) to enhance the semantic understanding and analysis of brain signal data within the context of BCI systems.

Entity-the_main_contribution.label: the main contribution
Entity-the_main_contribution.description: The main contribution refers to the introduction of context and contextual relations into the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), enhancing its ability to account for the situational dependencies of biological and neurophysiological signals in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-the_bci_domain.label: the BCI domain
Entity-the_bci_domain.description: The BCI domain refers to the specialized field of Brain-Computer Interaction, which encompasses the development and application of systems that facilitate direct communication between the human brain and external devices, often utilizing ontologies and models to enhance the semantic understanding and interoperability of BCI data capture activities.

Entity-multimodal_bci.label: multimodal BCI
Entity-multimodal_bci.description: A multimodal BCI (brain-computer interface) is a technology that enables direct communication between the brain and external devices by integrating and processing data from multiple sensory modalities to facilitate interaction with the environment.

Entity-owl_2_formal_structure.label: OWL 2 formal structure
Entity-owl_2_formal_structure.description: The OWL 2 formal structure refers to the standardized semantic framework utilized in the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) to model and formalize metadata for brain-computer interaction data, enabling semantic reasoning and adaptive analytics in BCI systems.

Entity-bci_metadata.label: BCI metadata
Entity-bci_metadata.description: BCI metadata refers to the sets of vocabulary developed to describe the settings of neuro-physiological recordings and the specifications of neuro-physiological events in Brain-Computer Interaction research.

Entity-sense.label: sense
Entity-sense.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'sense' refers to the concept of perceiving or interpreting neuro-physiological signals and environmental factors that influence brain-computer interactions, which are essential for understanding user states and facilitating appropriate responses in BCI systems.

Entity-bidirectional_subject-context_int.label: bidirectional subject-context interaction model
Entity-bidirectional_subject-context_int.description: The bidirectional subject-context interaction model is a conceptual framework within the BCI Ontology that integrates a Sense Model, which captures interactions from context to subject, and an Actuation Model, which facilitates interactions from subject to context, thereby enabling effective brain-computer interactions in real-world environments.

Entity-bci-o_s_actuation_model.label: BCI-O's Actuation Model
Entity-bci-o_s_actuation_model.description: BCI-O's Actuation Model is a theoretical framework that integrates the bci:Actuation and bci:Actuator abstractions to facilitate the actuation processes in Brain-Computer Interaction systems, aligning with established ontologies like SOSA/SSN and SAN.

Entity-stimulus-sensor-observation_ontol.label: Stimulus-Sensor-Observation Ontology Design Pattern
Entity-stimulus-sensor-observation_ontol.description: The Stimulus-Sensor-Observation Ontology Design Pattern is a conceptual framework used in the BCI Ontology to model the interaction between stimuli, sensors, and observations in brain-computer interaction systems.

Entity-sensed_signal.label: sensed signals
Entity-sensed_signal.description: Sensed signals refer to the brain signals captured by Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems, which are analyzed to classify brain states and dynamics in various real-life situations.

Entity-system.label: systems
Entity-system.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), 'systems' refers to the computational frameworks or software applications that process and annotate multimodal data collected from subjects, utilizing descriptive and predictive parameters for adaptive BCI functionalities.

Entity-semantic_reasoning_based_task.label: Semantic reasoning based tasks
Entity-semantic_reasoning_based_task.description: Semantic reasoning based tasks refer to the operations enabled by the axiomatizations of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that allow Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems to apply inference rules for machine learning and perform Adaptive BCI by refining brain state prediction models through semantic data queries.

Entity-it_alignment_to_bci-o.label: its alignment to BCI-O
Entity-it_alignment_to_bci-o.description: The term 'its alignment to BCI-O' refers to the relationship and integration of the vPod Ontology with the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) in defining relevant metadata concepts for Brain-Computer Interaction applications.

Entity-real-world_bci.label: real-world BCI
Entity-real-world_bci.description: Real-world BCI refers to brain-computer interfaces that are designed and implemented for practical applications in everyday environments, focusing on the effective capture and interpretation of brain activity data.

Entity-simulation.label: simulations
Entity-simulation.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'simulations' refer to the computational models and scenarios that mimic the behavior of brain-computer interaction systems, enabling the analysis and prediction of sensor and actuator data patterns.

Entity-bci__record.label: bci:Record
Entity-bci__record.description: bci:Record refers to a specific type of observation within the BCI Ontology that captures multi-dimensional data related to events in the context of brain-computer interaction.

Entity-bci_vocabulary.label: BCI vocabularies
Entity-bci_vocabulary.description: BCI vocabularies refer to a set of structured terms and definitions used to describe and categorize entities and interactions within the domain of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), facilitating the formalization and annotation of BCI-related metadata.

Entity-the_modeling_and_it_specification.label: The modeling and its specifications
Entity-the_modeling_and_it_specification.description: The modeling and its specifications refer to the structured representation and formal guidelines developed for the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which encompasses the design, conceptualization, and implementation processes aimed at capturing and annotating metadata relevant to Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-bci_sensor_and_actuator_network.label: BCI sensor and actuator networks
Entity-bci_sensor_and_actuator_network.description: BCI sensor and actuator networks are integrated systems that utilize brain-computer interface technology to connect sensors and actuators, enabling communication and control between the human brain and external devices.

Entity-usage.label: usage
Entity-usage.description: In this context, 'usage' refers to the application and integration of the Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) ontology within the Brain-Computer Interaction Ontology (BCI-O) framework, highlighting how BCI-O reuses SSN for enhanced semantic interoperability and data capture activities.

Entity-any_interaction.label: any interaction
Entity-any_interaction.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), 'any interaction' refers to the various types of engagements or exchanges that occur between users and BCI systems, which are categorized and represented through structured metadata to facilitate understanding and analysis of these interactions.

Entity-machine-readable_bci_semantic_mod.label: machine-readable BCI semantic model
Entity-machine-readable_bci_semantic_mod.description: The machine-readable BCI semantic model is a formalized framework designed to enable interoperability among software agents in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems by providing a structured representation of BCI data capture activities, ensuring simplicity, extensibility, and reusability.

Entity-previously_mentioned_module.label: previously mentioned modules
Entity-previously_mentioned_module.description: The 'previously mentioned modules' refer to the distinct components of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that collectively describe various functional aspects of the brain-computer interaction model, including concepts such as Subject, Context, Session, Sense Model, Sensors, System Capabilities, Results, Actuation Model, Annotation Tag, Descriptor, and EEG concepts.

Entity-context_stimulus.label: context stimuli
Entity-context_stimulus.description: Context stimuli refer to event markers that are used in the BCI Ontology to annotate specific data segments, capturing the interactions between a subject and their environment during brain-computer interaction activities.

Entity-bci_application.label: BCI application
Entity-bci_application.description: BCI application refers to a technology or software that utilizes brain-computer interface (BCI) systems to facilitate direct communication between the brain and external devices.

Entity-it_specification.label: its specifications
Entity-it_specification.description: The term 'its specifications' refers to the detailed requirements and guidelines established for the development and implementation of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which include the modeling processes, structural design, and validation checkpoints necessary to ensure the ontology's effectiveness in capturing and representing metadata for Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-bci__device.label: bci:Device
Entity-bci__device.description: bci:Device refers to a specific type of sensor within the Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) ontology that is used to capture and process brain signals as part of the BCI data capture activities.

Entity-event.label: events
Entity-event.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'events' refer to the contextual input data that are stimuli or observations related to a subject's interaction with their environment during brain-computer interaction activities.

Entity-ontological_overlay.label: ontological overlay
Entity-ontological_overlay.description: The ontological overlay refers to a conceptual framework within the BCI Ontology that enables Brain-Computer Interaction systems to organize and interpret large collections of data through semantic annotations, facilitating adaptive reasoning and data analytics.

Entity-sso-based_core_alignment.label: SSO-based core alignments
Entity-sso-based_core_alignment.description: SSO-based core alignments refer to the foundational concepts within the BCI Ontology that define the relationships and roles of Stimulus, Sensor, and Observation in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction, facilitating the semantic interoperability and integration of BCI systems.

Entity-ssn_and_iot-o_specification.label: SSN and IoT-O specifications
Entity-ssn_and_iot-o_specification.description: The SSN and IoT-O specifications refer to established guidelines and best practices for the development and documentation of ontologies related to sensor networks and the Internet of Things, which were utilized in the creation of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) for Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-augmented_bci.label: augmented BCI
Entity-augmented_bci.description: Augmented BCI refers to an enhanced brain-computer interface that incorporates semantic context-awareness to improve the interaction and functionality of BCI systems in ambient intelligence environments.

Entity-a_pervasive_online_bci_system.label: a pervasive online BCI system
Entity-a_pervasive_online_bci_system.description: A pervasive online BCI system refers to a comprehensive and integrated framework for Brain-Computer Interaction that utilizes a proto-ontology to facilitate the development and deployment of BCI applications within various physical and virtual environments, enhancing user interaction through context-aware technologies.

Entity-adaptive_bci.label: Adaptive BCI
Entity-adaptive_bci.description: Adaptive BCI refers to a type of brain-computer interface that dynamically adjusts its operation based on user interactions and environmental conditions to enhance data processing and decision-making capabilities.

Entity-environment.label: environment
Entity-environment.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), the term 'environment' refers to the real-world settings in which human beings interact with BCI systems while performing activities, encompassing the contextual events and stimuli that influence the data captured by these systems.

Entity-modeling_observation.label: modeling observations
Entity-modeling_observation.description: Modeling observations refers to the specific concepts and axioms defined within the BCI Ontology that facilitate the structured representation and interpretation of data collected from brain-computer interaction systems.

Entity-several_module.label: several modules
Entity-several_module.description: Several modules refer to distinct components within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that each address specific functional aspects of the brain-computer interaction model, facilitating a structured understanding of various key topics related to BCI data capture and processing.

Entity-bci_domain.label: BCI domain
Entity-bci_domain.description: The BCI domain refers to the conceptual area within Brain-Computer Interaction that encompasses observations, actuation, and interactions related to the processing and analysis of brain signals in real-world contexts.

Entity-event_annotation.label: event annotations
Entity-event_annotation.description: Event annotations refer to the structured metadata that describes specific neuro-physiological events within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), facilitating the classification and analysis of brain states and dynamics.

Entity-sso.label: SSO
Entity-sso.description: SSO refers to the Stimulus-Sensor-Observation ontology design pattern, which serves as a foundational structure for the Sense Model in the BCI Ontology, facilitating the organization and integration of observation-related data in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-bci_data_capture_activity.label: BCI data capture activities
Entity-bci_data_capture_activity.description: BCI data capture activities refer to the systematic processes involved in collecting and annotating brain signal data within Brain-Computer Interaction systems, aimed at understanding brain states and dynamics in various contexts.

Entity-the_concept_of_context_and_contex.label: the concepts of context and contextual relations
aliases: the concepts of context and contextual relations
Entity-the_concept_of_context_and_contex.description: The concepts of context and contextual relations refer to the integration of situational factors, such as user conditions and environmental influences, into the BCI Ontology to enhance the understanding and analysis of neurophysiological signals in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

mentions.local_name: the concepts of context and contextual relations

Entity-bci-o_s_context_model.label: BCI-O's Context Model
Entity-bci-o_s_context_model.description: BCI-O's Context Model is a framework that utilizes abstractions from the Unity game engine to describe and organize the structural, behavioral, and temporal aspects of environments in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-sso_odp.label: SSO ODP
Entity-sso_odp.description: SSO ODP refers to the Stimulus-Sensor-Observation ontology design pattern, which serves as a foundational structure for modeling observation-related ontologies and data in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-context.label: context
Entity-context.description: The term 'context' in this paper refers to the situational and environmental factors that influence the characteristics of biological and neurophysiological signals in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems, which are essential for understanding user states and improving data analysis.

Entity-observation.label: observations
Entity-observation.description: In the context of the BCI domain, 'observations' refer to the recorded stimuli and interactions captured during brain-computer interaction activities, which are essential for understanding and analyzing the relationship between human subjects and their environments.

Entity-interaction.label: interactions
Entity-interaction.description: In the context of the BCI domain, 'interactions' refer to the various ways in which human beings engage with their environment through brain-computer interfaces, encompassing both the observations made and the actuation processes involved.

Entity-the_relevant_metadata_concept.label: the relevant metadata concepts
Entity-the_relevant_metadata_concept.description: The relevant metadata concepts refer to the specific attributes and classifications used in the BCI-O ontology to establish relationships and facilitate semantic queries for brain-computer interaction applications.

Entity-semantic_foundation.label: semantic foundation
Entity-semantic_foundation.description: The term 'semantic foundation' refers to the underlying conceptual framework provided by the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that enables Brain-Computer Interaction systems to be context-aware and semantically informed, facilitating enhanced data analytics and interoperability in sensor systems.

Entity-bci_device.label: BCI devices
Entity-bci_device.description: BCI devices are technological systems that facilitate direct communication between the brain and external devices, enabling users to control computers or other machines through neural activity.

Entity-modeling_artifact_(1).label: modeling artifacts
Entity-modeling_artifact_(1).description: Modeling artifacts in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) refer to the components and structures, such as sensors and actuators, that facilitate the interaction between humans and their environment during real-world activities, enabling the observation and recording of stimuli and contextual events in multimodal BCI data.

Entity-another_application.label: Another application
Entity-another_application.description: Another application refers to the use of the BCI Ontology in the context of Neuromonitoring VR/AR Goggle systems, demonstrating its capability to enhance brain-computer interaction through semantic metadata definitions.

Entity-san-iot-o.label: SAN-IoT-O
Entity-san-iot-o.description: SAN-IoT-O is an ontology that provides a semantic framework for the Internet of Things, facilitating the integration and interoperability of sensor data within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-sosassn__san.label: SOSA/SSN + SAN
Entity-sosassn__san.description: SOSA/SSN + SAN refers to the core layer of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which integrates the Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA/SSN) ontologies with the Semantic Actuator Network (SAN) to provide a structured framework for modeling brain-computer interaction data and actuation processes.

Entity-event_marker.label: event markers
Entity-event_marker.description: Event markers are specific annotations within the BCI Ontology that denote context stimuli and are used to label data segments based on observed events and responses in brain-computer interaction systems.

Entity-the_context.label: the context
Entity-the_context.description: The context refers to the architectural description of a physical or virtual environment within the BCI Ontology, encompassing a sequence of scenes that illustrate the interactions of spatially located entities, which is essential for understanding the dynamics of human-environment interactions in Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-the_analysis_on_the_usage_of_ssn.label: the analysis on the usage of SSN
aliases: the analysis on the usage of SSN
Entity-the_analysis_on_the_usage_of_ssn.description: The analysis on the usage of SSN refers to the examination and documentation of how the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) aligns with and reuses the Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) ontology, highlighting its role in enhancing semantic interoperability and integration within Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

mentions.local_name: the analysis on the usage of SSN

Entity-any_environment_for_bci.label: any environment for BCI
Entity-any_environment_for_bci.description: Any environment for BCI refers to the conceptual and physical contexts, whether real or virtual, that facilitate Brain-Computer Interaction by providing the necessary architecture and components for effective human-environment interaction in BCI systems.

Entity-contextual_input_data.label: contextual input data
aliases: the contextual input data and events
Entity-contextual_input_data.description: The term 'contextual input data' refers to the observations and events related to a subject's interaction with their environment, as defined within the Sense Model of the BCI Ontology, which captures the relevant data streams and stimuli for brain-computer interaction.

mentions.local_name: the contextual input data and events

Entity-actuation.label: actuation
Entity-actuation.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), 'actuation' refers to the mechanism by which BCI systems translate analyzed neuro-physiological signals into specific responses or actions, enabling users to interact with their environment, such as controlling devices or responding to stimuli.

Entity-semantically_context-aware.label: semantically context-aware
Entity-semantically_context-aware.description: The term 'semantically context-aware' refers to BCI systems that utilize a novel Context Model to integrate contextual information with data recordings, enabling them to adapt and respond appropriately to real and virtual-world situations.

Entity-electronic_system.label: electronic systems
Entity-electronic_system.description: Electronic systems refer to Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) that collect and analyze neuro-physiological signals such as EEG, ECG, and EOG to determine a user's brain states and actuate specific responses.

Entity-modeling_result.label: modeling results
Entity-modeling_result.description: The term 'modeling results' refers to specific concepts within the BCI-O ontology that are aligned with axioms for representing data blocks and recorded outcomes from brain-computer interaction activities.

Entity-bci__context.scene.label: bci:Context.Scene
Entity-bci__context.scene.description: bci:Context.Scene refers to a specific type of context within the BCI Ontology that represents a spatial-temporal location relevant to brain-computer interaction scenarios.

Entity-subject-context_interaction.label: subject-context interactions
Entity-subject-context_interaction.description: Subject-context interactions refer to the cognitive processes and interactions that occur between a subject, such as a human, and their contextual environment, particularly in the context of monitoring brain dynamics within the BCI Ontology framework.

Entity-the_bci_metadata.label: the BCI metadata
Entity-the_bci_metadata.description: The BCI metadata refers to the combined sets of vocabulary, specifically the EEG Study Schema (ESS) and the Hierarchical Event Descriptor (HED), used to describe the settings of neuro-physiological recordings and the specification of neuro-physiological events in Brain-Computer Interaction research.

Entity-environment_for_bci.label: environment for BCI
Entity-environment_for_bci.description: The 'environment for BCI' refers to the relevant component architecture that encompasses both physical and virtual contexts in which Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems operate, facilitating the interaction between users and BCI technologies.

Entity-signal.label: signals
Entity-signal.description: The term 'signals' refers to the neuro-physiological signals that are collected and analyzed by Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) to determine a user's brain states, which can be influenced by various contextual factors such as physical conditions and environmental conditions.

Entity-the_relationship_between_the_rele.label: the relationship between the relevant metadata concepts
aliases: the relationship between the relevant metadata concepts
Entity-the_relationship_between_the_rele.description: The relationship between the relevant metadata concepts refers to the connections and interactions among various metadata elements that are essential for effectively categorizing and processing data within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), as defined by the vPod Ontology and its integration with the BCI Ontology (BCI-O).

mentions.local_name: the relationship between the relevant metadata concepts

Entity-bci_experiment.label: BCI experiments
Entity-bci_experiment.description: BCI experiments refer to research studies that investigate the interactions between the brain and external devices through brain-computer interface technology.

Entity-structure.label: structure
Entity-structure.description: In this context, 'structure' refers to the organized framework and foundational design principles underlying the BCI Ontology, which facilitates the integration and semantic representation of metadata for brain-computer interaction systems.

Entity-interaction_model_setting.label: interaction model settings
aliases: the interaction model settings of the data
Entity-interaction_model_setting.description: The interaction model settings refer to the descriptive features that characterize how data is collected and annotated in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems, influencing the interpretation and classification of brain signals in various contexts.

mentions.local_name: the interaction model settings of the data

Entity-bci_system_architecture.label: BCI systems architecture
Entity-bci_system_architecture.description: BCI systems architecture refers to the structured framework and design principles that govern the integration and functioning of brain-computer interface systems, encompassing components such as sensors, data processing, and user interaction.

Entity-the_semantic_sensor_network__ssn_.label: The Semantic Sensor Network (SSN)
Entity-the_semantic_sensor_network__ssn_.description: The Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) is a standard framework ontology that provides a structured conceptual template for modeling sensor networks and their interactions, which is further extended by the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) to enhance semantic interoperability in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-sensor__observation__sample__and_.label: Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator
Entity-sensor__observation__sample__and_.description: The mention 'Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator' refers to a framework that provides a standardized approach for modeling sensor-actuator systems, particularly in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) as integrated within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O).

Entity-action.label: action
Entity-action.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'action' refers to a specific behavior or movement performed by a subject while engaged in an activity, which is integral to the interaction model that connects stimuli and effects within the framework of brain-computer interactions.

Entity-concept.label: concepts
Entity-concept.description: In this context, 'concepts' refers to the fundamental ideas and constructs that define the semantic relationships and structures within the BCI Ontology, which are essential for organizing and interpreting the metadata associated with brain-computer interaction experiments.

Entity-the_semantic_matching.label: the Semantic Matching
Entity-the_semantic_matching.description: The Semantic Matching refers to the process of defining the relationships between relevant metadata concepts within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) applications, specifically as it relates to the vPod Ontology and its integration with the BCI Ontology (BCI-O).

Entity-activity.label: activity
Entity-activity.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'activity' refers to the specific tasks or actions performed by a human subject, which are integral to understanding their interaction with the environment and the associated states during Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-stimulus-sensor-observation.label: Stimulus-Sensor-Observation
Entity-stimulus-sensor-observation.description: The Stimulus-Sensor-Observation (SSO) ontology design pattern is a conceptual framework within the Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) that defines the relationships and interactions between stimuli, sensors, and observations, serving as a foundational structure for modeling sensor networks in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI).

Entity-bci__session.label: bci:Session
Entity-bci__session.description: bci:Session refers to a conceptual entity within the BCI Ontology that represents a specific instance of interaction or activity occurring in a defined spatial-temporal context related to brain-computer interaction.

Entity-bci-o_proto-ontology.label: BCI-O proto-ontology
Entity-bci-o_proto-ontology.description: The BCI-O proto-ontology is a preliminary framework developed collaboratively by NCTU and UCSD to facilitate semantic search and high-level processing of BCI metadata across diverse applications and datasets.

Entity-bci_sensor_and_actuator.label: BCI sensors and actuators
Entity-bci_sensor_and_actuator.description: BCI sensors and actuators are devices used in brain-computer interface systems to detect neural signals and translate them into commands for external devices or systems.

Entity-axiom_for_modeling_observation.label: axioms for modeling observations
Entity-axiom_for_modeling_observation.description: The 'axioms for modeling observations' refer to a set of formal principles within the BCI Ontology that define how to systematically represent and interpret specific data points and events related to sensory inputs in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-conceptual_framework.label: conceptual framework
Entity-conceptual_framework.description: The term 'conceptual framework' in this context refers to the structured model defined by the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that outlines the essential components and interactions within Brain-Computer Interaction systems, enabling their extension and implementation in various applications.

Entity-situation.label: situation
Entity-situation.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), 'situation' refers to the specific conditions or circumstances, such as user physical state and environmental factors, that influence the characteristics of biological and neurophysiological signals.

Entity-design_approach.label: Design Approach
Entity-design_approach.description: The 'Design Approach' refers to the foundational principle of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which is structured as a three-layered architecture of ontology alignments, integrating foundational, core, and domain-specific layers to facilitate the semantic interoperability and integration of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-contextual_aspect.label: contextual aspect
Entity-contextual_aspect.description: The 'contextual aspect' refers to the component of the BCI Ontology that elucidates the architecture of environments relevant to Brain-Computer Interaction by abstracting high-level concepts and relationships identified in existing literature.

Entity-bci_interaction_model_complexity.label: BCI interaction model complexity
Entity-bci_interaction_model_complexity.description: BCI interaction model complexity refers to the intricate structuring and formalization of the interactions and relationships among key components in Brain-Computer Interaction systems, which involves identifying major players and data flows, utilizing established Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) principles, and applying open BCI vocabularies to enhance the modeling of metadata annotations and related concepts.

Entity-sense_model.label: Sense Model
Entity-sense_model.description: The Sense Model is a conceptual component of the BCI Ontology that describes the interaction between contextual stimuli and sensory observations, based on the Stimulus-Sensor-Observation Ontology Design Pattern and aligned with the SOSA/SSN upper ontologies.

Entity-bci__subject.label: bci:Subject
Entity-bci__subject.description: bci:Subject refers to an entity type within the BCI Ontology that represents a person or natural person involved in brain-computer interaction contexts.

Entity-large-scale_bci_data_analytics_mo.label: large-scale BCI data analytics models
aliases: large-scale BCI data analytics models and processes
Entity-large-scale_bci_data_analytics_mo.description: Large-scale BCI data analytics models refer to comprehensive frameworks and methodologies designed to analyze and interpret extensive datasets generated from brain-computer interaction systems, leveraging semantic reasoning and machine learning techniques to enhance the understanding of brain states and dynamics in various contexts.

mentions.local_name: large-scale BCI data analytics models and processes

Entity-dynamic.label: dynamics
