Entity-dynamic.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), 'dynamics' refers to the analysis of brain states and their variations in response to diverse daily-life circumstances, which are essential for understanding and interpreting brain signals.

Entity-logical_model.label: logical models
Entity-logical_model.description: In the context of the BCI-O ontology, 'logical models' refer to structured representations that define the relationships and properties of entities within the Brain-Computer Interaction domain, facilitating the formalization and analysis of BCI data and interactions.

Entity-the_specification.label: The specification
Entity-the_specification.description: The specification refers to the guidelines within the BCI Ontology that determine how applications can manage the semantic expressiveness of measurement units and extend the concept of procedures in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-contextual_relation.label: contextual relations
Entity-contextual_relation.description: The term 'contextual relations' refers to the relationships and dependencies between various contextual factors, such as user conditions and environmental variables, that influence the interpretation and analysis of neurophysiological signals within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) framework.

Entity-integration.label: integration
Entity-integration.description: In this context, 'integration' refers to the process of enhancing the semantic interoperability of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems by utilizing the SOSA/SSN framework, which connects various components and facilitates effective communication within specialized sensor networks.

Entity-data_recording.label: data recordings
Entity-data_recording.description: Data recordings refer to the collections of brain signal data captured by BCI systems, which are annotated and structured to enable semantic context-awareness and facilitate advanced data analytics in both real and virtual environments.

Entity-contextual_integration.label: contextual integration
Entity-contextual_integration.description: Contextual integration refers to the process of linking stimuli, actions, and effects within a specific environment in the BCI-O framework, facilitating the interaction between a subject and their context through Sense and Actuation Models.

Entity-the_concept_of_context_with_those.label: the concepts of context with those of sense and actuation
aliases: the concepts of context with those of sense and actuation
Entity-the_concept_of_context_with_those.description: The concepts of context with those of sense and actuation refer to the integration of contextual factors, such as user conditions and environmental influences, with the mechanisms of sensing and actuating in Brain-Computer Interaction systems, as outlined in the BCI Ontology.

mentions.local_name: the concepts of context with those of sense and actuation

Entity-annotation_tag_module.label: Annotation Tag module
Entity-annotation_tag_module.description: The Annotation Tag module is a component of the BCI Ontology that facilitates the structured metadata annotation of brain-computer interaction data, enabling the classification and analysis of brain states in various contexts.

Entity-these_conceptual_component.label: These conceptual components
Entity-these_conceptual_component.description: These conceptual components refer to the essential elements within the BCI Ontology that facilitate the understanding and representation of the structural, functional, and temporal complexities of physical or virtual environments in Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-relevant_entity.label: relevant entities
Entity-relevant_entity.description: Relevant entities refer to the specific concepts and components within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that are essential for describing and extending the metadata associated with brain-computer interaction activities.

Entity-condition.label: conditions
Entity-condition.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'conditions' refer to the specific settings or parameters that define the environment and circumstances under which a session of brain-computer interaction occurs.

Entity-prediction.label: predictions
Entity-prediction.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), 'predictions' refers to the outcomes generated by brain state prediction and classification models that are trained and refined using relevant data sets through semantic data queries.

Entity-axiom_for_modeling_sensor.label: axioms for modeling sensors
aliases: axioms for modeling sensors under observations
Entity-axiom_for_modeling_sensor.description: The 'axioms for modeling sensors' refer to a formalized set of principles and rules within the BCI Ontology that define how sensors are represented and utilized in the context of observations in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

mentions.local_name: axioms for modeling sensors under observations

Entity-context_model.label: Context Model
Entity-context_model.description: The Context Model refers to a framework developed within the BCI Ontology that utilizes abstractions from Unity's gaming architecture to describe and organize the structural, behavioral, and temporal aspects of environments relevant to Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-reuse.label: reuse
Entity-reuse.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'reuse' refers to the application of existing ontology design patterns and alignment techniques to enhance the Sense and Actuation Models within the framework of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-bci_domain_concept.label: BCI domain concepts
Entity-bci_domain_concept.description: BCI domain concepts refer to the specific conceptual components and terminologies derived from semi-structured standard vocabularies and formats that are relevant to Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems, particularly in the context of data capture and analysis.

Entity-model.label: models
Entity-model.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'models' refer to the structured representations and computational frameworks used for calibrating and personalizing Brain-Computer Interaction systems, particularly in relation to subject-independent features and data sets for enhanced performance.

Entity-real_and_virtual-world_situation.label: real and virtual-world situations
Entity-real_and_virtual-world_situation.description: The term 'real and virtual-world situations' refers to the diverse contexts and environments, both physical and digital, in which Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems operate and analyze data, enabling them to be contextually aware and adaptive to varying circumstances.

Entity-spatial-temporal_specification.label: spatial-temporal specification
Entity-spatial-temporal_specification.description: The term 'spatial-temporal specification' refers to the detailed description of the location and timing aspects of a sensing activity within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems, as captured in the Observation component of the BCI Ontology.

Entity-the_design_principle.label: The design principle
Entity-the_design_principle.description: The design principle refers to the foundational concept that guides the interaction model in the BCI-O ontology, which encompasses the bidirectional relationship between sensory input and actuation in brain-computer interactions.

Entity-proto-ontology.label: proto-ontology
Entity-proto-ontology.description: The proto-ontology refers to an initial conceptual framework designed for a pervasive online Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) system, which was developed based on specific project requirements and iterative software engineering processes.

Entity-diverse_daily-life_circumstance.label: diverse daily-life circumstances
Entity-diverse_daily-life_circumstance.description: Diverse daily-life circumstances refer to the various real-world situations and environments in which Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems analyze brain states and dynamics, highlighting the need for context-aware metadata annotations to accurately capture and interpret brain signal data.

Entity-this_use_case.label: this use case
Entity-this_use_case.description: This use case refers to the application of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) in facilitating transfer learning operations through a semantic query that selects and categorizes EEG datasets for glaucoma detection, specifically focusing on high-correlation data segments for input into a more sophisticated convolutional neural network model.

Entity-characterization.label: characterizations
Entity-characterization.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'characterizations' refer to the formal definitions and classifications of the major players and interactions within Brain-Computer Interaction systems, which are structured according to established BCI vocabularies.

Entity-modality_type.label: modality types
Entity-modality_type.description: Modality types refer to the specific categories of observations in the BCI-O framework that characterize the nature of input data and events received from sensors during brain-computer interaction.

Entity-the_application.label: The application
Entity-the_application.description: The application refers to a specific functionality within the BCI-O framework that focuses on annotating the probability and correlation of high-correlated segments from a source model in the context of transfer learning for EEG data analysis.

Entity-implementation.label: implementations
Entity-implementation.description: The term 'implementations' refers to the practical applications and extensions of the BCI-O structure within Brain-Computer Interaction systems, allowing for the integration and utilization of the defined conceptual framework in real-world scenarios.

Entity-framework.label: frameworks
Entity-framework.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'frameworks' refers to structured models or systems that provide a conceptual template for organizing and integrating various components of Brain-Computer Interaction, specifically in relation to the Sense and Actuation Models derived from the Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) and other ontological standards.

Entity-core__generic__and_relevant_conse.label: core, generic, and relevant consensual concepts about BCI data capture activities
aliases: core, generic, and relevant consensual concepts about BCI data capture activities
Entity-core__generic__and_relevant_conse.description: The entity refers to the foundational and universally accepted ideas that guide the understanding and implementation of data capture processes in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

mentions.local_name: core, generic, and relevant consensual concepts about BCI data capture activities

Entity-modeling_structure_and_content.label: modeling structure and content
Entity-modeling_structure_and_content.description: The phrase 'modeling structure and content' refers to the comprehensive framework and organization of data and metadata within the Base Version of the BCI Ontology, which is designed to facilitate the representation and interaction of brain-computer interface data.

Entity-sample.label: Sample
Entity-sample.description: In the context of the Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) ontology, 'Sample' refers to a fundamental component that represents a specific instance of data collected from observations made by sensors within the framework of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-contextual_event.label: contextual events
Entity-contextual_event.description: Contextual events refer to stimuli that occur in the environment during real-world activities, which are observed and recorded by Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems to annotate multimodal data.

Entity-situation-specific_data_analytics.label: situation-specific data analytics
Entity-situation-specific_data_analytics.description: Situation-specific data analytics refers to the analytical methods and processes used in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems to interpret and reason about data collected from brain signals in specific contexts, enabling adaptive responses and transfer learning through the application of inference rules.

Entity-flow.label: flows
Entity-flow.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), 'flows' refer to the dynamic interactions and data exchanges between major components and entities involved in the BCI system, which are essential for understanding and modeling the complexity of human-computer interactions.

Entity-it_structure_and_documentation.label: its structure and documentation
Entity-it_structure_and_documentation.description: The mention 'its structure and documentation' refers to the organized framework and accompanying written guidelines that outline the design, implementation, and usage of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), which formalizes metadata for Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-observation_collection.label: Observation Collection
Entity-observation_collection.description: Observation Collection refers to a structured set of observations or data points collected during brain-computer interaction activities, which is being discussed in the context of ensuring consistency and homogeneity within the BCI Ontology framework.

Entity-owl_2_ql_profile_version_of_bci-o.label: OWL 2 QL profile version of BCI-O
aliases: OWL 2 QL profile version of BCI-O
Entity-owl_2_ql_profile_version_of_bci-o.description: The OWL 2 QL profile version of BCI-O is a specialized adaptation of the BCI Ontology designed to enable efficient querying of BCI-related metadata using a restricted subset of OWL 2 features.

mentions.local_name: OWL 2 QL profile version of BCI-O

Entity-observation__actuation__and_inter.label: observations, actuation, and interactions
Entity-observation__actuation__and_inter.description: The term 'observations, actuation, and interactions' refers to the conceptual components within the Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) domain that encompass the processes of sensing stimuli, executing actions based on those stimuli, and the interactions between the subject and their environment.

Entity-aae.label: AAE
Entity-aae.description: AAE refers to a specific design pattern used within the context of the Sense and Actuation Models in the BCI Ontology, which is part of a framework for modeling brain-computer interactions.

Entity-reasoning.label: reasoning
Entity-reasoning.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), 'reasoning' refers to the cognitive process of applying inference rules to analyze data and derive conclusions for situation-specific data analytics, particularly in the implementation of Adaptive BCI systems.

Entity-wearing_a_set_of_sensor.label: wearing a set of sensors
Entity-wearing_a_set_of_sensor.description: The term 'wearing a set of sensors' refers to the use of wearable devices that capture and transmit physiological or environmental data, enabling human interaction with their surroundings in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-module.label: modules
Entity-module.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'modules' refer to distinct components that categorize and explain key functional aspects of the Brain-Computer Interaction model.

Entity-san.label: SAN
Entity-san.description: SAN refers to an upper ontology that is aligned with the Actuation Model in the BCI Ontology, which is used to formalize the interaction between subjects and their context in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-unambiguous_searchability.label: unambiguous searchability
Entity-unambiguous_searchability.description: Unambiguous searchability refers to the capability of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) to facilitate clear and precise querying of sensor and actuator data patterns within Brain-Computer Interaction systems, ensuring that the search results are easily interpretable and contextually relevant.

Entity-requirement.label: requirements
Entity-requirement.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology development, 'requirements' refers to the initial project specifications that guided the design and construction of the proto-ontology for the Brain-Computer Interaction system.

Entity-these_concept.label: these concepts
Entity-these_concept.description: These concepts refer to the various metadata elements and their semantic relationships that are being developed to enhance the understanding and classification of brain-computer interaction (BCI) experiments.

Entity-the_new_proposed_concept_and_rela.label: the new proposed concepts and relationships
aliases: the new proposed concepts and relationships
Entity-the_new_proposed_concept_and_rela.description: The new proposed concepts and relationships refer to the ongoing discussions and extensions related to the SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation that aim to enhance the formal semantic structure for modeling observations and interactions in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) and bio-signal monitoring.

mentions.local_name: the new proposed concepts and relationships

Entity-easy_integration__reusability__an.label: easy integration, reusability, and extensibility
Entity-easy_integration__reusability__an.description: The term 'easy integration, reusability, and extensibility' refers to the capability of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) to seamlessly incorporate various Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems into the Linked Data framework, allowing for the efficient reuse of its semantic structures and the flexibility to extend its functionalities across diverse applications.

Entity-ambient_intelligence_setting.label: ambient intelligence settings
Entity-ambient_intelligence_setting.description: Ambient intelligence settings refer to environments enhanced by intelligent systems that utilize context-aware technologies to support and improve human-computer interactions, particularly in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-object.label: objects
Entity-object.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'objects' refers to instances of the 'dul:Object' class, which serve as foundational entities that can be further categorized into specific types such as sensors and devices within the framework of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-bci_datasets.label: BCI datasets
Entity-bci_datasets.description: BCI datasets refer to collections of data specifically gathered from brain-computer interface experiments, which may include various types of neuroimaging and behavioral assessments across different applications.

Entity-sensor_and_actuator_data_pattern.label: sensor and actuator data patterns
Entity-sensor_and_actuator_data_pattern.description: The term 'sensor and actuator data patterns' refers to the structured representations and analytical frameworks derived from the data collected by sensors and actuators in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems, which facilitate semantic analysis, searchability, and interoperability for enhanced understanding and prediction of brain states and dynamics.

Entity-term_definition.label: term definitions
Entity-term_definition.description: The term 'term definitions' refers to the formal descriptions and semantic specifications of relevant metadata terms used in the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) to facilitate BCI activity and data annotation, ensuring alignment with established ontologies such as SOSA/SSN and SAN (IoT-O).

Entity-real-world_activity.label: real-world activities
Entity-real-world_activity.description: Real-world activities refer to the various daily-life circumstances and interactions in which Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems are applied, leveraging advancements in technology to enhance human-computer interaction.

Entity-brain_state_and_dynamic.label: brain states and dynamics
Entity-brain_state_and_dynamic.description: The term 'brain states and dynamics' refers to the various conditions and activities of the brain as measured and analyzed by Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems, which involve the classification of brain signals in different real-life contexts.

Entity-specific_concept.label: specific concepts
Entity-specific_concept.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'specific concepts' refer to the defined elements that represent distinct observations within the framework of brain-computer interaction, which are structured according to established axioms for accurate modeling and analysis.

Entity-time_interval.label: time intervals
Entity-time_interval.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'time intervals' refer to defined datatype properties that facilitate the modeling of temporal aspects within Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-physicalvirtual_environment.label: physical/virtual environments
Entity-physicalvirtual_environment.description: The term 'physical/virtual environments' refers to the various contexts in which Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) occurs, encompassing both tangible, real-world settings and digital, simulated spaces that influence the interaction dynamics between users and BCI systems.

Entity-interval.label: interval
Entity-interval.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'interval' refers to a temporal entity that represents a duration of time, as defined in the W3C OWL-Time ontology, which is utilized for modeling time-related aspects of brain-computer interaction data.

Entity-structural-object.label: structural-object
Entity-structural-object.description: The term 'structural-object' refers to a modeling style utilized in the development of the BCI Ontology, specifically leveraging the Unity framework to represent complex interactions and structures within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-prominent_ontology.label: prominent ontologies
Entity-prominent_ontology.description: Prominent ontologies refer to well-established and widely recognized formal representations of knowledge, such as SOSA/SSN and SAN (IoT-O), that serve as foundational frameworks for developing and aligning new ontologies, like the BCI Ontology, in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-an_ontological_structure.label: an ontological structure
Entity-an_ontological_structure.description: An ontological structure refers to a formal framework developed to organize and define the relationships among concepts within the BCI metadata, facilitating the expansion of vocabulary and enhancing semantic clarity in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction experiments.

Entity-vocabulary.label: vocabulary
Entity-vocabulary.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'vocabulary' refers to the sets of metadata terms, specifically the EEG Study Schema (ESS) and the Hierarchical Event Descriptor (HED), that are used to describe neuro-physiological recordings and events in Brain-Computer Interaction experiments.

Entity-unity_world_model.label: UNITY world model
Entity-unity_world_model.description: The UNITY world model refers to a conceptual framework used in game development that integrates context and human-environment interactions, which has been incorporated into the BCI Ontology to enhance the understanding of neuro-physiological signals in Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-conceptual_component.label: conceptual components
Entity-conceptual_component.description: The term 'conceptual components' refers to the abstract elements within the BCI-O framework that facilitate the understanding and modeling of the structural, functional, and temporal complexities of environments in Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-annotation.label: annotations
Entity-annotation.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'annotations' refer to event markers that are derived from context stimuli and response markers generated by machine learning models, which are used to label specific segments of data for predictive analysis.

Entity-relevant_metadata_set.label: relevant metadata sets
Entity-relevant_metadata_set.description: Relevant metadata sets refer to the specific collections of data annotations and descriptors that capture essential features of brain signals within the BCI Ontology framework, enabling effective querying and analysis of BCI data.

Entity-aae_design_pattern.label: AAE Design Pattern
Entity-aae_design_pattern.description: The AAE Design Pattern refers to the Actuation-Actuator-Effect ontology design pattern used in the context of the BCI Ontology to structure the Actuation Model for Brain-Computer Interaction systems, aligning with the Semantic Actuator Network and the SOSA/SSN ontologies.

Entity-hci_notion.label: HCI notions
Entity-hci_notion.description: HCI notions refer to the fundamental concepts and principles of Human-Computer Interaction that guide the design and analysis of interactions between users and BCI systems.

Entity-stimulus_triggered_by_contextual_.label: stimuli triggered by contextual events
Entity-stimulus_triggered_by_contextual_.description: Stimuli triggered by contextual events refer to the observable and recordable responses or signals generated during human interactions with their environment in real-world activities, which are captured and annotated in multimodal Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) data.

Entity-it_alignment.label: its alignments
Entity-it_alignment.description: The term 'its alignments' refers to the semantic interoperability and integration capabilities of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) with other ontologies and data structures, facilitating the reuse and extensibility of BCI data within the Linked Data framework.

Entity-module_and_their_core_concept.label: modules and their core concepts
Entity-module_and_their_core_concept.description: The phrase 'modules and their core concepts' refers to the distinct components of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that encapsulate essential topics and functional aspects related to the interaction model in Brain-Computer Interaction, each contributing to the overall understanding and implementation of BCI systems.

Entity-segment.label: segments
Entity-segment.description: In the context of the BCI-O ontology, 'segments' refer to specific portions of analyzed EEG recordings that are categorized based on their attributes, such as probability and correlation, and are used in transfer learning operations between machine learning models.

Entity-any_environment.label: any environment
Entity-any_environment.description: The term 'any environment' refers to both physical and virtual settings that can be modeled to capture the structural, functional, and temporal complexities relevant to Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-descriptive_and_predictive_featur.label: descriptive and predictive features
Entity-descriptive_and_predictive_featur.description: Descriptive and predictive features refer to the essential characteristics and anticipated behaviors of brain signals that are captured through BCI metadata annotations, which are crucial for analyzing brain states and dynamics in various contexts.

Entity-interacting_with_one_another.label: interacting with one another
Entity-interacting_with_one_another.description: The term 'interacting with one another' refers to the dynamic relationships and engagements between spatially located entities within a modeled environment, as depicted in scenes that illustrate their specific interactions in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI).

Entity-accessing.label: accessing
Entity-accessing.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'accessing' refers to the process of retrieving and utilizing URI locators to external resources and raw data for the purpose of indexing within Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-context_domain.label: context domain
Entity-context_domain.description: The context domain refers to the conceptual area that encompasses the surroundings and environmental factors relevant to the interactions and activities within Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-behavioral.label: behavioral
Entity-behavioral.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'behavioral' refers to one of the three complementary perspectives used to model the architectural description of environments, focusing on the interactions and dynamics of entities within those environments.

Entity-situation_or_context_dependent.label: situation or context dependent
Entity-situation_or_context_dependent.description: The term 'situation or context dependent' refers to the variability of biological and neurophysiological signals, which are influenced by factors such as the user's physical conditions, time of day, and environmental conditions, thereby affecting the analysis and interpretation of brain states in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-sosassn_vertical_segmentation.label: SOSA/SSN Vertical Segmentation
Entity-sosassn_vertical_segmentation.description: SOSA/SSN Vertical Segmentation refers to the structural alignment framework within the BCI Ontology that integrates the SOSA (Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator) and SSN (Semantic Sensor Network) ontologies, facilitating the organization and interoperability of metadata for brain-computer interaction systems.

Entity-semantic_query_construction.label: semantic query constructions
Entity-semantic_query_construction.description: Semantic query constructions refer to the structured methods used within the BCI Ontology to facilitate the retrieval and analysis of brain-computer interaction data by enabling adaptive reasoning and situation-specific data analytics.

Entity-analysis.label: analysis
Entity-analysis.description: The mention 'analysis' refers to the examination and documentation of the usage of the Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) in relation to the BCI Ontology (BCI-O), highlighting how BCI-O reuses SSN as part of its framework.

Entity-the_overall_process.label: the overall process
Entity-the_overall_process.description: The overall process refers to the comprehensive methodology and series of steps undertaken to develop the BCI-O specifications, encompassing ontology authoring, quality assessment, and adherence to best practices in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-data_recording_collection.label: data recording collections
Entity-data_recording_collection.description: Data recording collections refer to extensive datasets that encompass recorded brain signals and associated metadata, which are utilized in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems for analysis, classification, and adaptive learning.

Entity-standard_axiomatization_model_for.label: standard axiomatization models for actuations
Entity-standard_axiomatization_model_for.description: Standard axiomatization models for actuations refer to formal frameworks developed by the W3C/OGC and IoT communities that provide structured definitions and relationships for actuation processes within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-the_bci-o_spec_s_html_version.label: the BCI-O spec's HTML version
Entity-the_bci-o_spec_s_html_version.description: The BCI-O spec's HTML version refers to the web-based representation of the BCI Ontology specification, which includes early applications and their corresponding RDF graph models for BCI data sharing and analysis.

Entity-formal_semantic_structure.label: formal semantic structure
Entity-formal_semantic_structure.description: A formal semantic structure refers to a standardized framework for modeling and representing the metadata annotations in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems, which is crucial for accurately capturing and interpreting the descriptive and predictive features of brain signals.

Entity-key_topic.label: key topic
Entity-key_topic.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, a 'key topic' refers to a specific module that provides a coherent explanation of a functional aspect related to the Brain-Computer Interaction model.

Entity-domain_level_concept.label: domain level concepts
Entity-domain_level_concept.description: The term 'domain level concepts' refers to the specialized abstractions and structures within the BCI Ontology's Actuation Model that are aligned with the Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA/SSN) framework, facilitating the representation and integration of actuation processes in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-specific_data_segment.label: specific data segments
Entity-specific_data_segment.description: Specific data segments refer to portions of data that are annotated with event markers based on context stimuli and response markers, which are used to define predictive data features in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-user__s_brain_state.label: user’s brain states
Entity-user__s_brain_state.description: User's brain states refer to the specific cognitive and physiological conditions of an individual as determined by the analysis of neuro-physiological signals such as EEG, ECG, and EOG, which are utilized in Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) to enable responsive actions based on the user's mental and emotional state.

Entity-the_project_specification.label: the project specifications
Entity-the_project_specification.description: The project specifications refer to the defined requirements and guidelines that guided the initial design and development of a proto-ontology for a pervasive online Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) system under the CaN-CTA Program.

Entity-semi-structured_standard_vocabula.label: semi-structured standard vocabularies
Entity-semi-structured_standard_vocabula.description: Semi-structured standard vocabularies refer to predefined sets of terms and formats used to describe and annotate data in the Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) domain, facilitating the organization and interoperability of multimodal data through structured metadata.

Entity-entity.label: entities
Entity-entity.description: The term 'entities' refers to the spatially located components within the BCI-O model that interact with one another in a specific way, representing elements of the physical or virtual environment being analyzed.

Entity-pattern-based_architecture.label: pattern-based architecture
Entity-pattern-based_architecture.description: The term 'pattern-based architecture' refers to a design approach utilized in the development of Sense and Actuation Models within the BCI Ontology, which emphasizes the reuse and alignment of established ontology design patterns to enhance the modeling of brain-computer interaction systems.

Entity-axiom_for_modeling_result.label: axioms for modeling results
Entity-axiom_for_modeling_result.description: The term 'axioms for modeling results' refers to a set of formal principles within the BCI Ontology that define how to represent and interpret data blocks and recorded outcomes from brain-computer interaction systems.

Entity-descriptive_and_predictive_parame.label: descriptive and predictive parameters
Entity-descriptive_and_predictive_parame.description: Descriptive and predictive parameters refer to the features annotated in multimodal BCI data, where descriptive parameters explain the interaction model settings and predictive parameters provide essential input for classification models in adaptive Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-categorizing_the_entity.label: categorizing the entities
Entity-categorizing_the_entity.description: The term 'categorizing the entities' refers to the process of organizing and classifying various components involved in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) by utilizing structured metadata to enhance understanding and analysis of interactions within different contexts.

Entity-single_observation.label: single observation
Entity-single_observation.description: The term 'single observation' refers to a specific instance of data captured by sensors in a Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) system, which includes modality types, interpretation aspects, and recorded data as sensor output streams.

Entity-descriptive_feature.label: descriptive features
Entity-descriptive_feature.description: Descriptive features refer to the parameters that elucidate the interaction model settings of the data collected in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-stimulus_event.label: stimulus events
Entity-stimulus_event.description: Stimulus events refer to specific contextual inputs or triggers that elicit responses from a subject in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction, serving as key components in the Sense Model of the BCI Ontology.

Entity-ontology_s_main_design_objective.label: ontology's main design objectives
Entity-ontology_s_main_design_objective.description: The ontology's main design objectives refer to the foundational goals of the BCI Ontology, which include defining essential concepts for BCI data capture, creating a machine-readable semantic model for interoperability among software agents, and promoting simplicity, extensibility, and reusability in its structure.

Entity-heterogeneous_bci_datasets.label: heterogeneous BCI datasets
Entity-heterogeneous_bci_datasets.description: Heterogeneous BCI datasets refer to diverse collections of brain-computer interface data that are gathered from various sources and applications, encompassing different experimental conditions and modalities.

Entity-performing_an_activity.label: performing an activity
Entity-performing_an_activity.description: The phrase 'performing an activity' refers to the action executed by a subject within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), as defined in the BCI Ontology, which encompasses the interaction between a human and their environment during a specific session.

Entity-bci__stimulusevent.label: bci:StimulusEvent
Entity-bci__stimulusevent.description: bci:StimulusEvent refers to an event in the BCI Ontology that represents a detectable change in the environment which triggers sensors to perform observations.

Entity-context_architectonic_definition.label: context architectonic definition
Entity-context_architectonic_definition.description: The 'context architectonic definition' refers to a conceptual framework within the BCI Ontology that integrates contextual information with data recordings to enhance the semantic awareness of Brain-Computer Interaction systems in both real and virtual environments.

Entity-brain_state.label: brain states
Entity-brain_state.description: Brain states refer to the various conditions and dynamics of brain activity that are analyzed and classified by Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems based on sensed signals in different real-life contexts.

Entity-device.label: devices
Entity-device.description: The term 'devices' refers to the hardware components used in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems, specifically those that are associated with the channeling schema and specifications for capturing and processing brain signal data.

Entity-proto-ontology_s_project_specific.label: proto-ontology's project specification
Entity-proto-ontology_s_project_specific.description: The term 'proto-ontology's project specification' refers to the initial set of requirements and guidelines established for the development of a proto-ontology within the context of a Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) system, outlining the conceptualization, formalization, and implementation processes necessary for its construction.

Entity-bci__actuation.label: bci:Actuation
Entity-bci__actuation.description: bci:Actuation refers to the process of executing a procedure that alters the state of a context within the Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) framework, utilizing an actuator to induce physical modifications.

Entity-a_brief_description_of_the_module.label: a brief description of the modules
aliases: a brief description of the modules
Entity-a_brief_description_of_the_module.description: The phrase 'a brief description of the modules' refers to a concise overview of the various components of the BCI Ontology, each representing a key functional aspect of the brain-computer interaction model.

mentions.local_name: a brief description of the modules

Entity-similarity.label: similarities
Entity-similarity.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'similarities' refers to the comparative analysis of sensor and actuator data patterns that enables BCI systems to identify and leverage common features across different datasets for enhanced semantic interoperability and data analytics.

Entity-unity.label: UNITY
Entity-unity.description: UNITY refers to a world model used in game development that provides a framework for integrating context and human-environment interaction into the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) for enhancing brain-computer interaction systems.

Entity-the_descriptive_feature.label: The descriptive features
Entity-the_descriptive_feature.description: The descriptive features refer to the parameters that elucidate the interaction model settings of the data collected in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-context_model_core_concept.label: Context Model core concepts
Entity-context_model_core_concept.description: The 'Context Model core concepts' refer to the foundational abstractions derived from Unity's gaming architectural modeling framework, which are utilized in the BCI Ontology to define and describe the structural, behavioral, and temporal aspects of environments relevant to Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-sosa.label: SOSA
Entity-sosa.description: SOSA (Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator) is a core ontology that serves as a standard framework for the Semantic Sensor Network (SSN), providing a structured approach to model sensor data and interactions in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI).

Entity-predictive_parameter.label: predictive parameters
Entity-predictive_parameter.description: Predictive parameters refer to the features annotated in multimodal BCI data that provide essential input for classification models aimed at adaptive brain-computer interaction.

Entity-alignment.label: alignment
Entity-alignment.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'alignment' refers to the process of ensuring that the definitions and structures of ontology design patterns are consistent and compatible with existing ontologies, specifically in relation to the Sense and Actuation Models.

Entity-annotation_on_specific_data_segme.label: annotations on specific data segments
Entity-annotation_on_specific_data_segme.description: Annotations on specific data segments refer to event markers that are derived from context stimuli and response markers generated by machine learning models, which are used to define predictive data features within the BCI Ontology framework.

Entity-the_human-environment_interaction.label: the human-environment interaction model
Entity-the_human-environment_interaction.description: The human-environment interaction model refers to a framework in Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) that emphasizes the integration of contextual factors with sensory input and actuation processes to enhance the interaction between users and their environments.

Entity-high-level_concept_and_relation.label: high-level concepts and relations
Entity-high-level_concept_and_relation.description: High-level concepts and relations refer to the abstracted foundational ideas and connections derived from existing literature that are essential for modeling the component architecture of environments in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI).

Entity-actuation_model.label: Actuation Model
Entity-actuation_model.description: The Actuation Model is a conceptual component within the BCI Ontology that describes the interaction from the subject to the context, based on the Actuation-Actuator-Effect Ontology Design Pattern and aligned with the SOSA and SAN upper ontologies.

Entity-daily-life_circumstance.label: daily-life circumstances
Entity-daily-life_circumstance.description: The term 'daily-life circumstances' refers to the various real-world situations and environments in which individuals engage in everyday activities, which are relevant for analyzing brain states and dynamics in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-channeling_schema.label: channeling schema
Entity-channeling_schema.description: The 'channeling schema' refers to a data structure model that defines how data from devices is organized and specified within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-the_team.label: the teams
Entity-the_team.description: The teams refer to the collaborative groups involved in the development and expansion of metadata vocabularies for Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) experiments, specifically the SCCN team and the PET Lab team working together on the BCI Ontology.

Entity-it_structure.label: its structure
Entity-it_structure.description: The term 'its structure' refers to the organizational framework of the BCI Ontology's Actuation Model, which is designed to align with the Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) ontology design pattern while integrating with the Semantic Sensor Network (SOSA/SSN) and the Semantic Actuator Network (SAN).

Entity-conceptualization_and_formalizati.label: conceptualization and formalization
Entity-conceptualization_and_formalizati.description: Conceptualization and formalization refer to the analytical and design processes involved in developing a structured representation of knowledge, specifically in the context of creating the BCI Ontology for Brain-Computer Interaction, which encompasses defining requirements, modeling concepts, and establishing formal semantics for BCI metadata.

Entity-that_research_project.label: that research project
Entity-that_research_project.description: The term 'that research project' refers to a collaborative initiative under the Cognition and Neuroergonomics Collaborative Technology Alliance (CaN-CTA) program, which involved the development of a semantic model for characterizing cognitive states and gathering data sets for Transfer Learning, ultimately resulting in the creation of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O).

Entity-accuracy_and_usefulness_of_bci_sy.label: accuracy and usefulness of BCI systems
aliases: accuracy and usefulness of BCI systems
Entity-accuracy_and_usefulness_of_bci_sy.description: The accuracy and usefulness of BCI systems refer to the effectiveness and reliability of these systems in interpreting neuro-physiological signals to accurately classify brain states and facilitate appropriate responses, which is often hindered by insufficient training data and variability among users.

mentions.local_name: accuracy and usefulness of BCI systems

Entity-homogeneity_of_an_observation_col.label: Homogeneity of an Observation Collection
aliases: the Homogeneity of an Observation Collection
Entity-homogeneity_of_an_observation_col.description: The Homogeneity of an Observation Collection refers to a theoretical issue concerning the uniformity and consistency of data collected from observations in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction, particularly as it relates to the integration and standardization of metadata annotations within the BCI Ontology.

mentions.local_name: the Homogeneity of an Observation Collection

Entity-feature_and_property.label: features and properties
Entity-feature_and_property.description: The term 'features and properties' refers to the specific characteristics and attributes of the observations made by BCI systems, detailing the methodologies and criteria used to capture and interpret brain signal data.

Entity-specific_setting_and_condition.label: specific settings and conditions
Entity-specific_setting_and_condition.description: The term 'specific settings and conditions' refers to the particular environmental and situational parameters that define the context in which a subject interacts with a Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) during a single activity session.

Entity-hybrid_modeling_style.label: hybrid modeling style
Entity-hybrid_modeling_style.description: The 'hybrid modeling style' refers to an integrated approach that combines verbal/semi-structured elements from BCI vocabularies, logic-based frameworks from upper ontologies, and structural-object components from the Unity framework to effectively model Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-the_predictive_feature.label: the predictive features
Entity-the_predictive_feature.description: The predictive features refer to the parameters derived from multimodal BCI data that are utilized as crucial inputs for classification models aimed at enabling adaptive brain-computer interaction.

Entity-eeg_study_schema.label: EEG Study Schema
Entity-eeg_study_schema.description: The EEG Study Schema (ESS) is a metadata vocabulary developed to describe the settings of neuro-physiological recordings in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) research.

Entity-verbalsemi-structured.label: verbal/semi-structured
Entity-verbalsemi-structured.description: The term 'verbal/semi-structured' refers to a modeling style that utilizes BCI vocabularies to represent concepts in a flexible and less formalized manner, allowing for a combination of natural language descriptions and structured data elements in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction ontology development.

Entity-system_capability.label: System Capabilities
Entity-system_capability.description: System Capabilities refer to specific concepts within the BCI-O ontology that define the logical components and measurement properties of a channeling schema's data structure model.

Entity-sensing_activity.label: sensing activity
Entity-sensing_activity.description: Sensing activity refers to the multi-dimensional event that captures information about a detectable change in the environment, the sensor performing the observation, and the output generated, as part of the BCI-O's Sense Model.

Entity-structural-object__unity_framewor.label: structural-object (Unity framework)
Entity-structural-object__unity_framewor.description: The term 'structural-object (Unity framework)' refers to a modeling style utilized in the development of the BCI Ontology, which integrates structured representations of entities and their relationships within the context of the Unity framework for enhanced human-computer interaction in Brain-Computer Interfaces.

Entity-specification.label: specifications
Entity-specification.description: The term 'specifications' refers to the detailed technical requirements and characteristics of devices used in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), particularly concerning their channeling schema.

Entity-dulsan_alignment.label: DUL/SAN alignments
Entity-dulsan_alignment.description: DUL/SAN alignments refer to the integration and equivalence relations established between the DUL (Dynamic Upper Level) ontology and the SAN (Semantic Sensor Network) ontology within the context of the BCI Ontology to ensure semantic consistency and interoperability in brain-computer interaction systems.

Entity-it_correspondent_functional_aspec.label: its correspondent functional aspect
Entity-it_correspondent_functional_aspec.description: The term 'its correspondent functional aspect' refers to the specific functional characteristics and roles of each module within the BCI Ontology that contribute to the overall understanding and implementation of the Brain-Computer Interaction model.

Entity-description_(1).label: description
Entity-description_(1).description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'description' refers to the detailed characterization and contextual information associated with entities defined within the ontology, which is extended and complemented by external resources.

Entity-these_annotation.label: these annotations
Entity-these_annotation.description: These annotations refer to web-oriented representations included in the BCI-O specifications that facilitate the reuse and sharing of ontological concepts and their descriptions, incorporating terms from established vocabularies like Dublin Core and SKOS.

Entity-format.label: formats
Entity-format.description: In the context of the BCI domain, 'formats' refers to the semi-structured standard vocabularies and data formats used for annotating and documenting multimodal brain-computer interaction data, such as Extensible Data Format (XDF) and EEG Study Schema (ESS).

Entity-specific_response.label: specific responses
Entity-specific_response.description: Specific responses refer to the actions or outputs generated by Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) in reaction to the analysis of a user's neuro-physiological signals, such as controlling a wheelchair or mitigating drowsiness.

Entity-the_relevant_component_architectu.label: the relevant component architecture
Entity-the_relevant_component_architectu.description: The relevant component architecture refers to the structured framework that outlines the high-level concepts and relationships necessary for understanding and modeling the interaction between Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) and their physical or virtual environments.

Entity-interpretation_aspect.label: interpretation aspects
Entity-interpretation_aspect.description: Interpretation aspects refer to the components involved in understanding and analyzing the contextual input data and events related to a single observation within the BCI-O framework.

Entity-relationship.label: relationships
Entity-relationship.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'relationships' refer to the connections and associations between entities within an environment, as modeled by Unity's architectural framework, which encompasses structural, behavioral, and temporal perspectives.

Entity-three_version.label: three versions
Entity-three_version.description: The term 'three versions' refers to the distinct iterations of the BCI-O specifications, which include the Base Version, the HTML Version, and the OWL 2 RDF/XML Version, each designed for different purposes and formats in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction ontology development.

Entity-related_concept.label: related concepts
Entity-related_concept.description: The term 'related concepts' refers to additional design considerations and entities that complement the Annotation Tag module within the BCI interaction model, aimed at enhancing the understanding and representation of brain-computer interaction dynamics.

Entity-aae_odp.label: AAE ODP
Entity-aae_odp.description: AAE ODP refers to the Actuation-Actuator-Effect ontology design pattern, which serves as a structural framework for modeling actuation processes in the context of the BCI Ontology, aligning with the Semantic Sensor Network and Semantic Actuator Network ontologies.

Entity-unity_dictionary.label: Unity dictionary
Entity-unity_dictionary.description: The Unity dictionary refers to a non-ontological resource application that provides structured metadata and vocabulary for the context domain within the framework of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-individual.label: individuals
Entity-individual.description: The term 'individuals' refers to distinct users or subjects whose neuro-physiological features are analyzed in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) to identify and deduce correlated cognitive states.

Entity-procedure_concept_extension.label: procedure concept extension
Entity-procedure_concept_extension.description: The procedure concept extension refers to the framework within the BCI Ontology that allows applications to define and manage the semantic expressiveness of measurement units in the context of brain-computer interaction.

Entity-vast_data_recording_collection.label: vast data recording collections
Entity-vast_data_recording_collection.description: Vast data recording collections refer to extensive datasets generated from various brain-computer interaction activities, which are utilized for semantic analysis and adaptive learning in BCI systems.

Entity-annotation_property.label: annotation properties
Entity-annotation_property.description: Annotation properties refer to metadata terms derived from established vocabularies that enhance the descriptive capabilities of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) by providing structured annotations for BCI concepts, facilitating semantic interoperability and data sharing.

Entity-team.label: teams
Entity-team.description: The mention 'teams' refers to collaborative groups of researchers and developers involved in the expansion of metadata for Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) experiments, specifically within the context of a project under the Cognition and Neuroergonomics Collaborative Technology Alliance (CaN-CTA) program.

Entity-description.label: descriptions
Entity-description.description: The term 'descriptions' refers to the annotations included in the BCI Ontology that provide well-known web-oriented representations for reusing and sharing ontological concepts.

Entity-bci-o_spec_s_html_version.label: BCI-O spec's HTML version
Entity-bci-o_spec_s_html_version.description: The BCI-O spec's HTML version is a digital document that outlines the BCI Ontology's applications, including the CerebraTek vPod Ontology for glaucoma diagnostics and the ESS+HED Standards Ontology, along with their corresponding RDF graph models.

Entity-brain-computer_interaction.label: Brain-Computer Interaction
Entity-brain-computer_interaction.description: Brain-Computer Interaction refers to the interdisciplinary field that focuses on the direct communication pathways between the brain and external devices, enabling users to control technology through neural activity.

Entity-functional_aspect.label: functional aspect
Entity-functional_aspect.description: The term 'functional aspect' refers to the specific characteristics or features of each module within the BCI Ontology that explain their roles and contributions to the overall Brain-Computer Interaction model.

Entity-hed_2.label: HED 2
Entity-hed_2.description: HED 2 refers to a specific version of the Hierarchical Event Descriptor, a metadata vocabulary developed to specify neuro-physiological events in Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) research, which has syntax characteristics similar to the RDF format.

Entity-setting.label: settings
Entity-setting.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'settings' refers to the specific conditions and environmental factors that define the context in which a subject interacts while performing a single activity.

Entity-hierarchical_event_descriptor.label: Hierarchical Event Descriptor
Entity-hierarchical_event_descriptor.description: The Hierarchical Event Descriptor (HED) is a metadata vocabulary developed to specify and categorize neuro-physiological events in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-actuation_result.label: actuation results
Entity-actuation_result.description: Actuation results refer to the specific data blocks and recorded data that capture the outcomes of actions performed by a subject within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction, as defined in the BCI Ontology.

Entity-indexing.label: indexing
Entity-indexing.description: Indexing refers to the process of organizing and accessing external resources and raw data through URI locators in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-eventsituation_based_data_logging.label: event/situation based data logging
Entity-eventsituation_based_data_logging.description: Event/situation based data logging refers to a data collection method that utilizes the Stimulus-Sensor-Observation (SSO) ontology design pattern to systematically record and annotate observations related to specific events or situations, facilitating semantic interoperability and integration in contexts such as Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-the_paper.label: the paper
Entity-the_paper.description: The paper refers to a document discussing the application of the BCI Ontology in the context of Neuromonitoring VR/AR Goggle technology.

Entity-actuation-actuator-effect_odp.label: Actuation-Actuator-Effect ODP
Entity-actuation-actuator-effect_odp.description: The Actuation-Actuator-Effect ODP is an ontology design pattern that defines the relationships and interactions between actuators, the actuation process, and the resulting effects in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-two_distinct_conceptual_domain.label: Two distinct conceptual domains
Entity-two_distinct_conceptual_domain.description: The term 'Two distinct conceptual domains' refers to the separation between the BCI domain, which encompasses observations, actuation, and interactions related to brain-computer interactions, and the context domain, which pertains to the surrounding environment and is modeled based on the Unity framework.

Entity-scene.label: scenes
Entity-scene.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'scenes' refer to conceptual representations that illustrate a sequence of spatially located entities and their interactions within a physical or virtual environment.

Entity-axiomatization_satisfiability.label: axiomatization satisfiability
Entity-axiomatization_satisfiability.description: Axiomatization satisfiability refers to the property of ensuring that the axiomatizations within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) are logically consistent and can be effectively aligned with the Semantic Actuator Network (SAN) framework in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-it_modeling.label: Its modeling
Entity-it_modeling.description: Its modeling refers to the conceptual framework that represents a sequence of scenes illustrating the interactions of spatially located entities within a specific environment, as part of the BCI Ontology's context module.

Entity-state.label: state
Entity-state.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'state' refers to the condition or status of a human subject engaged in an activity, encompassing their attributes and interactions within the BCI framework.

Entity-result_of_an_actuation.label: result of an actuation
Entity-result_of_an_actuation.description: The 'result of an actuation' refers to the effect observed in the context following an action performed by a subject within the Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) framework, as defined by the BCI Ontology.

Entity-annotation_tag.label: Annotation Tag
Entity-annotation_tag.description: Annotation Tag refers to event markers that denote context stimuli and response markers derived from machine learning models, used for annotating specific segments of data in the BCI Ontology.

Entity-fatigue.label: fatigue
Entity-fatigue.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), 'fatigue' refers to a cognitive state that can be characterized through the analysis of neuro-physiological signals, indicating a decrease in mental alertness and performance.

Entity-common_concept.label: Common concepts
Entity-common_concept.description: Common concepts refer to fundamental and general representations, such as time intervals, that are defined as datatype properties within the BCI Ontology to facilitate the modeling of Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-subject.label: subject
Entity-subject.description: The term 'subject' refers to a human participant from whom multimodal data is collected in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-it_associated_state.label: its associated state
Entity-it_associated_state.description: The term 'its associated state' refers to the specific condition or attributes of a human subject that are relevant to their engagement in an activity within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI).

Entity-their_description.label: their descriptions
Entity-their_description.description: The term 'their descriptions' refers to the annotations that provide minimal semantic commitment and are designed to reuse and share ontological concepts within the BCI-O specifications.

Entity-modeling.label: modeling
Entity-modeling.description: The term 'modeling' refers to the process of creating a structured representation of a sequence of scenes that illustrate the interactions among spatially located entities within a specific context in the BCI Ontology framework.

Entity-context_domain_concept.label: context domain concepts
Entity-context_domain_concept.description: The context domain concepts refer to the theoretical and conceptual elements derived from the gaming architectural modeling of the Unity framework, which are utilized to describe the environmental aspects relevant to Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-modeling_process.label: modeling process
Entity-modeling_process.description: The 'modeling process' refers to the systematic approach used to develop and refine the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) by generalizing and expanding its initial proto-ontology based on project specifications and software engineering tasks.

Entity-key_concept.label: key concepts
Entity-key_concept.description: The term 'key concepts' refers to the fundamental ideas and constructs that form the basis of the BCI-O's Sense Model, which were initially developed in alignment with the Stimulus-Sensor-Observation (SSO) design pattern and subsequently adapted to integrate with other ontological frameworks.

Entity-design_rule.label: design rules
Entity-design_rule.description: Design rules refer to the guidelines and principles established during the development of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) to ensure the effective categorization and representation of BCI metadata terms, facilitating semantic search and maintaining a coherent structure aligned with existing BCI vocabularies and ontologies.

Entity-the_core_concept_of_the_unity_wor.label: the core concepts of the UNITY world model
aliases: the core concepts of the UNITY world model
Entity-the_core_concept_of_the_unity_wor.description: The core concepts of the UNITY world model refer to foundational principles and frameworks used in game development that facilitate the integration of context and human-environment interactions, which have been adapted to enhance the BCI Ontology for Brain-Computer Interaction.

mentions.local_name: the core concepts of the UNITY world model

Entity-esshed_standard_ontology.label: ESS+HED Standards Ontology
aliases: the ESS+HED Standards Ontology for BCI-O
Entity-esshed_standard_ontology.description: The ESS+HED Standards Ontology is an ontological framework designed to enhance the ESS v2.0 and HED v2.0 EEG data sharing tools by providing a structured semantic overlay for BCI-O applications.

mentions.local_name: the ESS+HED Standards Ontology for BCI-O

Entity-horizontal_segmentation_module.label: horizontal segmentation module
Entity-horizontal_segmentation_module.description: The horizontal segmentation module refers to a component within the BCI-O framework that organizes and defines the logical structure of data related to system capabilities in Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-data_block.label: data blocks
Entity-data_block.description: Data blocks refer to structured units of information that encapsulate recorded data and actuation results within the BCI-O framework, facilitating the organization and analysis of data in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-subject-independent_feature.label: subject-independent features
Entity-subject-independent_feature.description: Subject-independent features refer to the modeling approach within the BCI-O framework that enables the representation of data characteristics that are not influenced by individual subject variations, thereby providing a consistent conceptual dimensionality for analyzing brain-computer interaction data.

Entity-datatype_property.label: datatype properties
Entity-datatype_property.description: Datatype properties refer to specific types of properties in ontologies that are used to define and represent data values, such as time intervals, in a structured manner to facilitate the modeling of systems like Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI).

Entity-the_relevant_figure.label: the relevant figure
Entity-the_relevant_figure.description: The relevant figure refers to a visual representation that illustrates the bidirectional subject-context interaction model in the BCI-O ontology, specifically showing the Sense Model and Actuation Model components.

Entity-simplicity.label: simplicity
Entity-simplicity.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'simplicity' refers to a design objective aimed at creating a straightforward and easily understandable framework for BCI data capture activities, facilitating interoperability and usability.

Entity-non-ontological_resource_applicat.label: Non-ontological resource applications
Entity-non-ontological_resource_applicat.description: Non-ontological resource applications refer to specific domains of resources utilized in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction, including the Unity dictionary for context, the MPEG-7 MDS glossary for video coding, and the OWL-Time glossary for time representation.

Entity-preliminary_classification.label: preliminary classification
Entity-preliminary_classification.description: The term 'preliminary classification' refers to the initial processing step in analyzing neuro-physiological signals and data sets, where existing machine learning algorithms are applied to categorize the data for further analysis in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI).

Entity-effect.label: effect
Entity-effect.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'effect' refers to the outcome or result that occurs in response to an actuation performed by a subject during an activity, as part of the event classification that integrates with Sense and Actuation Models.

Entity-domain_level_concept_(1).label: domain level concepts
Entity-domain_level_concept_(1).description: Domain level concepts refer to the specialized abstractions within the BCI Ontology's Sense Model that are derived from the Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) Skeleton module and aligned with the Dolce-Ultralite (DUL) framework, facilitating the semantic representation of sensor-related data in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-ontology_authoring_and_quality.label: Ontology authoring and quality
Entity-ontology_authoring_and_quality.description: Ontology authoring and quality refers to the processes and best practices involved in the creation and evaluation of ontologies, specifically in the context of developing the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) to ensure its structure, documentation, and overall effectiveness in representing BCI metadata.

Entity-observation-based_data.label: observation-based data
Entity-observation-based_data.description: Observation-based data refers to data that is generated from observations made by sensors in various contexts, particularly in the realm of Brain-Computer Interaction, and is structured to support semantic interoperability and integration within observation-related ontologies on the Semantic Web.

Entity-ssn__stimulus.label: ssn:Stimulus
Entity-ssn__stimulus.description: ssn:Stimulus refers to a detectable change in the environment that triggers sensors to perform observations, serving as a key component in the Semantic Sensor Network ontology for modeling events in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-figure.label: Figures
Entity-figure.description: Figures refer to visual representations that illustrate the alignment perspectives of the BCI-O's Actuation Model with the SOSA/SSN and SAN (IoT-O) frameworks, as defined by the AAE ontology design pattern.

Entity-ontological_resource_reuse.label: ontological resource reuse
Entity-ontological_resource_reuse.description: Ontological resource reuse refers to the practice of leveraging existing ontologies, such as SOSA/SSN, SAN (IoT-O), DUL, and dbpedia, to enhance the semantic structure and interoperability of the BCI Ontology by integrating established concepts and relationships.

Entity-computing_interface.label: computing interfaces
Entity-computing_interface.description: Computing interfaces refer to the technological systems and frameworks that facilitate the interaction between human bio-signals and computational devices, enabling the monitoring and processing of various physiological data.

Entity-the_domain_level_concept_of_the_a.label: the domain level concepts of the Actuation Model
aliases: the domain level concepts of the Actuation Model
Entity-the_domain_level_concept_of_the_a.description: The domain level concepts of the Actuation Model refer to the foundational elements and relationships within the Actuation Model of the BCI Ontology, specifically focusing on the concepts of Actuation, Actuator, and Effect, which are aligned with the SOSA/SSN framework and the Actuation-Actuator-Effect ontology design pattern.

mentions.local_name: the domain level concepts of the Actuation Model

Entity-comparable_feature_among_differen.label: comparable features among different users
Entity-comparable_feature_among_differen.description: Comparable features among different users refer to the shared characteristics or attributes of neuro-physiological signals that can be analyzed and compared across different individuals to enhance the performance and accuracy of Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems.

Entity-literature.label: literature
Entity-literature.description: In this context, 'literature' refers to the body of scholarly work and research materials related to Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) that inform the understanding of contextual concepts within Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI).

Entity-stimulus_to_the_subject.label: stimulus to the subject
Entity-stimulus_to_the_subject.description: The 'stimulus to the subject' refers to an event or input that triggers a response or action from a human subject within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction, as defined in the BCI Ontology.

Entity-an_action_issued_by_a_subject_whi.label: an action issued by a subject while performing an activity
aliases: an action issued by a subject while performing an activity
Entity-an_action_issued_by_a_subject_whi.description: An action issued by a subject while performing an activity refers to a specific behavior or movement executed by an individual in the context of their interaction with an environment, which is essential for understanding the dynamics of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

mentions.local_name: an action issued by a subject while performing an activity

Entity-iot-o.label: IoT-O
Entity-iot-o.description: IoT-O refers to the ontology designed for the Internet of Things, which provides a formal semantic structure to facilitate the integration and interoperability of IoT devices and systems.

Entity-spatially_located_entity.label: spatially located entities
Entity-spatially_located_entity.description: Spatially located entities refer to the conceptual components within the BCI Ontology that represent distinct objects or components situated in a physical or virtual environment, which interact with each other in defined ways during the modeling of scenes.

Entity-relevant_data_set.label: relevant data sets
Entity-relevant_data_set.description: The term 'relevant data sets' refers to specific collections of BCI data that are utilized for the personalized calibration of machine learning models, enhancing their performance and accuracy in brain-computer interaction applications.

Entity-san_ontology.label: SAN Ontologies
Entity-san_ontology.description: SAN Ontologies refer to the Semantic Actuator Network, which serves as an upper ontology for the Internet of Things (IoT) that is built around the Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) ontology design pattern, facilitating the integration and standardization of actuation models in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-extension_to_the_sosassn_w3c_reco.label: extensions to the SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation
aliases: extensions to the SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation
Entity-extension_to_the_sosassn_w3c_reco.description: The term 'extensions to the SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation' refers to proposed enhancements and modifications to the existing W3C standards for the Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) and Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) ontologies, aimed at improving their applicability and integration within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) and related fields.

mentions.local_name: extensions to the SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation

Entity-section_4.label: section 4
Entity-section_4.description: Section 4 refers to the part of the paper that describes the design principle underlying the bidirectional subject-context interaction model in the BCI Ontology.

Entity-two_fundamental_and_general_repre.label: Two fundamental and general representational aspects
aliases: Two fundamental and general representational aspects
Entity-two_fundamental_and_general_repre.description: The term 'Two fundamental and general representational aspects' refers to the core components of domain modeling in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), specifically focusing on the representation of BCI systems and the physical or virtual environments in which they operate.

mentions.local_name: Two fundamental and general representational aspects

Entity-our_feedback.label: our feedback
Entity-our_feedback.description: Our feedback refers to the insights and evaluations provided by the authors of the BCI Ontology regarding new proposed concepts and relationships in the context of ongoing discussions related to the SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation.

Entity-mapping_of_sosassn_to_aae_odp.label: mapping of SOSA/SSN to AAE ODP
aliases: mapping of SOSA/SSN to AAE ODP
Entity-mapping_of_sosassn_to_aae_odp.description: The mapping of SOSA/SSN to AAE ODP refers to the process of aligning the structural elements of the Semantic Sensor Network (SOSA/SSN) ontology with the Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) ontology design pattern to enhance interoperability and integration within the Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) Ontology.

mentions.local_name: mapping of SOSA/SSN to AAE ODP

Entity-query_projection.label: Query Projection
Entity-query_projection.description: Query Projection refers to the process of selecting and organizing raw data sets and their corresponding data segments that are utilized as input for a transfer learning target model in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-nctu__pet_lab_.label: NCTU (PET Lab)
Entity-nctu__pet_lab_.description: NCTU (PET Lab) refers to the PET Laboratory at National Chiao Tung University, which collaborates on research projects related to brain-computer interaction and the development of ontologies for BCI data.

Entity-online_multimodal_eeg_classificat.label: online multimodal EEG classification
Entity-online_multimodal_eeg_classificat.description: Online multimodal EEG classification refers to the process of using various data modalities, including electroencephalogram (EEG) signals, to classify brain states or cognitive tasks in real-time within brain-computer interface systems.

Entity-physical_or_virtual_environment.label: physical or virtual environment
Entity-physical_or_virtual_environment.description: The term 'physical or virtual environment' refers to the architectural framework that encompasses both tangible, real-world settings and digital, simulated spaces where interactions occur, particularly in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-documentation.label: documentation
Entity-documentation.description: The term 'documentation' refers to the structured guidelines and best practices derived from the SSN and IoT-O specifications that were utilized to inform the development and organization of the BCI Ontology.

Entity-three_key_concept.label: three key concepts
