Entity-three_key_concept.description: The term 'three key concepts' refers to the essential elements defined in the BCI Ontology that integrate contextual information with Sense and Actuation Models, specifically: a stimulus to the subject, an action performed by the subject, and the resulting effect in the context from the actuation.

Entity-pet_lab.label: PET Lab
Entity-pet_lab.description: PET Lab refers to the research laboratory at National Chiao Tung University (NCTU) involved in the development of the BCI-O proto-ontology for Brain-Computer Interaction projects.

Entity-other_framework.label: other frameworks
Entity-other_framework.description: The term 'other frameworks' refers to alternative ontological structures or models that BCI-O's Sense Model concepts were adapted to after their initial alignment with the Stimulus-Sensor-Observation (SSO) design pattern.

Entity-attribute.label: attributes
Entity-attribute.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'attributes' refer to the specific characteristics or properties that define a person engaging in an activity, analogous to the concept of 'Patient' in the HL7 standard.

Entity-participation_foundational_design.label: participation foundational design pattern
Entity-participation_foundational_design.description: The participation foundational design pattern is a conceptual framework that illustrates the hierarchical relationship between objects, sensors, and devices within the context of the BCI Ontology, specifically mapping dul:Object to sosa:Sensor and subsequently to bci:Device.

Entity-semantic_expressiveness_level.label: semantic expressiveness level
Entity-semantic_expressiveness_level.description: The 'semantic expressiveness level' refers to the degree to which applications can represent and manipulate measurement units and procedural concepts within the BCI Ontology framework.

Entity-tool.label: tools
Entity-tool.description: The term 'tools' refers to software and infrastructure developed for training and personalizing machine learning models, specifically designed to handle semi-structured and non-interoperable metadata formats in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-ssn.label: SSN
Entity-ssn.description: SSN refers to the Semantic Sensor Network, a standard framework ontology that facilitates the integration and interoperability of sensor data within the Internet of Things and the Internet of Services, particularly in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-semantic_sensor_network.label: Semantic Sensor Network
Entity-semantic_sensor_network.description: The Semantic Sensor Network is a standard framework ontology designed to facilitate the integration and interoperability of sensor data and related observations in various domains.

Entity-instant.label: instant
Entity-instant.description: The term 'instant' refers to a specific point in time as defined in the W3C OWL-Time ontology, which is utilized in the context of the BCI Ontology to model temporal entities.

Entity-these_tool.label: These tools
Entity-these_tool.description: These tools refer to the ESS v2.0 and HED v2.0 EEG data sharing tools that serve as an ontological overlay for the BCI-O, designed to facilitate the training and personalization of machine learning models using complex metadata formats.

Entity-san_upper_ontology.label: SAN upper ontologies
Entity-san_upper_ontology.description: SAN upper ontologies refer to a set of upper ontologies that provide a foundational framework for modeling and integrating various semantic structures, specifically in the context of the BCI Ontology's Actuation Model.

Entity-content.label: content
Entity-content.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'content' refers to the complete modeling structure and data encapsulated within the Base Version of the OWL 2 RDF/XML document.

Entity-category.label: categories
Entity-category.description: In the context of the BCI-O proto-ontology, 'categories' refers to the classifications used to organize and restrict observations based on attributes related to sessions, subjects, and records in the analysis of EEG recordings for applications such as glaucoma detection.

Entity-machine-launched_semantic_search.label: machine-launched semantic search
Entity-machine-launched_semantic_search.description: Machine-launched semantic search refers to an automated information retrieval process that utilizes semantic technologies to enhance the annotation and querying of brain-computer interaction (BCI) data, enabling more effective data analytics and inference in BCI systems.

Entity-core_layer.label: core layer
Entity-core_layer.description: The 'core layer' refers to a structural component of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) that integrates the SOSA/SSN and SAN ontologies, serving as a central framework for the ontology's design and functionality.

Entity-a_natural_design_structure.label: a natural design structure
Entity-a_natural_design_structure.description: A natural design structure refers to a generic and reusable framework or pattern that facilitates the organization and representation of data and interactions within the BCI-O's Sense Model, enabling effective observation-related ontologies and observation-based data on the Semantic Web.

Entity-relevant_abstraction.label: relevant abstractions
Entity-relevant_abstraction.description: Relevant abstractions refer to the conceptual components derived from the Unity framework's gaming architectural modeling, which are utilized in the BCI-O's Context Model to define the structural, functional, and temporal complexities of environments in Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-action_issued_by_a_subject.label: action issued by a subject
Entity-action_issued_by_a_subject.description: The phrase 'action issued by a subject' refers to a specific type of event in the BCI Ontology that describes the actions performed by a human subject during an activity, which are integral to understanding the interaction between the subject and their environment in the context of brain-computer interactions.

Entity-electroencephalogram__eeg_.label: electroencephalogram (EEG)
Entity-electroencephalogram__eeg_.description: An electroencephalogram (EEG) is a physiological signal that records electrical activity in the brain, used in Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) to analyze brain states and facilitate interaction with electronic systems.

Entity-logical_component.label: logical components
Entity-logical_component.description: Logical components refer to the essential elements of a channeling schema's data structure model that define how data is organized and measured within the BCI Ontology framework.

Entity-log.label: log
Entity-log.description: In the context of the ontology engineering process for the BCI Ontology, the term 'log' refers to a detailed record that documents the results and durations of each satisfiability checkpoint during the development and validation of the ontology.

Entity-two_set_of_metadata_vocabulary.label: two sets of metadata vocabulary
Entity-two_set_of_metadata_vocabulary.description: The term 'two sets of metadata vocabulary' refers to the EEG Study Schema (ESS) and the Hierarchical Event Descriptor (HED), which are developed to describe the settings of neuro-physiological recordings and the specifications of neuro-physiological events in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI).

Entity-the_internet.label: the Internet
Entity-the_internet.description: The Internet refers to the global network of interconnected computers and devices that communicate using standardized protocols, enabling the exchange of data and services, and is integral to the functioning of various technologies, including Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) and the Internet of Things (IoT).

Entity-recorded_data_a_sensor_output_str.label: recorded data as sensor output streams
aliases: recorded data as sensor output streams
Entity-recorded_data_a_sensor_output_str.description: Recorded data as sensor output streams refers to the continuous flow of data generated by sensors that capture observations and events related to a subject's interactions within a specific context, which are essential for analyzing brain states in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

mentions.local_name: recorded data as sensor output streams

Entity-major_player.label: major players
Entity-major_player.description: In the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI), 'major players' refers to the key entities and components involved in the interaction model, which are identified and characterized based on Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) principles and relevant BCI vocabularies.

Entity-a_semantic_query.label: A semantic query
Entity-a_semantic_query.description: A semantic query refers to a structured request that facilitates the selection and retrieval of specific data sets and segments from BCI metadata, enabling transfer learning operations between machine learning models based on categorized observations.

Entity-descriptor.label: Descriptor
Entity-descriptor.description: The Descriptor is an external resource set that enhances and complements the descriptions of relevant entities within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O).

Entity-axiomatization_model.label: axiomatization models
Entity-axiomatization_model.description: Axiomatization models refer to standardized frameworks developed by W3C/OGC and IoT communities that provide formal structures for defining and implementing actuations within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-their_correspondent_rdf_graph_mod.label: their correspondent RDF graph model
Entity-their_correspondent_rdf_graph_mod.description: The term 'their correspondent RDF graph model' refers to the specific RDF graph representations associated with the BCI-O ontology, exemplified by the CerebraTek vPod Ontology for glaucoma diagnostics and the ESS+HED Standards Ontology, which serve as structured frameworks for semantic data sharing and processing in Brain-Computer Interaction applications.

Entity-the_observation.label: the observations
Entity-the_observation.description: The observations refer to the categorized EEG recordings and data segments that have been analyzed and classified based on their relevance to glaucoma detection stages in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) applications.

Entity-category_on_session__subject__and.label: categories on sessions, subjects, and records
aliases: categories on sessions, subjects, and records
Entity-category_on_session__subject__and.description: The term 'categories on sessions, subjects, and records' refers to the attribute-based classifications used in the BCI-O framework to organize and restrict data observations based on the specific sessions of EEG recordings, the individual subjects involved in the study, and the distinct records generated during the data collection process.

mentions.local_name: categories on sessions, subjects, and records

Entity-abstraction.label: abstraction
Entity-abstraction.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'abstraction' refers to the conceptual level that allows for the definition of structural, functional, and temporal complexities of environments, facilitating a simplified representation of complex systems.

Entity-modeling_structure.label: modeling structure
Entity-modeling_structure.description: The 'modeling structure' refers to the comprehensive framework and content defined in the Base Version of the BCI Ontology, which is represented as an OWL 2 RDF/XML document that includes all necessary specifications for the ontology's design and implementation.

Entity-observation-related_ontology.label: observation-related ontologies
Entity-observation-related_ontology.description: Observation-related ontologies refer to a category of ontologies designed to facilitate the representation and organization of data concerning observations, particularly in the context of event and situation-based data logging on the Semantic Web.

Entity-one_session.label: one session
Entity-one_session.description: In the context of the BCI-O framework, 'one session' refers to a single instance of data collection for a subject, during which two EEG recordings are obtained, one for each eye, to facilitate the analysis of brain signals related to glaucoma detection.

Entity-sequence_of_scene.label: sequence of scenes
Entity-sequence_of_scene.description: The 'sequence of scenes' refers to a structured representation of a series of spatially located entities within a physical or virtual environment, illustrating their interactions and relationships in a specific context as part of the BCI Ontology's modeling framework.

Entity-dul__situation.label: dul:Situation
Entity-dul__situation.description: The entity 'dul:Situation' refers to a spatial-temporal context within the BCI Ontology that can be associated with specific instances such as a BCI session, context, or scene.

Entity-major_player_and_flow.label: major players and flows
Entity-major_player_and_flow.description: The term 'major players and flows' refers to the key entities and their interactions within the Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) model, which are identified and characterized based on Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) principles and formalized using established BCI vocabularies.

Entity-this_module.label: this module
Entity-this_module.description: This module refers to the Results module within the BCI Ontology, which encompasses data blocks and recorded data, including actuation results.

Entity-four_important_section.label: four important sections
Entity-four_important_section.description: The term 'four important sections' refers to the distinct components of a semantic query used in the BCI-O framework, which include Semantic Matching, Query Restriction, Model Selector for the Data, and Query Projection, each serving a specific role in the transfer learning operation for BCI applications.

Entity-text-handling_rule.label: text-handling rules
Entity-text-handling_rule.description: The 'text-handling rules' refer to the specific guidelines and protocols embedded within the Base Version of the BCI Ontology that dictate how text formatting and transformation should be managed in the context of the ontology's modeling structure and content.

Entity-response_marker.label: response markers
Entity-response_marker.description: Response markers are annotations derived from machine learning models that identify and classify specific data segments in Brain-Computer Interaction systems, reflecting the predictive features of the data.

Entity-level_of_confidence.label: level of confidence
Entity-level_of_confidence.description: The 'level of confidence' refers to a measure of certainty or reliability associated with the personalized calibration of models in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems, indicating how confidently the models can make predictions based on the relevant data sets.

Entity-human-computer_interaction.label: Human-Computer Interaction
Entity-human-computer_interaction.description: Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) is a multidisciplinary field that studies the design and use of computer technology, focusing particularly on the interfaces between people (users) and computers.

Entity-note_documentation_property.label: notes documentation properties
Entity-note_documentation_property.description: The 'notes documentation properties' refer to specific annotations within the BCI Ontology that provide structured information about the definitions, scope, editorial comments, and changes related to each concept, enhancing the clarity and usability of the ontology.

Entity-neuro-physiological_event.label: neuro-physiological events
Entity-neuro-physiological_event.description: Neuro-physiological events refer to the specific occurrences or phenomena related to the physiological signals generated by the nervous system, which are recorded and analyzed in the context of brain-computer interaction to understand cognitive states and behaviors.

Entity-physical_modification.label: physical modification
Entity-physical_modification.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'physical modification' refers to the changes in the state of the environment that are induced by an actuator as part of the actuation process.

Entity-existing_ml_algorithm.label: existing ML algorithms
Entity-existing_ml_algorithm.description: Existing ML algorithms refer to the established machine learning techniques utilized for processing neuro-physiological signals and performing feature extraction and classification in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-domain_and_scope_of_concept.label: domain and scope of concepts
Entity-domain_and_scope_of_concept.description: The 'domain and scope of concepts' refers to the defined boundaries and range of meanings for the concepts utilized in the BCI Ontology, ensuring that the model remains simple and stable while effectively categorizing relevant BCI metadata for data annotation and semantic search.

Entity-aae-based_core_alignment.label: AAE-based core alignments
Entity-aae-based_core_alignment.description: AAE-based core alignments refer to the foundational concepts within the BCI Ontology's Actuation Model that define the relationships and roles of Actuation, Actuator, and Effect in the context of changing the state of an environment through actuators.

Entity-sosassn.label: SOSA/SSN
Entity-sosassn.description: SOSA/SSN refers to a set of ontologies developed for the Semantic Sensor Network, providing a framework for modeling sensor data and their interactions in the context of the Internet of Things.

Entity-channeling_schema_information.label: channeling schema information
Entity-channeling_schema_information.description: Channeling schema information refers to the structured representation of data related to the modalities, interpretations, and outputs of observations in Brain-Computer Interaction systems, facilitating the integration and processing of sensor data streams.

Entity-brain_state_prediction_and_classi.label: brain state prediction and classification models
aliases: brain state prediction and classification models
Entity-brain_state_prediction_and_classi.description: Brain state prediction and classification models are computational frameworks used to analyze and interpret brain activity data in order to predict and categorize different mental states or cognitive processes.

mentions.local_name: brain state prediction and classification models

Entity-modality.label: modality
Entity-modality.description: In the context of EEG applications, 'modality' refers to the specific subtype of EEG data that characterizes the type of measurement or signal being recorded, such as different channels or devices used in brain-computer interaction.

Entity-brain_signal.label: brain signals
Entity-brain_signal.description: Brain signals refer to the electrical or chemical activity produced by neurons in the brain, which can be measured and analyzed to understand brain function and communication.

Entity-cerebratek_vpod_ontology.label: CerebraTek vPod Ontology
Entity-cerebratek_vpod_ontology.description: The CerebraTek vPod Ontology is an ontology framework specifically designed for glaucoma diagnostics utilizing multi-frequency steady-state visual evoked potentials (mfSSVEP) within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-the_structural__functional__and_t.label: the structural, functional, and temporal complexity definitions
aliases: the structural, functional, and temporal complexity definitions
Entity-the_structural__functional__and_t.description: The structural, functional, and temporal complexity definitions refer to the conceptual frameworks that describe the intricate interactions and relationships among spatially located entities within a physical or virtual environment in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI).

mentions.local_name: the structural, functional, and temporal complexity definitions

Entity-ambient_intelligence.label: ambient intelligence
Entity-ambient_intelligence.description: Ambient intelligence refers to an environment that is sensitive and responsive to the presence of people, utilizing various technologies to enhance user experience and interaction through seamless integration of smart devices and systems.

Entity-eog.label: EOG
Entity-eog.description: EOG refers to the electrooculogram, a physiological signal that measures the electrical potential difference between the front and back of the human eye, used in Brain-Computer Interfaces to analyze user brain states.

Entity-actuation-actuator-effect__aae_.label: Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE)
Entity-actuation-actuator-effect__aae_.description: The Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) refers to an ontology design pattern that structures the relationships between the actuation process, the devices (actuators) that implement these actions, and the resulting effects on the context, serving as a foundational framework for the Actuation Model in the BCI Ontology.

Entity-advanced_computational_approach.label: Advanced Computational Approaches
Entity-advanced_computational_approach.description: Advanced Computational Approaches refers to a research area focused on developing innovative methodologies and technologies, particularly in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction, to enhance the analysis and understanding of neuro-physiological signals and cognitive states.

Entity-certain_attribute.label: certain attributes
Entity-certain_attribute.description: In the context of the BCI Ontology, 'certain attributes' refer to the specific characteristics or properties that define a person engaging in an activity, analogous to the concept of 'Patient' in the HL7 standard.

Entity-actuation-actuator-effect__aae__o.label: Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) ontology design pattern
Entity-actuation-actuator-effect__aae__o.description: The Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) ontology design pattern is a conceptual framework used in the Semantic Actuator Network (SAN) to model the relationships and interactions between actuations, the devices that perform them (actuators), and the resulting changes in the environment (effects) within the context of Internet of Things (IoT) applications.

Entity-semantic_actuator_network.label: Semantic Actuator Network
Entity-semantic_actuator_network.description: The Semantic Actuator Network (SAN) is an upper ontology proposed for the Internet of Things (IoT) that provides a conceptual framework for understanding the relationships between actuations, actuators, and their effects.

Entity-feature.label: features
Entity-feature.description: The term 'features' refers to the extracted characteristics or attributes from neuro-physiological signals that are analyzed to deduce correlations among different individuals' cognitive states in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-vann.label: VANN
Entity-vann.description: VANN is a vocabulary designed for annotating vocabulary descriptions, which is utilized in the development of the BCI Ontology to enhance metadata concepts.

Entity-the_literature.label: the literature
Entity-the_literature.description: In this context, 'the literature' refers to the body of existing scholarly work and research that discusses high-level concepts and relationships relevant to the architecture of environments for Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI).

Entity-brain_dynamic.label: brain dynamics
Entity-brain_dynamic.description: Brain dynamics refers to the patterns of activity and interactions within the brain's neural networks, encompassing the temporal and spatial changes in brain states during various cognitive and physiological processes.

Entity-w3c_owl-time.label: W3C OWL-Time
Entity-w3c_owl-time.description: W3C OWL-Time is an ontology standard developed by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) that provides a framework for representing temporal information in web applications.

Entity-organ.label: organs
Entity-organ.description: In the context of the paper, 'organs' refers to the various biological structures within the human body, specifically including the brain, heart, and liver, that are relevant for monitoring bio-signals in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-owl_2_ql.label: OWL 2 QL
Entity-owl_2_ql.description: OWL 2 QL is a profile of the OWL 2 ontology language designed for applications that require a balance between expressiveness and computational efficiency, particularly in the context of querying ontologies.

Entity-owl_2.label: OWL 2
Entity-owl_2.description: OWL 2 is a web ontology language that provides a formal structure for representing knowledge and semantics in a machine-readable format, facilitating interoperability and reasoning in semantic web applications.

Entity-quality.label: quality
Entity-quality.description: In the context of the BCI-O specifications, 'quality' refers to the careful consideration and adherence to best practices in the ontology authoring process to ensure the reliability and effectiveness of the ontology's structure and documentation.

Entity-effect_in_the_context.label: effect in the context
aliases: an effect in the context as the result of an actuation
Entity-effect_in_the_context.description: The 'effect in the context' refers to the outcome or result that arises from an actuation performed by a subject within a specific physical or virtual environment, as defined in the BCI Ontology's framework for integrating context with sense and actuation models.

mentions.local_name: an effect in the context as the result of an actuation

Entity-guideline.label: Guidelines
Entity-guideline.description: The term 'Guidelines' refers to the best practices and standards derived from the SSN and IoT-O specifications that were adhered to during the incorporation of annotations into the BCI-O specifications.

Entity-data.label: data
Entity-data.description: The term 'data' refers to the analyzed recorded data segments from EEG recordings, which include attributes defining their probability and correlation for use in brain-computer interaction applications.

Entity-the_syntax_of_hed_2.label: the syntax of HED 2
Entity-the_syntax_of_hed_2.description: The syntax of HED 2 refers to the structured format used in the Hierarchical Event Descriptor (HED) metadata vocabulary, which has evolved to resemble the Resource Description Framework (RDF) format for describing neuro-physiological events in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-timestamps_and_interval.label: timestamps and intervals
Entity-timestamps_and_interval.description: Timestamps and intervals refer to the structured representations of specific points in time and durations, respectively, which can be enhanced semantically in BCI applications through the W3C OWL-Time ontology.

Entity-uniform_human-_and_machine-readab.label: uniform human- and machine-readable interface
Entity-uniform_human-_and_machine-readab.description: The term 'uniform human- and machine-readable interface' refers to a standardized framework of descriptors that facilitates the consistent representation and interpretation of EEG experimental events, enabling both human users and automated systems to access and understand the data effectively.

Entity-probability_and_correlation_(1).label: probabilities and correlations
Entity-probability_and_correlation_(1).description: The term 'probabilities and correlations' refers to the statistical measures that quantify the likelihood of certain outcomes and the degree of relationship between data segments in the context of EEG recordings for Brain-Computer Interaction, specifically used to identify high-correlation segments relevant for transfer learning in machine learning models.

Entity-hed.label: HED
Entity-hed.description: HED refers to the Hierarchical Event Descriptor, a metadata vocabulary developed to specify neuro-physiological events in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction research.

Entity-these_extension.label: these extensions
Entity-these_extension.description: These extensions refer to proposed modifications and enhancements to the SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation that aim to improve the modeling of observations and their relationships, which the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) intends to incorporate once finalized.

Entity-change_note.label: change note
Entity-change_note.description: The 'change note' refers to a specific type of documentation property used in the BCI Ontology to provide structured annotations that explain modifications or updates made to the ontology concepts.

Entity-lack_of_training_data_from_indivi.label: Lack of training data from individual users
aliases: Lack of training data from individual users
Entity-lack_of_training_data_from_indivi.description: The term 'Lack of training data from individual users' refers to the insufficient availability of personalized neuro-physiological data necessary for effectively training Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems, which negatively impacts their accuracy and applicability in real-world scenarios.

mentions.local_name: Lack of training data from individual users

Entity-their_data_segment.label: their data segments
Entity-their_data_segment.description: The term 'their data segments' refers to the specific portions of analyzed EEG recordings that have been categorized and annotated with attributes such as probability and correlation, which are relevant for transfer learning operations in brain-computer interaction applications.

Entity-data_set_and_segment.label: data sets and segments
Entity-data_set_and_segment.description: The term 'data sets and segments' refers to collections of analyzed EEG recordings and their corresponding segments, which are utilized in a semantic query for transfer learning operations between machine learning models in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-modeling_task.label: modeling task
Entity-modeling_task.description: The 'modeling task' refers to the initiative aimed at developing ontological frameworks to capture and represent various bio-signal markers and their interactions with technological interfaces across different human body organs and systems.

Entity-all_the_result.label: all the results
Entity-all_the_result.description: The term 'all the results' refers to the comprehensive log of outcomes and durations recorded during the satisfiability checkpoints in the ontology engineering process of the BCI Ontology.

Entity-interpersonal_feature.label: interpersonal features
Entity-interpersonal_feature.description: Interpersonal features refer to the characteristics and attributes derived from the neuro-physiological signals of different individuals that are relevant for understanding and analyzing their cognitive states in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-the_relation_among_the_extracted_.label: the relations among the extracted features from different individuals
aliases: the relations among the extracted features from different individuals
Entity-the_relation_among_the_extracted_.description: The relations among the extracted features from different individuals refer to the connections and correlations identified through semantic search between the neuro-physiological characteristics derived from various users, which are essential for enhancing the accuracy and effectiveness of Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

mentions.local_name: the relations among the extracted features from different individuals

Entity-these_conceptual_component_(1).label: These conceptual components
Entity-these_conceptual_component_(1).description: These conceptual components refer to the core abstractions derived from Unity's gaming architectural modeling framework that facilitate the definition of structural, functional, and temporal complexities of environments within the BCI Ontology.

Entity-the_different_version_of_the_spec.label: the different versions of the specifications
aliases: the different versions of the specifications
Entity-the_different_version_of_the_spec.description: The different versions of the specifications refer to the three distinct formats of the BCI-O ontology documentation, which include the Base Version, the HTML Version, and the OWL 2 RDF/XML Version, each designed for specific purposes and audiences.

mentions.local_name: the different versions of the specifications

Entity-dul__object.label: dul:Object
Entity-dul__object.description: The entity 'dul:Object' refers to a foundational class in the DUL ontology that represents any physical or abstract object within the context of the BCI Ontology, serving as a basis for defining specific sensor and device entities.

Entity-lexical_label.label: lexical labels
Entity-lexical_label.description: Lexical labels refer to the SKOS (Simple Knowledge Organization System) prefLabel properties used in the BCI-O specifications to provide structured documentation and distinguish the content nature of each concept within the ontology.

Entity-dolce-ultralite.label: Dolce-Ultralite
Entity-dolce-ultralite.description: Dolce-Ultralite (DUL) refers to an alignment module that serves as a foundational component for the BCI Ontology's Sense Model, facilitating the integration and semantic interoperability of brain-computer interaction systems within the SOSA/SSN framework.

Entity-eeg_concept.label: EEG concepts
Entity-eeg_concept.description: EEG concepts refer to specific subtypes related to electroencephalography (EEG) applications, encompassing aspects such as channel, device, modality, and record, which are essential for the effective modeling and interoperability of BCI systems.

Entity-web-oriented_representation.label: web-oriented representations
Entity-web-oriented_representation.description: Web-oriented representations refer to annotations that facilitate the reuse and sharing of ontological concepts and their descriptions, characterized by minimal semantic commitment.

Entity-interface.label: interface
Entity-interface.description: The term 'interface' refers to a uniform human- and machine-readable system that facilitates the interaction and communication of data related to EEG experimental events, as defined by the Hierarchical Event Descriptor Tags.

Entity-any_environment_(1).label: any environment
Entity-any_environment_(1).description: The term 'any environment' refers to a conceptual framework that encompasses the structural, functional, and temporal complexities of both real and virtual settings, as modeled in the BCI Ontology's Context Model, which is based on the Unity gaming architecture.

Entity-the_raw_data_set.label: the raw data sets
Entity-the_raw_data_set.description: The raw data sets refer to the analyzed EEG recordings and their corresponding data segments that are utilized as input for the transfer learning target model in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction applications.

Entity-iot-o_specification.label: IoT-O specifications
Entity-iot-o_specification.description: The IoT-O specifications refer to a set of guidelines and best practices for developing ontologies related to the Internet of Things, which are utilized to ensure proper structure and documentation in ontology engineering.

Entity-web-of-things_sensor.label: Web-of-Things sensors
Entity-web-of-things_sensor.description: Web-of-Things sensors are interconnected devices that collect and transmit data over the internet, enabling real-time monitoring and interaction within the Internet of Things ecosystem.

Entity-transfer_learning_operation.label: transfer learning operations
Entity-transfer_learning_operation.description: Transfer learning operations refer to the processes involved in transferring knowledge from one machine learning model to another, specifically in the context of utilizing previously classified data segments to enhance the performance of a more sophisticated model in applications such as Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-orthogonal_conceptual_dimensional.label: orthogonal conceptual dimensionality
Entity-orthogonal_conceptual_dimensional.description: Orthogonal conceptual dimensionality refers to the modeling of subject-independent features in Brain-Computer Interaction systems, allowing for the separation and independent analysis of various conceptual dimensions related to different subjects.

Entity-gaming_architectural_modeling.label: gaming architectural modeling
aliases: the gaming architectural modeling of the Unity framework
Entity-gaming_architectural_modeling.description: Gaming architectural modeling refers to the conceptual framework and design principles used in the Unity framework to create interactive environments and experiences in video games, which serve as a basis for understanding the context domain in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

mentions.local_name: the gaming architectural modeling of the Unity framework

Entity-model_selector.label: Model Selector
Entity-model_selector.description: The Model Selector is an algorithmic component that identifies and organizes annotated data segments based on their probabilities and correlations, facilitating the selection of relevant data for transfer learning in brain-computer interaction applications.

Entity-nctu.label: NCTU
Entity-nctu.description: NCTU refers to the National Chiao-Tung University, an educational institution in Taiwan involved in research on Brain-Computer Interaction and the development of the BCI Ontology.

Entity-the_specification_of_the_neuro-ph.label: the specification of the neuro-physiological events
aliases: the specification of the neuro-physiological events
Entity-the_specification_of_the_neuro-ph.description: The specification of the neuro-physiological events refers to the Hierarchical Event Descriptor (HED), a metadata vocabulary developed to detail the characteristics and classifications of neuro-physiological signals recorded during brain-computer interaction experiments.

mentions.local_name: the specification of the neuro-physiological events

Entity-software_agent__interoperability.label: software agents' interoperability
Entity-software_agent__interoperability.description: Software agents' interoperability refers to the ability of different software agents to communicate, exchange information, and work together effectively within a system, particularly in the context of a machine-readable BCI semantic model that facilitates seamless interaction and data sharing among various BCI systems.

Entity-the_task_of_deducing_the_correlat.label: the task of deducing the correlated interpersonal features
aliases: the task of deducing the correlated interpersonal features
Entity-the_task_of_deducing_the_correlat.description: The task of deducing the correlated interpersonal features refers to the process of identifying and analyzing the relationships among neuro-physiological features extracted from different individuals in order to enhance understanding and classification of cognitive states through semantic search within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction.

mentions.local_name: the task of deducing the correlated interpersonal features

Entity-hed_v2.0.label: HED v2.0
Entity-hed_v2.0.description: HED v2.0 refers to a version of the Hierarchical Event Descriptor, which is an EEG data sharing tool designed to standardize the metadata annotations for brain-computer interaction datasets.

Entity-modeling_artifact.label: modeling artifacts
Entity-modeling_artifact.description: Modeling artifacts refer to the conceptual components and structures derived from the Unity game engine that facilitate the architectural description and organization of entities and their relationships within environments, aiding in the design and implementation of the BCI-O's Context Model.

Entity-some_level_of_confidence.label: some level of confidence
Entity-some_level_of_confidence.description: The term 'some level of confidence' refers to the degree of certainty or reliability associated with the personalized calibration of machine learning models in Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems, indicating how well the models can generalize or perform based on the relevant data sets used.

Entity-channel.label: channel
Entity-channel.description: In the context of EEG applications, 'channel' refers to a subtype that represents a specific pathway for recording brain signals, facilitating the capture and analysis of neural data.

Entity-foundational_layer.label: foundational layer
Entity-foundational_layer.description: The foundational layer refers to the Dolce-Ultralite (DUL) ontology, which serves as the base layer in the three-layered architecture of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) for structuring its metadata and aligning with other ontologies.

Entity-in_a_specific_way.label: in a specific way
Entity-in_a_specific_way.description: The term 'in a specific way' refers to the manner in which spatially located entities interact with each other within the context of the BCI Ontology's modeling framework, emphasizing the structured and defined nature of these interactions.

Entity-it_modeling_artifact.label: its modeling artifacts
Entity-it_modeling_artifact.description: The term 'its modeling artifacts' refers to the conceptual components and structures derived from the Unity game engine that facilitate the architectural description of environments in the BCI Ontology's Context Model.

Entity-ml.label: ML
Entity-ml.description: ML refers to Machine Learning, a technique used to analyze biological signals in Brain-Computer Interfaces to classify brain states based on individual and situational characteristics.

Entity-w3c_semantic_sensor_network.label: W3C Semantic Sensor Network
Entity-w3c_semantic_sensor_network.description: The W3C Semantic Sensor Network is a framework and standard designed to facilitate the integration and interoperability of sensor data on the web.

Entity-high_number_of_channel.label: high numbers of channels
Entity-high_number_of_channel.description: The term 'high numbers of channels' refers to the capability of the Extensible Data Format (XDF) to accommodate and manage data from multiple channels in bio-signal recordings, particularly in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) systems.

Entity-ontology_alignment.label: Ontology Alignments
Entity-ontology_alignment.description: Ontology Alignments refer to the methods and processes used to establish correspondences between different ontologies, facilitating interoperability and data integration in semantic web applications.

Entity-biological_signal.label: biological signals
Entity-biological_signal.description: Biological signals are measurable indicators of physiological or biochemical processes in living organisms, often used in research and analysis to understand health, behavior, or states of biological systems.

Entity-project.label: project
Entity-project.description: The project refers to a research initiative under the Cognition and Neuroergonomics Collaborative Technology Alliance (CaN-CTA) program, aimed at developing a semantic model for characterizing cognitive states through neuro-physiological data analysis.

Entity-sosassn_upper_ontology.label: SOSA/SSN upper ontologies
Entity-sosassn_upper_ontology.description: SOSA/SSN upper ontologies refer to a set of upper ontologies that provide a framework for representing sensor and observation data in the context of the Semantic Sensor Network and Sensor Observation Service standards.

Entity-top-down_approach.label: top-down approach
Entity-top-down_approach.description: The term 'top-down approach' refers to a modeling strategy used in the development of the BCI interaction model, where high-level concepts and relations are abstracted and structured to inform the design of specific components, such as the Annotation Tag module.

Entity-correlated_interpersonal_feature.label: correlated interpersonal features
Entity-correlated_interpersonal_feature.description: Correlated interpersonal features refer to the relationships among extracted neuro-physiological features from different individuals, which are identified through semantic search to enhance understanding of cognitive states and facilitate Transfer Learning in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-dul.label: DUL
Entity-dul.description: DUL refers to an ontology that provides a formal representation and framework for describing the relationships and interactions within the context of data and systems, particularly in the domain of context-aware applications.

Entity-purpose.label: purpose
Entity-purpose.description: In this context, 'purpose' refers to the intended function or objective of the conceptual components within the BCI-O's Context Model, which is to define the structural, functional, and temporal complexities of environments.

Entity-version.label: versions
Entity-version.description: The term 'versions' refers to the three distinct iterations of the BCI-O specifications, each represented by related XML documents, including the Base Version, HTML Version, and OWL 2 RDF/XML Version.

Entity-biological_and_neurophysiological.label: biological and neurophysiological signals
Entity-biological_and_neurophysiological.description: Biological and neurophysiological signals refer to the various types of data and indicators derived from biological processes and neural activities that reflect the physiological state and functioning of living organisms.

Entity-bio-signal_data.label: bio-signal data
Entity-bio-signal_data.description: Bio-signal data refers to quantitative information derived from biological signals, such as electrical or mechanical activity of the body, used for analysis in biomedical applications.

Entity-context_domain__unity_dictionary_.label: context domain (Unity dictionary)
Entity-context_domain__unity_dictionary_.description: The 'context domain (Unity dictionary)' refers to a non-ontological resource that provides a structured vocabulary and definitions relevant to the context modeling within the Unity framework, facilitating the integration of contextual information in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-interpersonal_transfer_learning.label: interpersonal Transfer Learning
Entity-interpersonal_transfer_learning.description: Interpersonal Transfer Learning refers to a machine learning process that involves transferring knowledge and features learned from one individual to improve the learning and performance of models for other individuals, particularly in the context of analyzing neuro-physiological signals in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-only_high-correlated_segment.label: Only high-correlated segments
Entity-only_high-correlated_segment.description: Only high-correlated segments refer to specific segments of EEG data that exhibit a significant correlation with the target model's classification criteria, making them essential for effective transfer learning in Brain-Computer Interaction applications.

Entity-their_ongoing_discussion.label: their ongoing discussions
Entity-their_ongoing_discussion.description: The term 'their ongoing discussions' refers to the collaborative dialogues and feedback exchanges among stakeholders involved in the development and extension of the SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation, particularly concerning the integration of new concepts and relationships relevant to the BCI Ontology.

Entity-hci_literature.label: HCI literature
Entity-hci_literature.description: HCI literature refers to the body of academic writings and research focused on Human-Computer Interaction, which studies the design and use of computer technology and the interaction between humans and computers.

Entity-structural__functional__and_tempo.label: structural, functional, and temporal complexity
Entity-structural__functional__and_tempo.description: The phrase 'structural, functional, and temporal complexity' refers to the intricate characteristics of an environment as defined by the BCI-O ontology, which encompasses the arrangement of entities, their interactions, and the dynamics over time within a given context.

Entity-related_term_of_interest.label: related terms of interest
Entity-related_term_of_interest.description: The term 'related terms of interest' refers to additional vocabulary or concepts that are relevant and can be aligned with the primary terms used in the BCI Ontology for enhancing the semantic understanding and interoperability of BCI metadata annotations.

Entity-data_segment.label: data segments
Entity-data_segment.description: Data segments refer to sequences of analyzed recorded data that are characterized by associated attributes indicating their probability and correlation, which are crucial for identifying relevant epochs in brain signal analysis.

Entity-machine_learning__ml_.label: Machine Learning (ML)
Entity-machine_learning__ml_.description: Machine Learning (ML) refers to a subset of artificial intelligence techniques that enable systems to learn from and make predictions or decisions based on data, particularly in the context of analyzing complex biological signals for applications such as Brain-Computer Interfaces.

Entity-they.label: they
Entity-they.description: The term 'they' refers to the two sets of metadata vocabulary developed by the SCCN team, namely the EEG Study Schema (ESS) and the Hierarchical Event Descriptor (HED), which are collectively known as the BCI metadata.

Entity-sccn.label: SCCN
Entity-sccn.description: SCCN refers to the Swartz Center for Computational Neuroscience, a research team at the University of California, San Diego, focused on developing metadata vocabularies for neuro-physiological data in the context of brain-computer interaction.

Entity-probability_and_correlation.label: probability and correlation
Entity-probability_and_correlation.description: The mention 'probability and correlation' refers to the statistical attributes that are annotated for high-correlated segments in the context of EEG data analysis, specifically indicating the likelihood and relationship strength of data segments relevant to a source model in Brain-Computer Interaction applications.

Entity-data_with_high_sampling_rate.label: data with high sampling rates
Entity-data_with_high_sampling_rate.description: Data with high sampling rates refers to bio-signal data that is recorded at a frequency sufficient to capture rapid changes in the signal, allowing for detailed analysis and interpretation in applications such as Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-related_xml_document.label: related XML documents
Entity-related_xml_document.description: Related XML documents refer to the three distinct versions of the BCI-O specifications, which include an OWL 2 RDF/XML document, a set of XSL 3 documents for HTML transformation, and a clean OWL 2 RDF/XML version, each serving different purposes in the context of the BCI ontology development.

Entity-sccn_team.label: SCCN team
Entity-sccn_team.description: The SCCN team refers to the research group at the Swartz Center for Computational Neuroscience at the University of California, San Diego, which focuses on developing metadata vocabularies and ontological structures for brain-computer interaction research.

Entity-can-cta_program.label: CaN-CTA Program
Entity-can-cta_program.description: The CaN-CTA Program is a research initiative developed by the U.S. Army Research Laboratory focused on creating a pervasive online Brain-Computer Interaction system.

Entity-neuro-physiological_signalsdata_s.label: neuro-physiological signals/data sets
Entity-neuro-physiological_signalsdata_s.description: Neuro-physiological signals/data sets refer to the quantitative measurements and recordings of biological signals related to the nervous system, which are used for analysis and interpretation in various research and clinical applications.

Entity-consistent_explanation.label: consistent explanation
Entity-consistent_explanation.description: A consistent explanation refers to a coherent and unified description of the functional aspects of various modules within the BCI interaction model, ensuring clarity and understanding of how each module contributes to the overall system.

Entity-sensor__observation__sample__and_.label: Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA)
Entity-sensor__observation__sample__and_.description: Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) is a semantic web standard designed to facilitate the integration and interoperability of sensor data and actuator functionalities within the Internet of Things (IoT) ecosystem.

Entity-eeg_subtypes.label: EEG subtypes
Entity-eeg_subtypes.description: EEG subtypes refer to the different classifications of electroencephalogram (EEG) data based on various parameters such as channel, device, modality, and record, which are essential for analyzing brain activity in Brain-Computer Interaction applications.

Entity-proposal.label: proposal
Entity-proposal.description: The 'proposal' refers to a set of extensions to the SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation that are being discussed and will influence the future updates of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) once they are finalized.

Entity-multi-modal_mobile_brain_imaging.label: multi-modal mobile brain imaging
Entity-multi-modal_mobile_brain_imaging.description: Multi-modal mobile brain imaging refers to the use of various imaging techniques in a portable format to study brain activity and function in real-time across different environments and conditions.

Entity-section.label: sections
Entity-section.description: The term 'sections' refers to distinct parts of the paper that detail the structure, design principles, engineering aspects, and applications of the BCI Ontology.

Entity-high-correlation_of_their_segment.label: high-correlation of their segments' probabilities
Entity-high-correlation_of_their_segment.description: The term 'high-correlation of their segments' probabilities' refers to the annotation of EEG data segments that exhibit a strong statistical relationship in their probability distributions, which is crucial for selecting relevant data for transfer learning in brain-computer interaction applications.

Entity-base-to-html_transformation.label: base-to-HTML transformation
Entity-base-to-html_transformation.description: The base-to-HTML transformation refers to a process involving a set of XSL 3 documents and XPath 3 functions that convert a base version of the BCI-O ontology, structured in OWL 2 RDF/XML format, into an HTML representation for better accessibility and presentation.

Entity-related_attribute.label: related attributes
Entity-related_attribute.description: Related attributes refer to the specific characteristics of analyzed EEG data segments that quantify their probability and correlation, which are essential for identifying relevant epochs in the context of transfer learning operations within Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-human-_and_machine-readable_inter.label: human- and machine-readable interface
Entity-human-_and_machine-readable_inter.description: A human- and machine-readable interface is a system or format that allows both humans and machines to easily understand, interpret, and interact with data or information.

Entity-clean_and_proper_machine-readable.label: clean and proper machine-readable document
Entity-clean_and_proper_machine-readable.description: The 'clean and proper machine-readable document' refers to the OWL 2 RDF/XML Version of the BCI Ontology specifications, which is generated by removing HTML formatting from the base version to ensure it is suitable for automated processing and semantic querying.

Entity-validation_point.label: validation points
Entity-validation_point.description: Validation points refer to specific checkpoints in the ontology engineering process where the satisfiability of the BCI-O ontology is assessed after modifications to its axioms.

Entity-ontological_structure.label: ontological structure
Entity-ontological_structure.description: An ontological structure is a formal representation of a set of concepts within a domain and the relationships between those concepts, used to facilitate understanding and communication of knowledge.

Entity-bio-signal.label: bio-signal
Entity-bio-signal.description: A bio-signal is a measurable signal that originates from biological processes in the body, often used to monitor physiological states and interactions with technology.

Entity-unity_s_core_concept.label: Unity's core concepts
Entity-unity_s_core_concept.description: Unity's core concepts refer to the foundational abstractions and architectural modeling principles derived from the Unity game engine, which are utilized to define the structural, behavioral, and temporal aspects of environments in the BCI-O's Context Model.

Entity-a_detailed_log.label: a detailed log
Entity-a_detailed_log.description: A detailed log refers to a comprehensive record maintained during the ontology engineering process, documenting the results and durations of each satisfiability checkpoint in the development of the BCI Ontology.

Entity-query_restriction.label: Query Restriction
Entity-query_restriction.description: Query Restriction refers to the process of applying attribute-based limitations on categories such as sessions, subjects, and records to effectively categorize observations within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction data analysis.

Entity-neuro-physiological_signal.label: neuro-physiological signals
Entity-neuro-physiological_signal.description: Neuro-physiological signals are biological signals that reflect the physiological activity of the nervous system, often measured through various techniques such as EEG, ECG, and EOG.

Entity-uri_locator.label: URI locators
Entity-uri_locator.description: URI locators refer to Uniform Resource Identifiers that enable access to external resources and raw data, facilitating their indexing and retrieval in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-base_version.label: Base Version
Entity-base_version.description: The Base Version refers to the initial OWL 2 RDF/XML document that contains the complete modeling structure and content of the BCI Ontology, including embedded HTML formatting and text-handling rules.

Entity-extension.label: extensions
Entity-extension.description: The term 'extensions' refers to proposed enhancements or modifications to the SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation that will be integrated into the BCI Ontology (BCI-O) to improve its alignment and functionality.

Entity-subsequent_section.label: subsequent sections
Entity-subsequent_section.description: The term 'subsequent sections' refers to the later parts of the paper where the authors elaborate on the structure, design principles, engineering aspects, and applications of the BCI Ontology (BCI-O).

Entity-relation.label: relations
Entity-relation.description: In this context, 'relations' refers to the semantic connections or associations among the extracted neuro-physiological features from different individuals, which are identified through semantic search to aid in understanding cognitive states.

Entity-bio-signal_marker.label: bio-signal markers
Entity-bio-signal_marker.description: Bio-signal markers are measurable indicators derived from biological signals that reflect physiological or pathological states in the human body.

Entity-semantic_reasoning.label: semantic reasoning
Entity-semantic_reasoning.description: Semantic reasoning is a cognitive process that involves the application of logical inference and understanding of meaning to analyze and interpret data, often used in artificial intelligence and machine learning contexts.

Entity-machine-to-machine_environment.label: machine-to-machine environments
Entity-machine-to-machine_environment.description: Machine-to-machine environments refer to systems or settings where devices communicate and interact with each other autonomously, often without human intervention, to exchange data and perform tasks.

Entity-stable_status.label: stable status
Entity-stable_status.description: The term 'stable status' refers to the condition achieved during the iterative assessment process of the BCI-O modeling and specifications, indicating that they have reached a satisfactory level of consistency and reliability.

Entity-attribute-based_restriction.label: attribute-based restrictions
Entity-attribute-based_restriction.description: Attribute-based restrictions refer to the limitations applied to the categories of sessions, subjects, and records in a semantic query, which help in categorizing observations for data analysis in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-embedded_html_formatting.label: embedded HTML formatting
Entity-embedded_html_formatting.description: Embedded HTML formatting refers to the integration of HTML code within a document to enhance its presentation and structure, specifically in the context of the BCI-O specifications where it is used alongside text-handling rules in the OWL 2 RDF/XML document.

Entity-semantic_interoperability.label: semantic interoperability
Entity-semantic_interoperability.description: Semantic interoperability refers to the ability of different systems or organizations to exchange information with shared meaning, enabling effective communication and integration of data across diverse platforms.

Entity-accessing_and_indexing_purpose.label: accessing and indexing purposes
Entity-accessing_and_indexing_purpose.description: The term 'accessing and indexing purposes' refers to the utilization of URI locators to facilitate the retrieval and organization of external resources and raw data within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-vpod_ontology.label: vPod Ontology
Entity-vpod_ontology.description: The vPod Ontology is a specialized ontology used in the context of Early Glaucoma Detection, facilitating the selection of EEG datasets and segments classified by a Convolutional Neural Network for input into a more advanced CNN model.

Entity-a_human_being.label: a human being
Entity-a_human_being.description: A human being refers to an individual person who is actively engaged in an activity, characterized by specific attributes and states within the context of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-a_collection_of_spatially_located.label: a collection of spatially located entities
aliases: a collection of spatially located entities
Entity-a_collection_of_spatially_located.description: A collection of spatially located entities refers to a set of objects or components within a physical or virtual environment that are positioned in relation to one another and engage in interactions, as described in the context of the BCI Ontology's modeling of scenes.

mentions.local_name: a collection of spatially located entities

Entity-user__s_physical_condition.label: User’s physical conditions
Entity-user__s_physical_condition.description: User's physical conditions refer to the various health and biological states of an individual that can influence the neuro-physiological signals collected in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-iot.label: IoT
Entity-iot.description: IoT, or the Internet of Things, refers to a network of interconnected devices and systems that communicate and exchange data over the internet, enabling automation and smart functionalities across various applications.

Entity-semi-structured_and_non-interoper.label: semi-structured and non-interoperable metadata formats
Entity-semi-structured_and_non-interoper.description: Semi-structured and non-interoperable metadata formats refer to data organization structures that do not adhere to a standardized schema, making them difficult to integrate and share across different systems, particularly in the context of training and personalizing machine learning models in Brain-Computer Interaction applications.

Entity-owl_2_ontology.label: OWL 2 ontology
Entity-owl_2_ontology.description: OWL 2 ontology refers to a formal specification of ontologies that extends the Web Ontology Language (OWL) to provide greater expressiveness and support for reasoning about the relationships between concepts in a domain.

Entity-linked_sensor_data_standard.label: Linked Sensor Data standard
Entity-linked_sensor_data_standard.description: The Linked Sensor Data standard refers to the Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) framework, which facilitates the integration and interoperability of sensor data within the Internet of Things (IoT) and the Internet of Services, particularly in the context of Machine-to-Machine (M2M) environments.

Entity-it_namespace_uri_definition.label: its namespace URI definition
Entity-it_namespace_uri_definition.description: The term 'its namespace URI definition' refers to the specific identifier registered with w3id.org that serves as the unique namespace for the BCI Ontology, facilitating the organization and retrieval of its metadata and concepts.

Entity-enlightenment.label: enlightenment
Entity-enlightenment.description: In the context of cognitive states, 'enlightenment' refers to a psychological condition characterized by heightened awareness and understanding, which is being studied in relation to neuro-physiological features within Brain-Computer Interaction research.

Entity-domain_ontology.label: domain ontology
Entity-domain_ontology.description: A domain ontology is a formal representation of knowledge within a specific area, defining the concepts, relationships, and rules that govern the domain to facilitate understanding, communication, and interoperability among systems.

Entity-relevant_epoch.label: relevant epochs
Entity-relevant_epoch.description: Relevant epochs refer to specific segments of EEG data that exhibit high correlation with the source model's classifications, indicating their significance in accurately classifying the eye's vision in the context of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-semantic_commitment.label: semantic commitment
Entity-semantic_commitment.description: Semantic commitment refers to the degree of meaning or significance that annotations hold in the context of ontological representations, particularly in relation to their ability to facilitate the reuse and sharing of concepts within web-oriented frameworks.

Entity-event_classification.label: event classification
Entity-event_classification.description: Event classification refers to the systematic categorization of events based on their characteristics and relationships, often used in various fields such as computer science, linguistics, and cognitive science to analyze and interpret actions and their impacts.

Entity-a_certain_level_of_abstraction.label: a certain level of abstraction
Entity-a_certain_level_of_abstraction.description: The term 'a certain level of abstraction' refers to the degree of simplification or generalization applied to the structural, functional, and temporal complexities of an environment, as utilized in the context of modeling within the BCI Ontology's Context Model based on Unity's gaming architecture.

Entity-sensor_system.label: sensor systems
Entity-sensor_system.description: Sensor systems are integrated technologies that utilize various types of sensors to collect, process, and analyze data from the environment to facilitate automated responses or enhance decision-making processes.

Entity-m2m_environment.label: M2M environments
Entity-m2m_environment.description: M2M environments refer to settings or systems where machine-to-machine communication occurs, enabling devices to exchange data and interact autonomously without human intervention.

Entity-two_early_application.label: two early applications
Entity-two_early_application.description: The term 'two early applications' refers to the CerebraTek vPod Ontology, which is utilized for glaucoma diagnostics using mfSSVEP, and the ESS+HED Standards Ontology for BCI-O, which serves as an ontological overlay for EEG data sharing tools ESS v2.0 and HED v2.0.

Entity-human_body_bio-signal.label: human body bio-signal
Entity-human_body_bio-signal.description: Human body bio-signals are physiological signals generated by the human body that can be measured and analyzed to provide insights into various biological processes and health conditions.

Entity-the_conclusion.label: the conclusion
Entity-the_conclusion.description: The conclusion refers to the final section of the paper where the authors summarize the main contributions of their research on the BCI Ontology and outline potential future work in the field.

Entity-stimulus.label: stimuli
Entity-stimulus.description: Stimuli are external or internal factors that provoke a response or reaction in an organism or system, often serving as inputs in various contexts such as environmental interactions or experimental settings.

Entity-upper_ontology.label: upper ontologies
Entity-upper_ontology.description: Upper ontologies are high-level frameworks in knowledge representation that provide a structured vocabulary and conceptual organization for categorizing and relating various domains of knowledge.

Entity-external_resource_set.label: external resource set
Entity-external_resource_set.description: The 'external resource set' refers to a collection of additional resources that enhance or supplement the descriptions of entities defined within the BCI Ontology (BCI-O).

Entity-interoperable_model.label: interoperable models
Entity-interoperable_model.description: Interoperable models are structured representations or frameworks that enable different systems or components to work together seamlessly, facilitating data exchange and communication across diverse platforms.

Entity-logic-based__upper_ontology_.label: logic-based (upper ontologies)
Entity-logic-based__upper_ontology_.description: Logic-based upper ontologies refer to a modeling style that utilizes formal logical frameworks to define high-level concepts and relationships in ontologies, facilitating rigorous reasoning and semantic interoperability in knowledge representation.

Entity-cognition_and_neuroergonomics_col.label: Cognition and Neuroergonomics Collaborative Technology Alliance
aliases: Cognition and Neuroergonomics Collaborative Technology Alliance (CaN-CTA)
Cognition and Neuroergonomics Collaborative Technology Alliance
Entity-cognition_and_neuroergonomics_col.description: The Cognition and Neuroergonomics Collaborative Technology Alliance (CaN-CTA) is a research initiative sponsored by the U.S. Army Research Laboratory that focuses on advanced computational approaches to enhance brain-computer interaction and cognitive state analysis through collaborative projects among various academic institutions.

mentions.local_name: Cognition and Neuroergonomics Collaborative Technology Alliance
Cognition and Neuroergonomics Collaborative Technology Alliance (CaN-CTA)

Entity-eeg_signal.label: EEG signals
Entity-eeg_signal.description: EEG signals are electrical impulses generated by the brain's activity, measured through electrodes placed on the scalp, and are used to assess neurological function.

Entity-data_segment_for_the_transfer_lea.label: data segments for the transfer learning target model
aliases: data segments for the transfer learning target model
Entity-data_segment_for_the_transfer_lea.description: The 'data segments for the transfer learning target model' refers to the specific portions of analyzed EEG recordings that have been annotated with high correlation and probability attributes, which are selected as input for a more sophisticated convolutional neural network model in a transfer learning application aimed at improving glaucoma detection.

mentions.local_name: data segments for the transfer learning target model

Entity-her_brain_state.label: her brain states
Entity-her_brain_state.description: The term 'her brain states' refers to the specific cognitive and neuro-physiological conditions of an individual, as determined through the analysis of biological signals such as EEG, which are influenced by various situational and personal factors.

Entity-semantic_web.label: Semantic Web
Entity-semantic_web.description: The Semantic Web is a framework for enabling machines to understand and interpret data on the internet through the use of standardized formats and ontologies, enhancing data interoperability and facilitating intelligent information retrieval.

Entity-neuro-physiological_feature.label: neuro-physiological features
Entity-neuro-physiological_feature.description: Neuro-physiological features refer to the biological and physiological characteristics of the nervous system that can influence or reflect cognitive processes and states.

Entity-a_single_activity.label: a single activity
Entity-a_single_activity.description: A single activity refers to a specific task or action performed by a subject within a defined context, characterized by particular settings and conditions during a session of Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-revneti.label: RevNet+I
Entity-revneti.description: RevNet+I is a complex 24-layer convolutional neural network (CNN) model designed for advanced analysis of EEG signal features, functioning as a transfer learning target model in brain-computer interaction applications.

Entity-semantic_web_technology.label: Semantic Web technologies
Entity-semantic_web_technology.description: Semantic Web technologies refer to a set of standards and frameworks that enable the sharing and reuse of data across different applications on the web, facilitating enhanced data interoperability and semantic understanding.

Entity-skos_lexical_label.label: SKOS lexical labels
Entity-skos_lexical_label.description: SKOS lexical labels are annotation properties used in the Simple Knowledge Organization System (SKOS) to provide human-readable names for concepts, facilitating their identification and use in knowledge organization systems.

Entity-their_structural_resemblance.label: their structural resemblance
Entity-their_structural_resemblance.description: The term 'their structural resemblance' refers to the similarity in the conceptual frameworks and design patterns between the SOSA/SSN ontologies and the Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) ontology design pattern, which are both utilized in the development of the BCI Ontology's Actuation Model.

Entity-neurophysiological_signal.label: neurophysiological signals
Entity-neurophysiological_signal.description: Neurophysiological signals are electrical or chemical signals generated by the nervous system that reflect the activity of neurons and can be measured to assess brain and body functions.

Entity-content_negotiation_server-side_s.label: content negotiation server-side script
aliases: A basic content negotiation server-side script
Entity-content_negotiation_server-side_s.description: A content negotiation server-side script is a program designed to dynamically serve different versions of web content based on the client's request, ensuring that users receive the appropriate format of the specifications for the BCI Ontology.

mentions.local_name: A basic content negotiation server-side script

Entity-swartz_center_for_computational_n.label: Swartz Center for Computational Neuroscience (SCCN)
Entity-swartz_center_for_computational_n.description: The Swartz Center for Computational Neuroscience (SCCN) is a research facility at the University of California, San Diego, focused on advancing the understanding of brain function through computational approaches and collaboration in neurophysiological research.

Entity-ontology_design_pattern.label: Ontology design pattern
Entity-ontology_design_pattern.description: An ontology design pattern is a reusable solution to a recurring modeling problem in ontology engineering, providing a structured approach to represent knowledge in a specific domain.

Entity-modeling_and_ontology_tool.label: modeling and ontology tools
Entity-modeling_and_ontology_tool.description: Modeling and ontology tools are software applications designed to assist in the creation, visualization, and management of models and ontologies, facilitating the organization and representation of knowledge in various domains.

Entity-u.s._arl_translational_neuroscien.label: U.S. ARL Translational Neuroscience Branch (CaN-CTA Program)
aliases: U.S. ARL Translational Neuroscience Branch (CaN-CTA Program)
Entity-u.s._arl_translational_neuroscien.description: The U.S. ARL Translational Neuroscience Branch (CaN-CTA Program) is a research initiative focused on advancing translational neuroscience through collaborative projects that integrate brain-computer interaction technologies and methodologies.

mentions.local_name: U.S. ARL Translational Neuroscience Branch (CaN-CTA Program)

Entity-dl.label: DL
Entity-dl.description: DL refers to Deep Learning, a subset of machine learning techniques used for analyzing complex biological signals in Brain-Computer Interface systems.

Entity-deep_learning__dl_.label: Deep Learning (DL)
Entity-deep_learning__dl_.description: Deep Learning (DL) refers to a subset of machine learning techniques that utilize neural networks with multiple layers to analyze complex data patterns, particularly in the context of classifying biological signals in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-swartz_center_for_computational_n.label: Swartz Center for Computational Neuroscience
Entity-swartz_center_for_computational_n.description: The Swartz Center for Computational Neuroscience is a research center at the University of California, San Diego, focused on advancing the understanding of brain function through computational methods and neuroinformatics.

Entity-owl-time_glossary.label: OWL-Time glossary
Entity-owl-time_glossary.description: The OWL-Time glossary is a resource that provides definitions and descriptions related to temporal concepts and structures within the OWL-Time ontology, which is used for modeling time in semantic web applications.

Entity-incremental_software_engineering_.label: incremental software engineering tasks
Entity-incremental_software_engineering_.description: Incremental software engineering tasks refer to the iterative and progressive activities involved in the development and refinement of software systems, which in this context were utilized to design a proto-ontology for a Brain-Computer Interaction system.

Entity-sensor.label: sensors
Entity-sensor.description: Sensors are devices or components that detect and measure physical properties or environmental conditions, converting them into signals that can be read and interpreted.

Entity-ontological_framework.label: ontological frameworks
Entity-ontological_framework.description: Ontological frameworks are structured theoretical models that provide a systematic representation of concepts and their relationships within a specific domain, facilitating understanding and communication of complex information.

Entity-semantic_matching.label: Semantic Matching
Entity-semantic_matching.description: Semantic Matching is a conceptual framework or methodology used to identify and establish relationships between different data elements or concepts based on their meanings and contextual relevance.

Entity-personalized_calibration.label: personalized calibration
Entity-personalized_calibration.description: Personalized calibration refers to the process of adjusting machine learning models using relevant data sets to enhance their performance and accuracy for individual users in Brain-Computer Interaction systems.

Entity-internet_of_service_layer.label: Internet of Services layers
