Entity-internet_of_service_layer.description: The Internet of Services layers refers to a conceptual framework that integrates various services and applications over the Internet, facilitating communication and interaction between devices and systems, particularly in the context of Machine-to-Machine (M2M) environments.

Entity-it_purpose.label: its purpose
Entity-it_purpose.description: The term 'its purpose' refers to the intended function or objective of the structural, functional, and temporal complexity definitions of environments as modeled in the BCI-O's Context Model.

Entity-ssn_skeleton.label: SSN Skeleton
Entity-ssn_skeleton.description: The SSN Skeleton is a module that defines the Stimulus-Sensor-Observation (SSO) ontology design pattern, serving as the foundational structure for the Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) framework.

Entity-sosa__sensor.label: sosa:Sensor
Entity-sosa__sensor.description: sosa:Sensor refers to a class of entities in the Sensor Observation Service ontology that represents devices capable of observing and measuring physical phenomena.

Entity-dul__event.label: dul:Event
Entity-dul__event.description: dul:Event refers to a conceptual representation of an occurrence or happening that can be observed and recorded within an ontology framework.

Entity-session.label: Session
Entity-session.description: Session refers to the interaction between a subject and a context while performing a single activity under specific settings and conditions, encompassing both observations and actuations.

Entity-convolutional_neural_network.label: Convolutional Neural Network
Entity-convolutional_neural_network.description: A Convolutional Neural Network is a type of deep learning model specifically designed to process and analyze visual data by mimicking the way the human brain recognizes patterns.

Entity-eeg_experimental_event.label: EEG experimental events
Entity-eeg_experimental_event.description: EEG experimental events refer to specific occurrences or conditions during an electroencephalogram (EEG) study that are systematically manipulated or recorded to assess brain activity in response to stimuli or tasks.

Entity-the_interaction_between_a_subject.label: the interaction between a subject and a context
aliases: the interaction between a subject and a context
Entity-the_interaction_between_a_subject.description: The interaction between a subject and a context refers to a session in which a human engages in an activity, influenced by specific environmental settings and conditions.

mentions.local_name: the interaction between a subject and a context

Entity-semantic_sensor_network__ssn_.label: Semantic Sensor Network (SSN)
Entity-semantic_sensor_network__ssn_.description: The Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) is a framework and standard designed to facilitate the integration and interoperability of sensor data and services on the web.

Entity-ontology_development.label: ontology development
Entity-ontology_development.description: Ontology development is the process of creating and refining formal representations of knowledge within a specific domain, often involving the integration of existing vocabularies and metadata standards.

Entity-development_driver.label: development drivers
Entity-development_driver.description: Development drivers refer to key initiatives or modeling tasks that facilitate the creation and enhancement of ontological frameworks aimed at capturing and integrating bio-signal markers and technological interfaces for various human body organs and systems.

Entity-annotated_data_segment.label: annotated data segments
Entity-annotated_data_segment.description: Annotated data segments refer to portions of data that have been labeled or tagged with specific information to facilitate analysis, training, or evaluation in various data processing tasks.

Entity-wearable_sensor.label: wearable sensors
Entity-wearable_sensor.description: Wearable sensors are electronic devices that can be worn on the body to collect data about the user's physiological or environmental conditions, often used in health monitoring and fitness applications.

Entity-ontological_concept.label: ontological concepts
Entity-ontological_concept.description: Ontological concepts are abstract ideas or categories that define the nature of being and existence within a specific domain, often used in formal representations to facilitate understanding and communication of knowledge.

Entity-m2m.label: M2M
Entity-m2m.description: M2M refers to 'Machine-to-Machine' communication, a technology that enables devices to communicate and exchange data with each other over networks, particularly relevant in the context of Internet of Things (IoT) applications.

Entity-web-of-things.label: Web-of-Things
Entity-web-of-things.description: The Web-of-Things is a conceptual framework that extends the Internet of Things by integrating web technologies to enable seamless interaction and interoperability among connected devices and services.

Entity-specialized_linked_data_service.label: specialized linked data services
Entity-specialized_linked_data_service.description: Specialized linked data services refer to tailored functionalities provided by a linked data engine that facilitate the serving of various data formats, such as HTML and RDF/XML, and manage URI entry points for different user agents in the context of the BCI Ontology specifications.

Entity-sensor_network.label: sensor networks
Entity-sensor_network.description: Sensor networks are systems composed of interconnected devices that collect, transmit, and process data from various sensors to monitor and manage physical environments.

Entity-sensor-actuator_system.label: sensor-actuator system
Entity-sensor-actuator_system.description: A sensor-actuator system is a technological framework that integrates sensors to collect data and actuators to perform actions based on that data, enabling automated responses in various applications.

Entity-ontology_authoring.label: Ontology authoring
Entity-ontology_authoring.description: Ontology authoring is the process of creating and defining ontologies, which are formal representations of a set of concepts within a domain and the relationships between those concepts.

Entity-distributed_computing.label: distributed computing
Entity-distributed_computing.description: Distributed computing is a computing paradigm that involves the use of multiple interconnected computers to perform tasks and process data collaboratively, often to improve efficiency and resource utilization.

Entity-technological_interface.label: technological interfaces
Entity-technological_interface.description: Technological interfaces are systems or devices that facilitate interaction between humans and technology, enabling the exchange of information and control over various technological processes.

Entity-semantic_middleware.label: semantic middleware
Entity-semantic_middleware.description: Semantic middleware is a type of software that facilitates the integration and interoperability of data and services by utilizing semantic technologies to enhance communication and understanding between different systems.

Entity-cognitive_state.label: cognitive states
Entity-cognitive_state.description: Cognitive states refer to the various mental conditions or psychological states that characterize an individual's thoughts, feelings, and awareness at a given time.

Entity-brain.label: brain
Entity-brain.description: The brain is a complex organ that serves as the central part of the nervous system, responsible for processing sensory information, regulating bodily functions, and enabling cognitive abilities.

Entity-convolutional_neural_network__cnn.label: Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)
Entity-convolutional_neural_network__cnn.description: A Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) is a type of deep learning algorithm specifically designed for processing structured grid data, such as images, by using convolutional layers to automatically and adaptively learn spatial hierarchies of features.

Entity-classified_recording.label: classified recordings
Entity-classified_recording.description: Classified recordings refer to EEG data that has been analyzed and categorized into specific classifications, such as Normal, G. Early, or G. Late, based on their relevance to glaucoma detection stages, and are used as input for transfer learning in machine learning models.

Entity-eye_s_vision.label: eye's vision
Entity-eye_s_vision.description: The term 'eye's vision' refers to the classification of visual perception data derived from EEG recordings, specifically in the context of identifying and analyzing the visual capabilities and conditions of the eye, such as in glaucoma detection.

Entity-duration_of_each_satisfiability_c.label: durations of each satisfiability checkpoint
Entity-duration_of_each_satisfiability_c.description: The term 'durations of each satisfiability checkpoint' refers to the recorded time intervals taken to validate the consistency and correctness of the BCI ontology at various stages of its development, as monitored by the reasoner HermiT.

Entity-eegnet.label: EEGNet
Entity-eegnet.description: EEGNet is a convolutional neural network model designed for analyzing electroencephalogram (EEG) data, often utilized in machine learning applications for classification tasks.

Entity-uri_entry_point.label: URI entry points
Entity-uri_entry_point.description: URI entry points refer to specific Uniform Resource Identifiers that serve as access points for different user agents to retrieve various versions of the BCI-O specifications, including HTML and RDF/XML formats.

Entity-the_probability.label: the probability
Entity-the_probability.description: The probability refers to a statistical measure that quantifies the likelihood of a specific event or outcome occurring, particularly in the context of high-correlated segments of EEG data in Brain-Computer Interaction applications.

Entity-ucsd__sccn_.label: UCSD (SCCN)
Entity-ucsd__sccn_.description: UCSD (SCCN) refers to the University of California, San Diego's Swartz Center for Computational Neuroscience, an institution involved in research and development in the field of brain-computer interaction.

Entity-transfer_learning.label: Transfer Learning
Entity-transfer_learning.description: Transfer Learning is a machine learning technique that focuses on transferring knowledge gained from one task to improve the performance on a different but related task.

Entity-sosa__observation.label: sosa:Observation
Entity-sosa__observation.description: sosa:Observation refers to a class in the Sensor, Observation, Sample, and Actuator (SOSA) ontology that represents a recorded instance of an observation made by a sensor or an observer.

Entity-ontology_engineering_process.label: ontology engineering process
Entity-ontology_engineering_process.description: The ontology engineering process is a systematic methodology for designing, creating, and maintaining ontologies, which are formal representations of knowledge within a specific domain.

Entity-stress_and_fatigue_neuroimaging.label: stress and fatigue neuroimaging
Entity-stress_and_fatigue_neuroimaging.description: Stress and fatigue neuroimaging refers to the application of neuroimaging techniques to study and analyze the brain activity and responses associated with stress and fatigue in various contexts, as part of heterogeneous datasets utilized in Brain-Computer Interaction research.

Entity-internet-of-things.label: Internet-of-Things
Entity-internet-of-things.description: The Internet-of-Things refers to a network of interconnected devices and objects that communicate and exchange data over the internet, enabling automation and smart functionalities.

Entity-classification_model.label: classification models
Entity-classification_model.description: Classification models are algorithms or machine learning models designed to categorize data into predefined classes based on input features.

Entity-instant_and_interval_concept.label: instant and interval concepts
Entity-instant_and_interval_concept.description: The instant and interval concepts refer to temporal representations that define specific points in time and durations, respectively, and are derived from the W3C OWL-Time ontology.

Entity-actuator.label: actuators
Entity-actuator.description: Actuators are devices or components that convert control signals into physical motion or action, enabling interaction with the environment.

Entity-categorized_observation.label: categorized observations
Entity-categorized_observation.description: Categorized observations refer to the classified EEG recordings of glaucoma patients, which are organized into specific categories such as Normal, G. Early, or G. Late, and are used as input for transfer learning operations in machine learning models.

Entity-metadata_annotation.label: metadata annotations
Entity-metadata_annotation.description: Metadata annotations are structured pieces of information that provide descriptive context and additional details about data, facilitating better understanding and interpretation of the underlying content.

Entity-ontology_design_pattern_reuse.label: ontology design pattern reuse
aliases: Ontology design pattern reuse and alignment
Entity-ontology_design_pattern_reuse.description: Ontology design pattern reuse refers to the practice of utilizing existing ontology design patterns to enhance the development and integration of ontologies, promoting consistency and efficiency in semantic modeling.

mentions.local_name: Ontology design pattern reuse and alignment

Entity-dul_ontology.label: DUL ontologies
Entity-dul_ontology.description: DUL ontologies refer to a set of formal ontologies that provide a framework for representing and reasoning about the semantics of data in the context of the Semantic Web.

Entity-sensor_output_stream.label: sensor output streams
Entity-sensor_output_stream.description: Sensor output streams refer to continuous flows of data generated by sensors that capture and transmit information about physical phenomena or environmental conditions.

Entity-hierarchical_event_descriptor_tag.label: Hierarchical Event Descriptor Tags
Entity-hierarchical_event_descriptor_tag.description: Hierarchical Event Descriptor Tags refers to a structured hierarchy of standard and extended descriptors specifically designed for annotating and analyzing experimental events in event-related EEG studies, facilitating both human and machine readability.

Entity-pruning_and_modularization.label: pruning and modularization
Entity-pruning_and_modularization.description: Pruning and modularization refer to the processes involved in refining and organizing the BCI Ontology to enhance its structure and functionality by removing unnecessary elements and creating distinct, manageable components.

Entity-the_analyzed_raw_data.label: the analyzed raw data
Entity-the_analyzed_raw_data.description: The analyzed raw data refers to the EEG recordings and their corresponding data segments that have been processed and annotated for high correlation and probability, which are utilized as input for the RevNet+I model in the context of transfer learning for glaucoma detection.

Entity-ontology_library.label: ontology library
Entity-ontology_library.description: An ontology library is a structured collection of ontologies that provides a framework for knowledge representation and facilitates the organization, sharing, and reuse of knowledge across different domains.

Entity-neuro-physiological_recording.label: neuro-physiological recording
Entity-neuro-physiological_recording.description: Neuro-physiological recording refers to the process of measuring and documenting the electrical and physiological activity of the nervous system, typically through techniques such as electroencephalography (EEG) or other neuroimaging methods.

Entity-electroencephalogram.label: electroencephalogram
Entity-electroencephalogram.description: An electroencephalogram is a medical test that measures electrical activity in the brain through electrodes placed on the scalp, used to diagnose and monitor neurological conditions.

Entity-the_setting_of_the_neuro-physiolo.label: the settings of the neuro-physiological recording
aliases: the settings of the neuro-physiological recording
Entity-the_setting_of_the_neuro-physiolo.description: The settings of the neuro-physiological recording refer to the specific configurations and parameters used during the collection of neuro-physiological data, such as electrode placement, sampling rate, and environmental conditions.

mentions.local_name: the settings of the neuro-physiological recording

Entity-multi-dimensional_event.label: multi-dimensional event
Entity-multi-dimensional_event.description: A multi-dimensional event is an observation that encapsulates information regarding a stimulus, the sensor that detects it, the sensor's output, and the spatial-temporal context of the sensing activity.

Entity-logic-based.label: logic-based
Entity-logic-based.description: Logic-based refers to a modeling style or data representation approach that utilizes formal logic principles to structure and infer relationships within data or knowledge systems.

Entity-external_resource.label: external resources
Entity-external_resource.description: The term 'external resources' refers to URI locators that provide access to additional data and raw information, which can be utilized for indexing and enhancing the functionality of BCI systems.

Entity-machine_learning.label: Machine Learning
Entity-machine_learning.description: Machine Learning is a field of artificial intelligence that focuses on the development of algorithms and statistical models that enable computers to perform tasks without explicit instructions, relying on patterns and inference instead.

Entity-hierarchical_event_descriptor_tag.label: Hierarchical Event Descriptor Tags for Analysis of Event-Related EEG Studies
aliases: Hierarchical Event Descriptor Tags for Analysis of Event-Related EEG Studies
Entity-hierarchical_event_descriptor_tag.description: Hierarchical Event Descriptor Tags for Analysis of Event-Related EEG Studies is a structured framework that establishes a hierarchy of standardized and extended descriptors for EEG experimental events, facilitating a consistent interface for both human and machine interpretation of EEG data.

mentions.local_name: Hierarchical Event Descriptor Tags for Analysis of Event-Related EEG Studies

Entity-real-time_data_processing.label: real-time data processing
Entity-real-time_data_processing.description: Real-time data processing refers to the continuous input, processing, and output of data with minimal latency, enabling immediate analysis and response to incoming data streams.

Entity-linked_data_world.label: Linked Data world
Entity-linked_data_world.description: The 'Linked Data world' refers to a framework for publishing and connecting structured data on the web, enabling interoperability and integration of diverse datasets through semantic web technologies.

Entity-neuromonitoring_vrar_goggle.label: Neuromonitoring VR/AR Goggle
Entity-neuromonitoring_vrar_goggle.description: The Neuromonitoring VR/AR Goggle is a specialized device designed for brain-computer interaction, utilizing virtual and augmented reality technologies to monitor and analyze neurological states in real-time.

Entity-w3cogc.label: W3C/OGC
Entity-w3cogc.description: W3C/OGC refers to the collaborative efforts and standards developed by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) and the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) aimed at enhancing the interoperability and integration of web-based and geospatial data and services.

Entity-an_application_for_early_glaucoma.label: An application for Early Glaucoma Detection
aliases: An application for Early Glaucoma Detection
Entity-an_application_for_early_glaucoma.description: An application for Early Glaucoma Detection refers to a system that utilizes the vPod Ontology to identify and select EEG data sets and segments previously classified by a simple Convolutional Neural Network, which are then used as input for a more advanced CNN model to enhance the accuracy of glaucoma diagnosis.

mentions.local_name: An application for Early Glaucoma Detection

Entity-transfer_learning_source_model_(1.label: transfer learning source model
Entity-transfer_learning_source_model_(1.description: The transfer learning source model refers to the EEGNet model, which is utilized as a high-level selector in the context of transfer learning operations for classifying EEG recordings in applications such as glaucoma detection.

Entity-owl_2_rdfxml.label: OWL 2 RDF/XML
Entity-owl_2_rdfxml.description: OWL 2 RDF/XML is a serialization format for representing OWL 2 ontologies in RDF/XML syntax, enabling the exchange and storage of semantic web data.

Entity-metadata_vocabulary.label: metadata vocabulary
Entity-metadata_vocabulary.description: A metadata vocabulary is a structured set of terms and definitions used to describe and categorize data, facilitating consistent data representation and interoperability across different systems.

Entity-eeg_recording.label: EEG recordings
Entity-eeg_recording.description: EEG recordings are data obtained from electroencephalography, a technique used to measure electrical activity in the brain through electrodes placed on the scalp.

Entity-high-correlated_segment.label: High-correlated segments
Entity-high-correlated_segment.description: High-correlated segments refer to specific epochs in EEG recordings that exhibit a strong statistical correlation with the source model used for classifying visual information in glaucoma detection.

Entity-learning_process.label: learning process
Entity-learning_process.description: The learning process refers to the cognitive and educational activities through which individuals acquire knowledge, skills, and competencies, often involving the integration of new information with existing knowledge.

Entity-open.vocab.org.label: Open.vocab.org
Entity-open.vocab.org.description: Open.vocab.org is a vocabulary repository that provides web-oriented representations for reusing and sharing ontological concepts and their descriptions, often used in the context of metadata standards.

Entity-multimodal_classification.label: multimodal classification
Entity-multimodal_classification.description: Multimodal classification is a machine learning technique that involves the integration and analysis of data from multiple modalities or sources to categorize or classify information effectively.

Entity-recorded_data.label: recorded data
Entity-recorded_data.description: Recorded data refers to information that has been captured and stored, typically from sensors or observations, for analysis or reference.

Entity-the_architectural_description_of_.label: the architectural description of a physical or virtual environment
aliases: the architectural description of a physical or virtual environment
Entity-the_architectural_description_of_.description: The architectural description of a physical or virtual environment refers to a structured representation that outlines the spatial and functional relationships among entities within a given setting, enabling the modeling of interactions and complexities inherent to that environment.

mentions.local_name: the architectural description of a physical or virtual environment

Entity-nervous.label: nervous
Entity-nervous.description: The term 'nervous' refers to the nervous system, which is one of the biological systems in the human body responsible for transmitting signals between different body parts and coordinating bodily functions.

Entity-an_ongoing_effort.label: an ongoing effort
Entity-an_ongoing_effort.description: An ongoing effort refers to the current initiative aimed at proposing extensions to the SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation, which involves active participation and feedback from the BCI-O perspective.

Entity-metadata_concept.label: metadata concepts
Entity-metadata_concept.description: Metadata concepts refer to the ideas and principles that define the structure, organization, and meaning of data, facilitating its understanding and use in various applications.

Entity-high-level_selector.label: high-level selector
Entity-high-level_selector.description: The term 'high-level selector' refers to a model, specifically the EEGNet model, that is utilized in the context of transfer learning to select and classify relevant data segments based on their correlation and probability attributes in EEG recordings.

Entity-standard_and_extended_descriptor.label: standard and extended descriptors
Entity-standard_and_extended_descriptor.description: Standard and extended descriptors refer to a hierarchical classification system used in EEG studies that provides a structured, uniform interface for describing experimental events in a way that is accessible to both humans and machines.

Entity-interoperability.label: interoperability
Entity-interoperability.description: Interoperability refers to the ability of different systems, devices, or applications to work together and exchange information effectively, often through standardized protocols and interfaces.

Entity-skos.label: SKOS
Entity-skos.description: SKOS, or Simple Knowledge Organization System, is a standard for representing knowledge organization systems such as thesauri, classification schemes, and taxonomies in a machine-readable format.

Entity-hermit_v1.3.8.label: HermiT v1.3.8
Entity-hermit_v1.3.8.description: HermiT v1.3.8 is a version of a software tool designed for reasoning in description logics and ontology management.

Entity-structural__behavioral__and_tempo.label: structural, behavioral, and temporal
Entity-structural__behavioral__and_tempo.description: The mention 'structural, behavioral, and temporal' refers to the three complementary perspectives used in Unity's architectural modeling framework to describe the organization of entities and their relationships within any environment.

Entity-time_domain__owl-time_glossary_.label: time domain (OWL-Time glossary)
Entity-time_domain__owl-time_glossary_.description: The time domain in the OWL-Time glossary refers to a conceptual framework that defines and organizes temporal concepts and relationships for use in semantic web applications.

Entity-sosassn_w3c_recommendation.label: SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation
Entity-sosassn_w3c_recommendation.description: The SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation is a set of standards developed by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) for modeling and sharing sensor data and observations on the web.

Entity-a_session.label: A session
Entity-a_session.description: A session refers to the interaction between a subject and a context while performing a single activity under specific settings and conditions, encompassing both observations and actuations.

Entity-u.s._arl_translational_neuroscien.label: U.S. ARL Translational Neuroscience Branch
Entity-u.s._arl_translational_neuroscien.description: The U.S. ARL Translational Neuroscience Branch is a research branch of the U.S. Army Research Laboratory focused on advancing neuroscience applications, particularly in the context of brain-computer interaction and related technologies.

Entity-model_selector_for_the_data.label: Model Selector for the Data
aliases: the Model Selector for the Data
Entity-model_selector_for_the_data.description: The Model Selector for the Data refers to a component that identifies and selects annotated data segments characterized by their probabilities and correlations, along with classified recordings, to facilitate transfer learning in machine learning models.

mentions.local_name: the Model Selector for the Data

Entity-predictive_feature.label: predictive features
Entity-predictive_feature.description: Predictive features are data attributes or characteristics that are used as inputs in models to forecast outcomes or classifications based on the underlying data patterns.

Entity-record.label: record
Entity-record.description: In the context of EEG applications, 'record' refers to a specific subtype related to the collection and representation of EEG data, encompassing aspects such as channel, device, and modality.

Entity-transfer_learning_source_model.label: transfer learning source model
Entity-transfer_learning_source_model.description: A transfer learning source model is a pre-trained machine learning model that serves as a foundation for further training on a specific task or dataset, leveraging knowledge gained from previous tasks to improve performance.

Entity-two_machine_learning_model.label: two machine learning models
Entity-two_machine_learning_model.description: The term 'two machine learning models' refers to a transfer learning scenario involving a simple Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model, EEGNet, as the source model for classifying EEG recordings related to glaucoma detection, and a more complex 24-layer CNN model, RevNet+I, as the target model that analyzes features of the collected EEG signals.

Entity-semantic_relation.label: semantic relations
Entity-semantic_relation.description: Semantic relations refer to the connections and associations between concepts in terms of their meanings and the ways in which they relate to one another within a given context.

Entity-real-world_application.label: real-world applications
Entity-real-world_application.description: Real-world applications refer to practical uses or implementations of theories, technologies, or systems in everyday life or actual scenarios outside of experimental or theoretical settings.

Entity-preflabel.label: prefLabel
Entity-preflabel.description: prefLabel is a type of annotation property used in knowledge organization systems to provide a preferred label for a concept, facilitating clear identification and communication of that concept.

Entity-relational_database_system.label: relational database systems
Entity-relational_database_system.description: Relational database systems are structured data storage systems that organize data into tables with predefined relationships, allowing for efficient data retrieval and management using structured query language (SQL).

Entity-eye.label: eye
Entity-eye.description: The term 'eye' refers to the anatomical structure of the organ responsible for vision, with each subject in the study having one session that includes EEG recordings from both eyes.

Entity-machine_learning_technique.label: machine learning techniques
Entity-machine_learning_technique.description: Machine learning techniques refer to a set of methodologies and algorithms used to enable computers to learn from and make predictions or decisions based on data.

Entity-set_of_xsl_3_document.label: set of XSL 3 documents
Entity-set_of_xsl_3_document.description: The 'set of XSL 3 documents' refers to a collection of documents designed to transform the base OWL 2 RDF/XML version of the BCI Ontology into HTML format using XPath 3 functions and an accompanying XML configuration document.

Entity-feature-based_transfer_learning.label: feature-based transfer learning
Entity-feature-based_transfer_learning.description: Feature-based transfer learning is a machine learning technique that leverages features learned from one task to improve the performance of a model on a different but related task.

Entity-issue__1028.label: issue #1028
Entity-issue__1028.description: Issue #1028 refers to a specific discussion topic concerning the Homogeneity of an Observation Collection within the ongoing discussions related to the extensions of the SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation, which the authors are monitoring and providing feedback on from the perspective of the BCI Ontology.

Entity-semantic_model.label: semantic model
Entity-semantic_model.description: A semantic model is a theoretical framework or construct used to represent and analyze the meanings and relationships of concepts within a specific domain, often facilitating understanding and communication of complex information.

Entity-dc.label: DC
Entity-dc.description: DC refers to the Dublin Core Metadata Terms, a set of vocabulary terms used to describe a wide range of resources and facilitate metadata interoperability.

Entity-ucsd_research_team.label: UCSD research team
Entity-ucsd_research_team.description: The UCSD research team refers to a group of researchers at the University of California, San Diego, who conducted an experiment involving EEG recordings from glaucoma patients as part of their work on Brain-Computer Interaction.

Entity-the_categorization_of_the_observa.label: the categorization of the observations
Entity-the_categorization_of_the_observa.description: The categorization of the observations refers to the process of classifying EEG recordings into specific categories, such as Normal, G. Early, or G. Late, based on their annotations for glaucoma detection stages.

Entity-pervasive_embedding_technology__p.label: Pervasive Embedding Technologies (PET) Lab
Entity-pervasive_embedding_technology__p.description: The Pervasive Embedding Technologies (PET) Lab is a research facility at the National Chiao-Tung University in Taiwan, focused on developing semantic models to analyze neuro-physiological features and cognitive states in collaboration with other research institutions.

Entity-transfer_learning_target_model.label: transfer learning target model
Entity-transfer_learning_target_model.description: A transfer learning target model is a machine learning model that is specifically designed to be adapted or fine-tuned using knowledge gained from a different but related task or dataset.

Entity-eeg_data_sharing_tool.label: EEG data sharing tools
Entity-eeg_data_sharing_tool.description: EEG data sharing tools are software applications designed to facilitate the sharing and management of electroencephalogram (EEG) data among researchers and clinicians.

Entity-eeg_study.label: EEG Studies
Entity-eeg_study.description: EEG Studies refer to research investigations that utilize electroencephalography to measure and analyze electrical activity in the brain, often focusing on cognitive processes, neurological conditions, or event-related potentials.

Entity-many_layer.label: many layers
Entity-many_layer.description: The term 'many layers' refers to the multi-iterative process infrastructure utilized in the development of tools for training and personalizing machine learning models, which incorporates various levels of complexity and abstraction in handling semi-structured and non-interoperable metadata formats.

Entity-structured_metadata.label: structured metadata
Entity-structured_metadata.description: Structured metadata refers to organized information that provides context and meaning to data, facilitating its identification, management, and retrieval.

Entity-simple_knowledge_organization_sys.label: Simple Knowledge Organization System
Entity-simple_knowledge_organization_sys.description: The Simple Knowledge Organization System (SKOS) is a vocabulary designed for representing knowledge organization systems such as thesauri, classification schemes, and taxonomies in a machine-readable format, facilitating the sharing and reuse of semantic concepts on the web.

Entity-neuroimaging.label: neuroimaging
Entity-neuroimaging.description: Neuroimaging is a field of study that involves the use of various techniques to visualize and analyze the structure and function of the brain and nervous system.

Entity-wireless_network.label: wireless networks
Entity-wireless_network.description: Wireless networks are communication systems that allow devices to connect and exchange data without the use of physical cables, utilizing radio waves or other wireless communication technologies.

Entity-a_vocabulary_for_annotating_vocab.label: a vocabulary for annotating vocabulary descriptions
aliases: a vocabulary for annotating vocabulary descriptions
Entity-a_vocabulary_for_annotating_vocab.description: A vocabulary for annotating vocabulary descriptions (VANN) is a framework designed to provide standardized annotations for the descriptions of various vocabularies, facilitating the reuse and sharing of ontological concepts and their definitions.

mentions.local_name: a vocabulary for annotating vocabulary descriptions

Entity-linked_data.label: Linked Data
Entity-linked_data.description: Linked Data is a method of publishing structured data on the web in a way that allows it to be interlinked and become more useful through semantic connections.

Entity-semantic_query.label: semantic query
Entity-semantic_query.description: A semantic query is a type of query that retrieves information based on the meaning of the data rather than just its syntactic form, often used in data retrieval and information retrieval processes.

Entity-w3id.org.label: w3id.org
Entity-w3id.org.description: w3id.org is a web resource that provides a persistent identifier system for linking and managing namespaces in the context of the Semantic Web.

Entity-the_unity_framework_(1).label: the Unity framework
Entity-the_unity_framework_(1).description: The Unity framework is a widely-used game engine that provides a high-level modeling architecture for creating and managing complex environments through the organization of entities and their relationships from structural, behavioral, and temporal perspectives.

Entity-internet_of_service.label: Internet of Services
Entity-internet_of_service.description: The Internet of Services refers to a networked framework that enables the delivery and integration of services over the internet, facilitating interactions between various devices and applications.

Entity-standard_relational_database_syst.label: standard relational database systems
Entity-standard_relational_database_syst.description: Standard relational database systems are structured data management systems that use a relational model to store, retrieve, and manage data in tables, allowing for efficient querying and data integrity through the use of SQL (Structured Query Language).

Entity-multi-modal_data.label: multi-modal data
Entity-multi-modal_data.description: Multi-modal data refers to data that is collected from multiple sources or modalities, such as text, audio, images, and video, allowing for a comprehensive analysis and understanding of complex phenomena.

Entity-eeg_application.label: EEG applications
Entity-eeg_application.description: EEG applications refer to the various uses and implementations of electroencephalography technology in fields such as neuroscience, clinical diagnostics, and cognitive research.

Entity-dbp__person.label: dbp:Person
Entity-dbp__person.description: dbp:Person refers to a class in the DBpedia ontology that represents individuals or entities recognized as persons.

Entity-multi-iterative_process_infrastru.label: multi-iterative process infrastructure
Entity-multi-iterative_process_infrastru.description: The multi-iterative process infrastructure refers to a complex framework designed to facilitate the training and personalization of machine learning models through multiple layers, specifically utilizing semi-structured and non-interoperable metadata formats.

Entity-these_annotation_(1).label: These annotations
Entity-these_annotation_(1).description: These annotations refer to the classifications assigned to EEG recordings in a glaucoma detection study, specifically categorizing the recordings as Normal, G. Early, or G. Late based on the stage of glaucoma.

Entity-virtual_environment.label: virtual environment
Entity-virtual_environment.description: A virtual environment is a simulated setting created by computer software that allows users to interact with a computer-generated space, often used for training, gaming, or educational purposes.

Entity-spatial_data_on_the_web_working_g.label: Spatial Data on the Web Working Group
aliases: W3C Spatial Data on the Web Working Group
Spatial Data on the Web Working Group
Entity-spatial_data_on_the_web_working_g.description: The Spatial Data on the Web Working Group is a collaborative committee under the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) focused on developing standards and best practices for the representation and sharing of spatial data on the web.

mentions.local_name: Spatial Data on the Web Working Group
W3C Spatial Data on the Web Working Group

Entity-conceptualization.label: conceptualization
Entity-conceptualization.description: Conceptualization refers to the process of forming a clear and coherent idea or model of a concept, often involving analysis and design to define its structure and purpose.

Entity-owl_2_rdfxml_version.label: OWL 2 RDF/XML Version
Entity-owl_2_rdfxml_version.description: OWL 2 RDF/XML Version is a specification that defines a machine-readable format for representing OWL 2 ontologies using RDF/XML syntax.

Entity-ml_algorithm.label: ML algorithms
Entity-ml_algorithm.description: ML algorithms refer to computational methods and techniques used to analyze data, learn from it, and make predictions or decisions based on that data, typically within the field of machine learning.

Entity-definition.label: definition
Entity-definition.description: A definition is a statement that explains the meaning of a term or concept, often used to clarify its use and context within a specific domain.

Entity-multi-channel_time_series_data.label: multi-channel time series data
Entity-multi-channel_time_series_data.description: Multi-channel time series data refers to a type of data that consists of multiple sequences of observations recorded over time, where each sequence represents a different channel or variable, allowing for the analysis of temporal relationships and patterns across these channels.

Entity-raw_recorded_data.label: raw recorded data
Entity-raw_recorded_data.description: Raw recorded data refers to unprocessed information collected directly from experiments or observations, typically serving as the foundational input for analysis in research.

Entity-source_model.label: source model
Entity-source_model.description: The 'source model' refers to the EEGNet model, which is a simple 4-layer CNN used for glaucoma classification and serves as the basis for transfer learning in the context of analyzing EEG recordings.

Entity-each_recorded_data.label: Each recorded data
Entity-each_recorded_data.description: Each recorded data refers to the analyzed EEG recordings that consist of sequences of data segments, each associated with attributes indicating their probability and correlation, which are used to identify relevant epochs for classification in the context of glaucoma detection.

Entity-xsl_3_document.label: XSL 3 documents
Entity-xsl_3_document.description: XSL 3 documents refer to a collection of documents that utilize XSLT 3.0 to transform XML data into HTML format, specifically designed for the BCI-O specifications to facilitate the presentation of structured metadata in a web-friendly manner.

Entity-semantic_data_repository.label: semantic data repository
Entity-semantic_data_repository.description: A semantic data repository is a type of database designed to store, manage, and retrieve data that is annotated with semantic metadata, enabling advanced querying and interoperability based on the meaning of the data.

Entity-relevant_data_set_for_transfer_le.label: relevant data sets for Transfer Learning
aliases: relevant data sets for Transfer Learning
Entity-relevant_data_set_for_transfer_le.description: relevant data sets for Transfer Learning refer to collections of data specifically curated or utilized to enhance the performance of machine learning models by transferring knowledge from one domain to another.

mentions.local_name: relevant data sets for Transfer Learning

Entity-deep_learning.label: Deep Learning
Entity-deep_learning.description: Deep Learning is a subset of artificial intelligence and machine learning that uses neural networks with many layers to analyze and interpret complex data.

Entity-gaming_high-level_modeling_archit.label: Gaming High-Level Modeling Architecture
Entity-gaming_high-level_modeling_archit.description: The Gaming High-Level Modeling Architecture refers to the architectural modeling framework derived from the Unity game engine, which organizes and describes environments through structural, behavioral, and temporal perspectives to facilitate the design of complex systems.

Entity-domain_modeling.label: domain modeling
Entity-domain_modeling.description: Domain modeling is the process of creating abstract representations of a specific area of interest or knowledge, often used to understand and analyze the structure and behavior of that domain.

Entity-satisfiability_checkpoint.label: satisfiability checkpoint
Entity-satisfiability_checkpoint.description: A satisfiability checkpoint is a validation step in the ontology engineering process where the consistency and correctness of the ontology's axioms are assessed using a reasoner, ensuring that the defined concepts and relationships do not lead to contradictions.

Entity-feature_of_the_collected_eeg_sign.label: features of the collected EEG signals
aliases: features of the collected EEG signals
Entity-feature_of_the_collected_eeg_sign.description: The characteristics or attributes derived from electroencephalogram (EEG) signals that are used for analysis and interpretation.

mentions.local_name: features of the collected EEG signals

Entity-metadata.label: metadata
Entity-metadata.description: Metadata refers to data that provides information about other data, often used to describe the content, context, and structure of the primary data.

Entity-metadata_set.label: metadata sets
Entity-metadata_set.description: Metadata sets are collections of data that provide information about other data, facilitating its organization, retrieval, and management.

Entity-sophisticated_cnn_model.label: sophisticated CNN model
Entity-sophisticated_cnn_model.description: The 'sophisticated CNN model' refers to the RevNet+I, a complex 24-layer convolutional neural network used for analyzing features of EEG signals in the context of Early Glaucoma Detection.

Entity-4-layer_cnn_model.label: 4-layer CNN model
Entity-4-layer_cnn_model.description: The 4-layer CNN model refers to EEGNet, a straightforward convolutional neural network designed specifically for classifying different stages of glaucoma based on EEG recordings.

Entity-iot_community.label: IoT community
Entity-iot_community.description: The IoT community refers to a collective of individuals, organizations, and stakeholders involved in the development, implementation, and promotion of Internet of Things (IoT) technologies and applications.

Entity-semantic_search.label: semantic search
Entity-semantic_search.description: Semantic search is an information retrieval technique that aims to improve search accuracy by understanding the contextual meaning of search queries and the relationships between terms.

Entity-human_being.label: human beings
Entity-human_being.description: Human beings are members of the species Homo sapiens, characterized by their capacity for complex thought, language, and social interaction.

Entity-a_person.label: a person
Entity-a_person.description: The mention 'a person' refers to a human being engaged in an activity, characterized by specific attributes, and is equivalent to the term 'Patient' in the HL7 standard.

Entity-internet.label: Internet
Entity-internet.description: The Internet is a global network of interconnected computers and devices that communicate using standardized protocols, enabling the exchange of data and access to information.

Entity-content_negotiation.label: content negotiation
Entity-content_negotiation.description: Content negotiation is a mechanism used in web technologies and protocols that allows a client and server to agree on the best representation of a resource based on the client's capabilities and preferences.

Entity-categorization.label: categorization
Entity-categorization.description: Categorization is the process or methodology of classifying or grouping items, concepts, or observations based on shared characteristics or criteria.

Entity-dbpedia.label: dbpedia
Entity-dbpedia.description: DBpedia is a community-driven project that extracts structured content from the information created in Wikipedia, providing a knowledge base that enables the linking and querying of data across the web.

Entity-metadata_hierarchy.label: metadata hierarchy
Entity-metadata_hierarchy.description: A metadata hierarchy is a structured framework that organizes metadata into levels of importance or categories, facilitating the management and retrieval of information related to data sets.

Entity-integumentary.label: integumentary
Entity-integumentary.description: The integumentary system is a biological system that includes the skin, hair, nails, and associated glands, serving as a protective barrier for the body and playing roles in sensation, temperature regulation, and excretion.

Entity-semantic_expressiveness.label: semantic expressiveness
Entity-semantic_expressiveness.description: Semantic expressiveness refers to the ability of a language or system to convey complex meanings and relationships through its structure and vocabulary.

Entity-electrooculogram.label: electrooculogram
Entity-electrooculogram.description: An electrooculogram is a medical test that measures the electrical potential difference between the front and back of the human eye, used to assess eye movement and position.

Entity-sso_design_pattern.label: SSO Design Pattern
Entity-sso_design_pattern.description: The SSO Design Pattern is a software architecture concept that outlines a standardized approach for implementing Single Sign-On (SSO) functionality, allowing users to authenticate once and gain access to multiple applications or services without needing to log in separately for each one.

Entity-dcmitype.label: DCMIType
Entity-dcmitype.description: DCMIType is a vocabulary used in metadata standards to define types of resources in the context of the Dublin Core Metadata Initiative.

Entity-data_set.label: data sets
Entity-data_set.description: Data sets are organized collections of data, typically used for analysis, research, or training purposes in various fields.

Entity-time_domain.label: time domain
Entity-time_domain.description: The time domain refers to a conceptual framework or area of study that focuses on the representation and analysis of time-related data or phenomena.

Entity-4-layer_cnn.label: 4-layer CNN
Entity-4-layer_cnn.description: A 4-layer CNN is a convolutional neural network architecture that consists of four layers designed to process and analyze visual data.

Entity-xml-based_specification.label: XML-based specification
Entity-xml-based_specification.description: An XML-based specification that defines a structured metadata hierarchy for the documentation and description of electrophysiological studies and their associated raw data.

Entity-inference_rule.label: inference rules
Entity-inference_rule.description: Inference rules are formal guidelines or principles used in logic and reasoning frameworks to derive conclusions from premises, often applied in various fields such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, and data analysis.

Entity-ihmc_cmaptools.label: IHMC CmapTools
Entity-ihmc_cmaptools.description: IHMC CmapTools is a software application designed for creating and sharing concept maps, facilitating visual representation of knowledge and ideas.

Entity-arl.label: ARL
Entity-arl.description: ARL refers to the U.S. Army Research Laboratory, a government agency involved in advanced research and development projects, including those related to brain-computer interaction.

Entity-use_case.label: use case
Entity-use_case.description: A use case is a description of a specific situation or scenario in which a system or application is utilized to achieve a particular goal or outcome.

Entity-result.label: Results
Entity-result.description: Results refer to the outcomes or findings derived from a process or action, often used to evaluate the effectiveness or impact of an intervention or activity.

Entity-a_simple_linked_data_engine.label: A simple linked data engine
Entity-a_simple_linked_data_engine.description: A simple linked data engine refers to a system designed to manage and provide specialized linked data services, facilitating the delivery of HTML and RDF/XML versions of specifications and enabling URI entry points for various user agents.

Entity-environmental_condition.label: environmental conditions
Entity-environmental_condition.description: Environmental conditions refer to the various physical and biological factors in the surrounding environment that can influence living organisms and their interactions.

Entity-vigilance.label: vigilance
Entity-vigilance.description: Vigilance is a cognitive state characterized by the sustained attention and alertness required to detect and respond to potential stimuli or threats in the environment.

Entity-electrocardiogram__ecg_.label: electrocardiogram (ECG)
Entity-electrocardiogram__ecg_.description: An electrocardiogram (ECG) is a physiological signal that records the electrical activity of the heart over a period of time, commonly used in medical diagnostics and monitoring.

Entity-national_chiao-tung_university__n.label: National Chiao-Tung University (NCTU)
Entity-national_chiao-tung_university__n.description: National Chiao-Tung University (NCTU) is a prominent research university located in Taiwan, known for its contributions to technology and engineering, particularly in the fields of cognitive neuroscience and brain-computer interaction.

Entity-data_analysis.label: data analysis
Entity-data_analysis.description: Data analysis is the systematic process of inspecting, cleaning, transforming, and modeling data to discover useful information, inform conclusions, and support decision-making.

Entity-an_experiment.label: an experiment
Entity-an_experiment.description: An experiment refers to a structured investigation conducted by a UCSD research team involving the collection of EEG recordings from 100 subjects to study glaucoma detection stages.

Entity-the_unity_framework.label: the Unity framework
Entity-the_unity_framework.description: The Unity framework is a versatile game development platform that provides tools and architecture for creating interactive 2D and 3D content, widely used in the gaming industry and beyond for modeling complex environments and interactions.

Entity-reusability.label: reusability
Entity-reusability.description: Reusability refers to the design principle that emphasizes the ability to use components or systems in multiple applications or contexts without modification.

Entity-correlation.label: correlation
Entity-correlation.description: Correlation is a statistical measure that describes the degree to which two variables are related to each other.

Entity-dublin_core_metadata_term.label: Dublin Core Metadata Terms
Entity-dublin_core_metadata_term.description: Dublin Core Metadata Terms is a set of vocabulary terms used to describe a wide range of resources and their metadata, facilitating the organization and discovery of information on the web.

Entity-each_eye.label: each eye
Entity-each_eye.description: Each eye refers to the individual ocular organ of a subject, for which EEG recordings are collected during a session in the context of glaucoma detection.

Entity-an_eeg_recording.label: An EEG recording
Entity-an_eeg_recording.description: An EEG recording refers to a specific instance of electroencephalography data collected from a subject, which is analyzed and classified into categories related to glaucoma detection stages, such as Normal, G. Early, or G. Late.

Entity-24-layer_cnn_model.label: 24-layer CNN model
Entity-24-layer_cnn_model.description: A 24-layer CNN model is a convolutional neural network architecture consisting of 24 layers, designed for processing and analyzing data, particularly in tasks such as image recognition and feature extraction.

Entity-training_data.label: training data
Entity-training_data.description: Training data refers to the dataset used to train machine learning models, consisting of input examples that help the model learn patterns and make predictions.

Entity-spatial-temporal_location.label: spatial-temporal location
Entity-spatial-temporal_location.description: A spatial-temporal location refers to a specific point or area defined by both spatial coordinates and a temporal context, often used to describe where and when an event occurs.

Entity-rdf.label: RDF
Entity-rdf.description: RDF, or Resource Description Framework, is a standard model for data interchange on the web that facilitates the representation of information about resources in a structured way, enabling semantic web applications.

Entity-big_data_set.label: big data sets
Entity-big_data_set.description: Big data sets refer to large and complex collections of data that are generated and collected from various sources, which require advanced tools and techniques for storage, processing, and analysis.

Entity-existing_algorithm.label: existing algorithms
Entity-existing_algorithm.description: Existing algorithms refer to established computational methods or procedures that are currently in use for processing data or solving specific problems.

Entity-high_sampling_rate.label: high sampling rates
Entity-high_sampling_rate.description: High sampling rates refer to the frequency at which data points are collected in a given time period, indicating a high level of detail and precision in the representation of signals or data.

Entity-ontology_restructuring.label: Ontology restructuring
Entity-ontology_restructuring.description: Ontology restructuring refers to the process of refining and organizing an ontology by removing unnecessary elements (pruning) and dividing it into manageable, coherent modules to enhance its usability and clarity.

Entity-linked_data_service.label: linked data services
Entity-linked_data_service.description: Linked data services are services that facilitate the creation, management, and access of linked data, enabling the interconnection and integration of data across different sources using standardized web protocols and formats.

Entity-w3id.org_identifier.label: w3id.org identifier
Entity-w3id.org_identifier.description: A w3id.org identifier is a unique identifier associated with a namespace, used to facilitate the identification and referencing of resources on the web.

Entity-lov_registry.label: LOV registry
Entity-lov_registry.description: The LOV registry is a platform for publishing and sharing linked open vocabularies and ontologies, facilitating their discovery and reuse in various applications.

summary:
Key developments in wearable sensors, wireless networks, and distributed computing will largely enable Brain-Computer Interaction (BCI) as a powerful, natural and intuitive mainstream human-computer interaction in real-world activities. BCI systems annotate the sensed signals in order to classify the analysis of brain states and dynamics in diverse daily-life circumstances. There is no complete and standardized formal semantic structure to model the BCI metadata annotations, which are essential to capture the descriptive and predictive features of the brain signals.

We present the BCI Ontology (BCI-O): the first OWL 2 ontology that formalizes relevant metadata for BCI data capture activities by integrating BCI-domain-specific Sense and Actuation Models along with a novel Context Model for describing any kind of real or virtual environments. At its core, BCI-O defines a human-environment interaction model for any BCI, based on design patterns and primarily aligned to the SOSA/SSN, SAN-IoT-O, and DUL ontologies. Its axiomatizations aid BCI systems to implement an ontological overlay upon vast data recording collections to support semantic query constructions to perform Adaptive BCI and reasoning for situation-specific data analytics to apply inference rules for Transfer Learning in multimodal classification.

Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCI) are systems that analyze neuro-physiological signals like EEG to determine brain states and actuate responses, often using Machine Learning techniques. A project under the U.S. Army Research Laboratory involved the Pervasive Embedding Technologies Lab and the Swartz Center for Computational Neuroscience to develop a BCI Ontology for identifying cognitive states and facilitating Transfer Learning. The project created metadata vocabularies, EEG Study Schema (ESS) and Hierarchical Event Descriptor (HED), leading to the development of an ontological structure for BCI experiments. BCI-O aims to process neuro-physiological data for feature extraction and classification, aligning with W3C frameworks and IoT ontologies. A key contribution was integrating context into BCI-O, acknowledging that biological signals are context-dependent. The paper details BCI metadata, design principles, and future work.

Real-world multimodal BCI involves using sensors and actuators for human-environment interaction during activities, with contextual stimuli recorded in BCI data. BCI-O defines a bidirectional interaction model comprising a Sense Model (context to subject) and an Actuation Model (subject to context), based on specific ontologies. It includes two domains: the BCI domain (observations and interactions) and the context domain (surroundings), with concepts derived from the Unity framework and various standard vocabularies. Key formats include Extensible Data Format (XDF) for multi-channel data and EEG Study Schema (ESS) for electrophysiological studies. After data collection, systems annotate it with descriptive and predictive parameters for adaptive BCI. The ontology aims to define core BCI concepts, develop a machine-readable semantic model for interoperability, and ensure simplicity and reusability. The BCI-O framework is extendable for BCI system implementations.

BCI-O concepts are organized into modules that explain key aspects of the BCI interaction model. The Subject represents a person with attributes, akin to a Patient in HL7. Context describes the environment through scenes of interacting entities, linking stimuli, actions, and effects. A Session captures the interaction between a subject and context during an activity. The Sense Model details input data and observations, while Sensors relate to devices and their specifications. System Capabilities focus on data structure models, and Results encompass recorded data and actuation outcomes. The Actuation Model illustrates how subjects interact with contexts. Annotation Tags mark events and responses for predictive features, while Descriptors provide external resources for entity descriptions. EEG concepts cover subtypes for channels and devices, allowing interoperability in BCI systems. The specification allows flexibility in handling measurement units and extending procedures.

The Semantic Sensor Network (SSN) and its core ontology SOSA provide a framework that BCI-O extends for the BCI domain, offering a structure for Sense and Actuation Models. The Sense Model utilizes SSN to enhance semantic interoperability in BCI systems, connecting IoT and the Internet of Services. It describes sensor networks as Web applications and employs the Stimulus-Sensor-Observation (SSO) design pattern for observation-related ontologies. The Actuation Model is based on bci:Actuation and bci:Actuator, integrating the Semantic Actuator Network (SAN) and following the Actuation-Actuator-Effect (AAE) design pattern. BCI-O's design approach features a three-layered ontology architecture, aligning foundational, core, and domain layers. The Context Model is based on Unity's gaming architecture, which organizes entities and relationships from structural, behavioral, and temporal perspectives, ensuring consistency with DUL.

A proto-ontology was developed under the CaN-CTA Program for a BCI system, focusing on BCI and physical/virtual environments. The modeling process involved identifying major players and flows, formalizing characterizations, and defining common concepts. A hybrid modeling style was employed, utilizing verbal, logic-based, and structural-object approaches. Ontology authoring followed best practices from SSN and IoT-O, with a focus on relevant BCI metadata terms and class hierarchies. Popular vocabularies like Dublin Core and SKOS enriched the BCI-O concepts. Satisfiability was checked using the HermiT reasoner, and three versions of specifications were developed: Base, HTML, and OWL 2 RDF/XML. A linked data engine was created for serving specifications, and the BCI-O was published in the LOV registry on November 8, 2016.

The BCI-O proto-ontology was developed by NCTU and UCSD, with the U.S. ARL Translational Neuroscience Branch, to enable semantic search in large BCI datasets. It has been applied in various contexts, including neuroimaging for stress and fatigue, driving tests, and VR/AR goggle applications. The HTML version of BCI-O includes two applications: the CerebraTek vPod Ontology for glaucoma diagnostics and the ESS+HED Standards Ontology for EEG data sharing. These tools support machine learning model training using semi-structured metadata. A use case demonstrates BCI-O's role in transfer learning, where a semantic query selects high-correlation EEG data segments for a more advanced CNN model, RevNet+I, based on categorized observations from 100 glaucoma patients. The semantic query includes sections for semantic matching, query restrictions, model selection, and query projection. Overall, BCI-O enhances BCI systems by modeling subject-independent features and providing relevant datasets for personalized model calibration.

BCI-O models subject-context interactions while focusing on monitoring the brain dynamics. In the long term, we would like to take BCI-O as the basis towards generalizing a semantic model to describe how any human body bio-signal, not only from the brain, can be monitored and made to interact with computing interfaces. Initially, this work would lead to BCI-O's generalization towards a Bio-signal Computer-Interaction Ontology. This modeling task is planned to be one of the main development drivers in the future for a set of ontological frameworks to capture the different bio-signal markers and technological interfaces for the entire human body: organs such as the brain, heart, liver, and systems including nervous, integumentary, and endocrine.

Additionally, there is an ongoing effort on proposing some extensions to the SOSA/SSN W3C Recommendation. We are following closely the new proposed concepts and relationships and providing our feedback from the BCI-O perspective in their ongoing discussions, with special interest for issue #1028 regarding the Homogeneity of an Observation Collection. BCI-O will be updated accordingly following the structure and alignments of these extensions after the proposal becomes stable. Lastly, some BCI applications keep part of their metadata stored in standard relational database systems. As an aside project, we are planning to work on an OWL 2 QL profile version of BCI-O, so that those relevant metadata sets can be queried through a restrictive version of BCI-O.

As a foundational model for real-world BCI, BCI-O will become an important tool to aid large-scale BCI data analytics models and processes, due primarily to its OWL 2 formal structure. Semantic reasoning based tasks of BCI-O's axiomatizations enable BCI systems to carry out two major jobs: first, to apply inference rules to aid machine learning techniques, such as feature-based transfer learning in online multimodal EEG classification, and second, to perform Adaptive BCI, which involves training and refining brain state prediction and classification models based on relevant data sets constructed through semantic data queries.

Another key contribution of BCI-O is its novel Context Model. This model associates the context architectonic definition with the data recordings, making BCI systems semantically context-aware for real and virtual-world situations. Thus, it provides a semantic foundation for augmented BCI, assisting ambient intelligence settings in sensor systems for any kind of BCI. As a domain ontology for BCI sensors and actuators, BCI-O allows for semantically informed BCI analytics of sensor and actuator data patterns, including unambiguous searchability, similarities, simulations, and predictions, as well as semantic interoperability based on its alignments. This enables easy integration, reusability, and extensibility into the Linked Data world for all kinds of BCI. In general, its axiomatizations enable BCI systems to apply Semantic Web technologies for data analysis, serving as a form of semantic middleware for BCI sensor and actuator networks.

Predicate-enable.label: enable
Predicate-enable.description: The predicate 'enable' signifies a facilitative relationship where the subject provides the means, capability, or opportunity for the object to occur or be realized. It indicates that the subject plays a crucial role in making the object possible, thereby enhancing or allowing the functionality, process, or experience associated with the object.

Predicate-enable_(1).label: enable
Predicate-enable_(1).description: The predicate 'enable' signifies a relationship where the subject provides the necessary conditions, resources, or capabilities that allow the object to occur, function, or be realized. It indicates that the subject plays a crucial role in facilitating or empowering the object, thereby making it possible for the object to exist or operate effectively.

Predicate-is_used_in.label: is used in

It implies that the subject contributes to or facilitates the activities, processes, or contexts represented by the object.

Predicate-enables.label: enables
Predicate-enables.description: The predicate 'enables' indicates that the subject provides the means, capability, or opportunity for the object to occur or be realized. It suggests a facilitative relationship where the subject contributes to the functionality or implementation of the object, allowing it to be achieved or utilized effectively.
